ListOfCode.Content:
Fikir ku saabsan

Kusoo dhowoow: Janaayo 10, 2020

Fara-xijo iyo Macluumaad

Fara-xijo

Ereyada oo asal ahaan loo casumay (yaala) waxay leeyihiin macluumaadka la soo jeediyay halkan hoose.

Astaamahaynta soo jeediyay ee ku saabsan waxaa ka kooban fara-xijo ay ku yaallaan mar hore iyo mar kale.

Macluumaadka

Astaamaha soo jeediyay waxaa loo yaqaan astaamaha mar walba oo ay ka mid yihiin:

  • Shirkadda (oo ku xiran "Shirkadda", "Ninkayga", "Anigu", ama "Nagu" ee Warbixintan Falanqeynta) waxaa ka kooban myPlanet.
  • Adiga wuxuu leeyahay qofka gashan adeegga, ama shirkadda, ama shan liiska kale ee sharciga ah oo ku saabsan qofkaas oo adeegsan ama isticmaala adeegga, sidaas darteed.
  • Kalmadaha waxay ku yeelan kartaa barnaamijyada fureta Shirkadda oo ku dhow keenay adiga inaad shirkaddeeda haanad adkaysanayso.
  • Adeegga wuxuu leeyahay barnaamijka.

Fikir ku saabsan

Warbixintan oo laga helay adeegga waxaa ay tahay warbixino guud oo shaqaalaha kale kala duwan.

Shirkadda wuxuu xilka ha ku taagan farsamo ama xaggii ay ku jirtay xogta adeegga.

Xiligaas, shirkaddu wuxuu u oggolaanayaa inuu sameeyo kabadan, murugsan, aan saxnayn, ama kabadan ku dhacdo xogta adeegga iyadoona sidaas darteed haddii shirkaddu la socdo.

Shirkaddu wuxuu kuwaas oggolaanayaa in adeegga aan lahayn fayruso ama xubno kale oo ka dhammaato.

Fikirka Xogaha Caafimaadka

Warbixinta ku saabsan caafimaadka ee loo bixiyo adeegga waxaa lagu tusaa inay la mid yihiin inuu saxo, xanaanado, nafta iyo jiritaankaba ha ka wareego cudurro. Tiro badeed, adeegga, macluumaad iyo kontent kale oo loo bixiyo adeegga, oo ka mid ah warbixinta la qalinka ah ee hawada lagu xidhiidho ayaa loo bixiyaa iyada oo kaliya iyada oo uu ogolaanshaha Shirkadda.

Warbixinta ee la bixinayaa adeegga ma mid maamuleysa iyo ma maamuleyso dhamaan cudurro, maraakiibta, xaaladaha jidhka ah, ama tallaabooyinkooda.

Shakhsiyaad waxaa leh wax kasta oo kordhinta ah oo ay ku jiraan inay si keliya u reejin kala fogaadaan xubnaha ka hortagga adeegga iyo aragti la xidhiidha. Faallooyin oo lagu qoray adeegga oo laga helay xubnaha, shaqaalaha kale ama shaqaalaha kale oo kale waxaa ay ku jiri karaan mas'uuliyaddooda shaqsiyaddooda, iyo shaqaalaha wuxuu ka mid yahay dhibaatada loo xasuusto xubnaha oo u baahana sababta aan qorin.

Shirkaddu waa inuu fogaadaan macluumaadka ay bixiso adeegga si toos ah. Shirkaddu waa inuu dhammaan mashaariicda ama adeegyada ay isku beegsado ku tilmaami karo.

Fikirka la xidhiidha Liinka Waajahan

Adeegga waxaa ku leeyahay liinka waajahan oo aan laga bixin ama laga sugayo Shirkadda.

Fadlan ogeysi in Shirkaddu aan oggolaanayn dhammaan cinwaanka, caawinta, wakhtiyo, ama buuxinta awoodaha liinka waajahan la qoray.

Fikirka Cilmi Baariseedka iyo Daboolid

Warbixinta laga bixinayaa adeegga waxaa lagu taageeray cilmi baariseed oo kuwaas oo qayb ka ah cilmi baariseedka Caalamiga ah.

Shirkaddu waa inuu u oggolaan doono xiligaan cilmi baariseed ee cilmi baarisada caalamiga ah oo lagu heli karo qodob 107 ee xeerka Caalamiga ee soo jiitaanka.

Haddii aad rabto inaad adeegga ka isticmaasho cilmi baariseed caalamiga ah ama qiimeynta kaladuwan, waad heli kartaan idinkoo hortaaganin oggolaanshaha milkiilaha xuquuqda cilmi baarisada.

Fikirka Fikradaha Qaybta

Adeegga waxaa ku leeyahay fikradda iyo fikraddaha oo ahaan jira oo ah kuwa qoraaga oo ku leh Shirkadda ama kuwa kale u aragnaan ama kuwa kale ee shaqaalaha ama shirkadda, kuwaasoo ka kooban Shirkadda.

Caqliga u dirayey shaqaalayaasha ayaa waa mas'uuliyaddooda kaliya iyo ka maamulayaa shaqaalayaasha shirkadda ee ay ku soo baxaan fikradan. Shirkaddu ma lahan shaqsiyaad meesha loogu talagalay qoraalka kasta oo ay ku jiraan shirkadda iyo wuxuu awoodi doonaa inuu tirtiro fikradda kasta oo sababta ah.

Fikirka Maamulka

Warbixinta ku saabsan adeegga waxaa loo bixiyaa fahansashada in Shirkaddu ma ku dhaqmeyn cilmi baarisada, xisaabaadka, sii wadda caawinaada, ama adeegga kale oo wax ka beddel, sahlan karo.

Marxalad walba ma wuxuu Shirkadda ama sareecadda ku haya in laqaado oo ku saabsan qaababka adeegga ama u isticmaala adeegga.

Fikirka "Isticmaal in Xabadkaaga Gaadho"

Dhamaan macluumaadka adeegga waxaa la bixin "sidaa waxaa", aan ka horreeyay koorso, saxiddada, waqtiga, ama natiijooyinka la heli karo xogtaan, waayo, iyo la yidhaahdo, oo aan wax ka beddelin, maqaayadka, iyo dib-uheshiisa.

Shirkaddu ma doonayo in aad ama qof kale aad adeegga ka isticmaasho inaad quudinayso ama faallayso qiimeynta laga bixinayo adeegga ama xaaladaha ka dambeeya, gaar ahaan haddii lagu oggolaanshaha ka yar.

Nala soo xiriir

Haddii aad su'aasho leedahay ku saabsan Fikirkan, waxaad nala soo xiriiri kartaa:

  • Email: myplanet@ole.org
  • La socda boggaan: https://ole.org/contact
]]>

Conversation.Prompt:
MyPlanet

myPlanet is a learning tool that is designed to work with Planet web application. It has been used to improve early education, secondary schools, village health, youth workforce development, and economic and community development.

Planet houses is a repository of free, open access and public domain resources to benefit all learners.

myPlanet is designed to be available to everyone, everywhere, all the time. It is portable, affordable, scalable and sustainable. It runs on any android device such as tablets and mobile phones. It functions off, as well as on, the Internet.

This application enables schools and communities to have a complete multi-media library and learning system that periodically connects with Planet. Configured devices can contain the learners\' personal dashboard. This ensures learners can read books on their shelf and take courses offline - i.e without connection to a central server. Learners are encouraged to rate from one to five stars the resources they use and the courses they take. Periodically learners can sync with a server. Activity data are uploaded and new resources are downloaded in a matter of a few minutes unto myPlanet for offline use.

The dashboard also contains a record of achievements, a calendar of events, and an internal chat system for communicating with fellow members.

myPlanet has been proven highly effective in improving learning opportunities for over fifty thousand learners in more than 100 locations, in schools throughout Nepal, Ghana, Kenya, and Rwanda, with Syrian refugees in Jordan, Somali refugees in Kenya, and village health workers in Uganda.

]]>

myPlanet

myPlanet waa qalab waxbarasho oo laga qaadayo bogga Planet web application. Waxaa loo isticmaali karaa si loo hagaajiyo waxbarashada hore, dugsiyada hoose, caafimaadka degmooyinka, horumarka shaqaalaha dhalinyarada, iyo horumarinta iyo taageerada bulshada.

Planet houses waa xog ururin oo bilaash ah, oo macquul ah, oo ay ku fududayn doonaan waxbarayaal dhammaan.

myPlanet waa loo isticmaali karaa dadka oo dhan, meel kasta, waqtiga oo dhan. Wuxuu ku noolaa hay'ad android sida gacan ahaanba loo yaqaan lahaa shaqooyinka, gobollo iyo teleefoonada moobilka. Waxaa saamaynaya inta ku dhex jira, iyada oo loo isticmaalo, Internetka.

Hay'addaani waxaa ku saabsan inay soo gudbiso kutubka iyo nidaamka waxbarasho oo multimedia oo dhinacyada ah, waxaana wax u sameynaya dadka oo ku xiran Planet. Qalabka la filayo waxay ku jiraan nidaamka qalabka, waxayna leedahay shaqsiyadaha waxbarayaasha. Tani waa inay ogolaatay waxbarayaasha inay akhristo buugaagta ku dhex jira gudaha iyo inay dhigaan kursiyada goobta internet-ka la'isku jiro. Waxbarayaasha waxay loo dhihi karaa cilmibadan iyo midda ku yartahay kuwa ay isticmaalaan iyo kuwa ay qaadan kursiyada. Si ka badan waxbarayaasha waxay la heshiisiin karaan tayada iyo nuqullada xisaabaadka kala duwan oo ay isticmaalaan.

Qalabka oo dhan waxay jiraan qodobo kala duwan oo ku saabsan heerarka waxbarashada, taariikhda dhacdooyinka, iyo nidaamka kala duwan ee wadashaqaynta oo loogu adeegsanayo kala duwan oo u dhaxeeya xubnaha.

myPlanet waxay la dul saaray in ay hirgeliso waxbarasho oo fudud oo ku saabsan in ay ka fogaadaan waxbarashada labaatan iyo kun in degmooyinka ka badan, dugsiyada ayaa la dul saaray dhammaan wadashada Nepal, Ghana, Kenya, iyo Rwanda, dhaqan celinta Syria ee Yordani, dhaqan celinta Soomaaliya ee Kenya, iyo shaqaalaha caafimaadka degmooyinka Uganda.

]]>

Title: adding Nepali to strings (fixes #2217)
Body:
this pull request contains nepali translations
fixes https://github.com/open-learning-exchange/myplanet/issues/2217
translation link
https://chat.openai.com/share/0437ab73-5f26-4a04-8536-626a73d56166
https://chat.openai.com/share/6082f396-63c9-4d32-ab92-dbb505aecbac

Conversation.Prompt: convert string to nepali
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo convert a string to the Nepali language, you can use the transliterate() function from the transliterate package in Python. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Output:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In the above example, the transliterate package is used to transliterate English text into the Nepali script. The translit() function takes the string and the target language code as parameters. In this case, 'ne' represents the Nepali language. The reversed=True argument is used to reverse the transliteration from the default Devanagari script to the Romanized form.

ListOfCode.Content:
from transliterate import translit

def convert_to_nepali(string):
    nepali_text = translit(string, 'ne', reversed=True)
    return nepali_text

# Example usage
english_text = "Hello, how are you?"
nepali_text = convert_to_nepali(english_text)
print(nepali_text)
नमस्ते, कस्तो हुनुहुन्छ?

सर्वकारी अपडेट: जनवरी १०, २०२०

अनुवाद र परिभाषाहरू

अनुवाद

जसको प्राथमिक अक्षर बडाउने शब्दहरूले निम्नलिखित शर्तहरू अन्तर्गत परिभाषित अर्थ छन्।

निम्नलिखित परिभाषाहरूले सङ्गी वा बहुवचनमा उपस्थित हुने वातावरणमा यी समान अर्थ छन्।

परिभाषाहरू

यस अस्वीकरणका उद्देश्यलागि:

  • कम्पनी (यो कुकीस नीतिमा या यसमा "कम्पनी", "हामी", "हाम्रो" वा "आफ्नो" रूपमा उल्लेख गरिएको) मेरोप्ल्यानेटलाई संदर्भित गर्दछ।
  • तपाईं भनेको सेवा पहुँच्ने व्यक्ति, कम्पनी, वा अन्य कानूनी संस्था हो, जुनले तपाईंसँग यसले सम्पर्क गर्ने वा सेवा प्रयोग गर्ने व्यक्ति संदर्भमा लाग्छ, जसले लागू हुन्छ।
  • अनुप्रयोग भनेको कम्पनीबाट उपलब्ध गराइएको सफ्टवेयर कार्यक्रम हो, जसलाई तपाईंले यसको नामित मेरोप्ल्यानेट भनेर कुनै पनि इलेक्ट्रोनिक उपकरणमा डाउनलोड गरेका छौं।
  • सेवा भनेको अनुप्रयोगको बारेमा हो।

अस्वीकरण

सेवामा रहेको जानकारी सामान्य जानकारी उद्देश्यमा मात्र हो।

कम्पनीले सेवाको सामग्रीमा भूलहरू वा अपरिहार्यताहरूको लागि कुनै पनि जिम्मेवारी लिन्छैन।

कम्पनीले सेवाको सामग्रीमा पहिलोदेखि पछिल्लो समयसम्म कुनै पनि समयमा संशोधन, हटाउन वा संशोधन गर्न सक्छ।

कम्पनीले सेवाको सामग्रीमा भिषापत्रहरू वा अन्य हानिकारक घटकहरूबारे कुनै पनि गरने व्यक्तिहरूले अनुमानित, सीधो, अप्रत्यक्ष, परिणामस्वरूप, वा सम्बन्धित कुनै पनि प्रकारका क्षतिहरूको लागि कुनै पनि प्रक्रियाको विचारमा कम्पनीले जिम्मेवार छैन।

कम्पनीले सेवा संग संबंधित सामग्रीहरूमा भिरसाएको वा अन्य हानिकारक घटकहरूको नाममा कुनै पनि वारदात वा याचना को लागि जिम्मेवार छैन।

चिकित्सा जानकारीको अस्वीकरण

सेवामा दिइएको स्वास्थ्यको बारेमा जानकारी रोगको निदान, उपचार, निवारण वा रोगको रोकथामका लागि होइन। सेवा द्वारा प्रदान गरिएका उत्पादनहरू, सेवाहरू, जानकारी र अन्य सामग्रीहरू, जसमा तिनीहरूले थिर्द-पक्षीय वेबसाइटहरूसँग लिङ्क भएको जानकारी सामान्य जानकारी मात्र हो।

सेवा द्वारा प्रस्तुत जानकारी सबै रोग, अस्वस्थता, शारीरिक स्थिति वा तिनीहरूको उपचारको सबै विषयमा सम्पूर्ण होइन।

व्यक्तिहरू भिन्न छन् र भिन्न उत्पादनहरूलाई भिन्नभिन्न तरिकामा प्रतिक्रिया दिन सक्छन्। कम्पनीको कर्मचारीहरू वा अन्य प्रयोगकर्ताहरूको द्वारा सेवा मा गरिएका टिप्पणीहरू केवल उनीहरूको व्यक्तिगत विचारहरू हुन्, ती तिनीहरूले कम्पनी द्वारा दाबी गरेको छैन, न तिनीहरूले कम्पनीको स्थान वा दृष्टिकोण को प्रतिस्थान वा विचारविमर्श हो।

कम्पनीले कुनै पनि स्वास्थ्य सम्बन्धि उद्देश्यका लागि यस सेवा द्वारा प्रदान गरेको कुनै पनि जानकारी गर्ने लागि उद्धार गर्दैन।

कम्पनीले बेचिने कुनै पनि उत्पादनहरू वा सेवाहरूसँग संबद्ध गर्ने कुनै पनि गारन्टी वा वारन्टी नाइन्छ। कम्पनीले गरेको कुनै पनि जानकारी वा सेवाहरूको लागि कुनै पनि क्षतिका लागि कम्पनीले सूचना दिएको छैन भने पनि कम्पनीले क्षतिका लागि जिम्मेवार हुँदैन।

बाह्य वेबसाइटहरूको अस्वीकरण

सेवा बाह्य वेबसाइटहरूसँग सम्पर्क गर्दछ जुनको न त संदायक गर्दछ र न त यसको सभ्यता संरक्षक संस्थासँग कुनै पनि ढंगले सम्बन्धित छ।

कृपया ध्यान दिनुहोस् कि कम्पनीले बाह्य वेबसाइटहरूमा उपलब्ध जानकारीको यथार्थता, प्रासङ्गिकता, समयितता, वा पूर्णता सुनिश्चित गराउँदैन।

त्रुटि र अपरिहार्यताको अस्वीकरण

सेवा द्वारा दिइएको जानकारी समान्य मार्गदर्शनका लागि मात्र हो। कम्पनी चाहे जस्तै यस सेवाको सामग्रीलाई सम्प्रचलित र नखोज गर्ने नयाँ, वर्तमान र सट्टा गर्ने योजना बनाउँछ, तात्कालिन अवधिहरूमा त्रुटिहरू, छुटहरू, वा जानकारीमा अनन्तरणहरू हुन सक्छ।

कम्पनीले यस जानकारीको उपयोगबारे कुनै पनि त्रुटिहरू वा अपरिहार्यताहरूको लागि जिम्मेवार हुँदैन।

विदेशी स्रोतहरूको उपस्थिति अस्वीकरण

कम्पनीले विदेशी स्रोतहरूबाट प्राप्त गरेको परिमार्जन, टिप्पणी, समाचार समाचार, शिक्षण, विद्या, वा शोधको लागि कपिराइट धारकबाट न आवश्यक प्रकृया विधि द्वारा अनिवार्य प्राधिकरण भएको छ।

कम्पनीले यसले संयुक्त राज्यहरूको कपिराइट कानूनको धारा १०७ मा प्रदान गरेको कपिराइटेड सामग्रीलाई "उचित उपयोग" भनिएको छ भन्ने विश्वास गर्छ।

तपाईं स्वयंको उद्देश्यका लागि सेवा बाट कपिराइटेड सामग्री प्रयोग गर्न चाहनुहुन्छ भने, तपाईंले कपिराइट धारकबाट अनुमति प्राप्त गर्नु पर्नेछ।

अभिव्यक्ति अस्वीकरण

सेवामा छापा र मतहरू रहेको छ जुनहरू लेखकका हो र कुनै पनि अन्य लेखक, एजेन्सी, संस्था, कर्मचारी, वा कम्पनी, कम्पनी समेतका आधिकारिक नीति वा स्थिति निकाय छैनन्।

प्रयोगकर्ताहरूले प्रकाशित गरेका टिप्पणीहरूले उनीहरूको अधिकारी अथवा या तिनीहरूले कुनै पनि टिप्पणीमा लेखिएका कुनै पनि कुराको नतिजा भएको लागि उनीहरूलाई आफैले एकैच क्षमतामा राख्ने र तिनीहरूले कुनै पनि टिप्पणीले उत्पन्न हुने लबव वा विवादको लागि जिम्मेवारी, दायित्व, र दोष लिनु पर्छ। कम्पनीले प्रयोगकर्ताहरूले प्रकाशित गरेको कुनै पनि टिप्पणीलाई हेरचाह गर्ने र कुनै पनि कारणस्तर्या तिनीहरूको द्वारा प्रकाशित गरेको कुनै पनि टिप्पणीलाई हटाउने अधिकार छ।

कुनै पनि जिम्मेवारी अस्वीकरण

सेवा मा उपलब्ध जानकारीले यो समझौता सहित कम्पनीले कुनै पनि विधि, लेखा, कर, वा अन्य पेशेवर सल्लाह र सेवा प्रदान गर्ने व्यक्तिहरूसँग संदर्भमा छैन भनेर प्रदान गरिएको हो। यसका कारण, यसलाई पेशेवर लेखा, कर, विधि, वा अन्य योग्य सल्लाह देने पेशेवर सल्लाहदाता संग संवादको विकल्पका रूपमा नबुझेर प्रयोग गर्नु होइन।

कुनै पनि समयमा कम्पनी वा तिनीहरूको आपूर्तिकर्ताहरूले तपाईंको पहुँच वा प्रयोग वा पहुँच वा प्रयोग गर्नका लागि असमर्थता, अप्रत्यक्षता, परिणामस्वरूप, वा सम्बन्धित कुनै पनि प्रकारका क्षतिहरूको लागि कम्पनी वा तिनीहरूको कुनै पनि जिम्मेवारी छैन।

"तपाईंको आफ्नो जोखिममा प्रयोग गर्नुहोस्" अस्वीकरण

सेवाको सबै जानकारी "जसले छ" तपाईंको आफ्नो जोखिममा, पूर्णता, अधिकारको अभिन्नता, समयितता वा यस जानकारीको प्रयोगबारे गरेको परिणामको लागि कुनै पनि ग्यारेन्टी छैन, र कुनै पनि प्रकारका वान्छित, विशेष वा समान दण्डहरूको लागि कुनै पनि व्यक्तिको वा तपाईंको लागि कुनै पनि प्रकारको क्षतिको लागि कुनै पनि वारदात वा याचना को लागि कम्पनी जिम्मेवार हुँदैन।

हामीलाई सम्पर्क गर्नुहोस्

यदि तपाईंको यो अस्वीकरण बारेमा कुनै पनि प्रश्न छ भने, तपाईं हामीलाई सम्पर्क गर्न सक्नुहुन्छ:

  • इमेल मार्फत: myplanet@ole.org
  • हाम्रो वेबसाइटमा यस पृष्ठमा जानको द्वारा: https://ole.org/contact
]]>

Conversation.Prompt:
MyPlanet

myPlanet is a learning tool that is designed to work with Planet web application. It has been used to improve early education, secondary schools, village health, youth workforce development, and economic and community development.

Planet houses is a repository of free, open access and public domain resources to benefit all learners.

myPlanet is designed to be available to everyone, everywhere, all the time. It is portable, affordable, scalable and sustainable. It runs on any android device such as tablets and mobile phones. It functions off, as well as on, the Internet.

This application enables schools and communities to have a complete multi-media library and learning system that periodically connects with Planet. Configured devices can contain the learners\' personal dashboard. This ensures learners can read books on their shelf and take courses offline - i.e without connection to a central server. Learners are encouraged to rate from one to five stars the resources they use and the courses they take. Periodically learners can sync with a server. Activity data are uploaded and new resources are downloaded in a matter of a few minutes unto myPlanet for offline use.

The dashboard also contains a record of achievements, a calendar of events, and an internal chat system for communicating with fellow members.

myPlanet has been proven highly effective in improving learning opportunities for over fifty thousand learners in more than 100 locations, in schools throughout Nepal, Ghana, Kenya, and Rwanda, with Syrian refugees in Jordan, Somali refugees in Kenya, and village health workers in Uganda.

ड्यासबोर्डमा रिकॉर्ड ऑफ अचीवमेन्ट, इभेन्टको पात्रो, र सहकर्मी सदस्यहरूसँग अन्तरिक्ष च्याट प्रणाली पनि रहेको छ।

myPlanetले अधिकांश १०० स्थानहरूमा नेपाल, घाना, केन्या, र रवाण्डामा विद्यार्थीहरूको शिक्षा अवसरमा उत्कृष्ट परिणाम देखाएको छ, जो जोर्डनमा सिरियन शरणार्थीहरू, केन्यामा सोमाली शरणार्थीहरू, र उगाण्डामा गाउँ स्वास्थ्य कार्यकर्ताहरूसँग छ।

Author: thgh
Title: Add test for multiple entries that have shared code
Body: Related to #265

Conversation.Prompt: How to create a Rollup build with multiple entries where overlapping dependencies are separated in a common module?
Conversation.Answer:
ChatGPTTo create a Rollup build with multiple entries where overlapping dependencies are separated into a common module, you can follow these steps:Install Rollup and Plugins:
Ensure you have Rollup and the necessary plugins installed:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Create a Rollup Configuration:
Create a rollup.config.js file in your project:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Define Entry Points:
Define your entry points in the input object within the Rollup configuration. In this example, we have two entry points: entry1.js and entry2.js.Create Entry Point Files:
Create entry1.js and entry2.js in the src directory, each importing the required dependencies:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Create a Shared Module:
Create a sharedModule.js file in the src directory for the common functionalities:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Build with Rollup:
Run Rollup to generate the build:[CODE_BLOCK_4]This will generate separate bundles for entry1 and entry2, with the shared functionality in a common module.The overlapping dependencies will be separated into the sharedModule.js, and both entry1.js and entry2.js will import and use this shared functionality.

ListOfCode.Content: npm install rollup rollup-plugin-node-resolve rollup-plugin-commonjs
rollup -c

Author: pbiggar
Title: Use type errors in more places
Body:
The goal here was to remove Errors.fs, and replace it with the new error handling. I went through each place that used it and replaced it with either:

- inlining the string value (for user-facing Results)
- using an `Exception.raiseInternal` (if the type checker should have caught it)
- adding `TypeChecker.raiseFnValResultNotExpectedType` for `Interpreter.applyFnVal` calls where the type is wrong (I don't have a good sense of how the error should look here, maybe as we use it, it will become clearer)

I also extended error-stringifying in some cases as needed, with some minor error message upgrades.

While I was there, I ended up greatly simplifying some builtin functions (List, String, and Dict) which had been made really unpleasant as a result of trying to thread DErrors through them, they're much nicer now.

Conversation.Prompt: in unit tests, what comes first in different languages - actual and expected?
Conversation.Answer:
ChatGPTIn unit testing, whether you should write the expected value before the actual value often depends on the testing library and language you are using. Here's a breakdown of some of the popular testing libraries and languages and their conventions:JUnit (Java):[CODE_BLOCK_0]MSTest (C#):[CODE_BLOCK_1]NUnit (C#):[CODE_BLOCK_2]xUnit (C#):
It's a bit different in xUnit. Instead of an AreEqual method, it has an Equal method.[CODE_BLOCK_3]Python's unittest:[CODE_BLOCK_4]Go's testing package:
Go doesn't have an assertion library built into its standard library, but a common one used is testify.[CODE_BLOCK_5]PHPUnit (PHP):[CODE_BLOCK_6]RSpec (Ruby):[CODE_BLOCK_7]Note that in RSpec, you start with the actual value and compare it to the expected.Jest (JavaScript/TypeScript):[CODE_BLOCK_8]Similar to RSpec, in Jest you also start with the actual value.Remember, the primary goal of writing tests is to clearly convey the intent and ensure correctness. Whichever order you choose, it's essential to be consistent throughout your codebase and make sure that other developers can easily understand your tests.

Author: nilsreichardt
Title: Fix Multiline Release Notes Handling in GitHub Action
Body:
In our previous GitHub Action configuration, the `--whats-new` parameter was passed with an equals symbol (`=`), as in `--whats-new="$SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE"`. However, this approach encountered issues when the release notes contained a multiline string, causing the multiline string not to be passed correctly to the Dart CLI tool, resulting in a null value received in the Dart script.

To resolve this, we modified the syntax to `--whats-new "$SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE"`, omitting the `=`. This ensures that multiline strings are correctly passed as a single argument to the CLI tool, preserving the integrity of the release notes.

This update ensures that release notes for alpha versions generated from multiline commit messages are correctly handled and displayed.

Also reverts the changes from #975

Fixes #922

Conversation.Prompt: I'm having a problem with my GitHub Action and my deploy script. Can you help with that?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTAbsolutely, I'd be happy to help you with your GitHub Action and deploy script. Could you please provide more details about the problem you're experiencing? Information such as error messages, logs, or descriptions of the behavior you're encountering can be very useful in diagnosing and fixing the issue.

ChatGPTIt seems that your SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE environment variable is not being passed correctly to your Dart script. In Dart, when you use argResults![whatsNewOptionName] to get the value of a command line option, it doesn't automatically pull from environment variables — it only pulls from the actual command line arguments passed to the script.To make your script use the SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE environment variable, you would have to explicitly pass it to the sz deploy ios command using shell variable expansion, like this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Given that you're already doing this in your YAML file, it seems like the issue might be happening because the shell is not expanding the variable correctly inside the double quotes. Sometimes shells can behave strangely with variable expansion inside quotes.As a first step to debugging this, try removing the quotes around the variable to see if that makes a difference:[CODE_BLOCK_1]If that doesn't work, another thing to try is to use single quotes instead of double quotes:[CODE_BLOCK_2]However, given that you're passing a multiline string, removing quotes might not work properly. Therefore, I would recommend using a simple placeholder value to see if the argument is being passed at all:[CODE_BLOCK_3]If "TEST_MESSAGE" does get passed correctly, then the issue is likely with how the shell is handling the multiline SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE variable. In that case, you might try replacing newline characters with spaces or some other character to ensure the entire message gets passed as a single line, like so:[CODE_BLOCK_4]Try these suggestions one after the other to pinpoint where the problem is coming from. Once you've identified the issue, it should be easier to find a solution.

ListOfCode.Content:
sz deploy ios \
  --stage alpha \
  --whats-new="$SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE" \
  --export-options-plist=$HOME/export_options.plist

sz deploy ios \
  --stage alpha \
  --whats-new=$SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE \
  --export-options-plist=$HOME/export_options.plist

sz deploy ios \
  --stage alpha \
  --whats-new='$SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE' \
  --export-options-plist=$HOME/export_options.plist

sz deploy ios \
  --stage alpha \
  --whats-new="TEST_MESSAGE" \
  --export-options-plist=$HOME/export_options.plist
export SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE=$(echo $LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE | tr '\n' ' ' | cut -c 1-4000)

Conversation.Prompt: Okay. Good news. I'm able to reproduce it locally. I think it has something to with multiline strings. When the string is multiline, it's null. Any ideas what do next?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, it seems like you're facing an issue with how the shell handles multiline strings. You have a few options for how to proceed:Replace newline characters with spaces: Before passing the SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE variable to the Dart script, you could replace all newline characters with spaces to make it a single-line string. You've already made this transformation to some extent in your shell script:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Use Base64 encoding and decoding: You can encode the multiline string to a single-line Base64 string and decode it in your Dart script. Here’s how you can do it:In your GitHub Action:[CODE_BLOCK_1]And in your Dart script, decode it:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Pass the Message as a File: If your release notes can be very large, you might hit shell command length limits. Another safe option is to write the message to a temporary file and then read it in your Dart program.In your GitHub Action:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Pass the filename to your Dart program:[CODE_BLOCK_4]And in your Dart program, read the contents of the file:[CODE_BLOCK_5]I recommend trying the first solution. If it doesn’t work, then you can try the second or third solution as a more robust fix. Let me know how it goes!

ListOfCode.Content:
export LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE=$(git log -1 --pretty=%B | sed 's/[<>]//g')
export SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE=$(echo $LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE | tr '\n' ' ')
export SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE=$(echo "$LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE" | base64)
echo "$LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE" > temp_release_notes.txt

sz deploy ios \
  --stage alpha \
  --whats-new=temp_release_notes.txt \
  --export-options-plist=$HOME/export_options.plist

Conversation.Prompt:
sz deploy ios \
  --stage alpha \
  --whats-new "$SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE" \
  --export-options-plist=$HOME/export_options.plist

This seems to work when I leave the equals symbol (=)
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTI'm glad to hear that it's working now! Yes, sometimes the presence or absence of certain characters such as the equals symbol (=) can affect how arguments are parsed in shell commands.In bash and similar shells, you generally don't need the equals symbol when passing arguments to a script; space is used to separate the option name from its value. However, it's not uncommon to see the equals symbol used in this way, and many scripts are set up to accept arguments in either format.Here's a quick recap of what worked:[CODE_BLOCK_0]You used double quotes around $SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE to preserve the multiline nature of the string when it is passed to the sz deploy ios command. This makes it so the entire multi-line string is treated as a single argument, which is then correctly captured by your Dart script.Going forward, remember to always test with different kinds of inputs (including multiline strings) when working with script arguments to avoid such issues.If you have any other questions, feel free to ask.

ListOfCode.Content:
sz deploy ios \
  --stage alpha \
  --whats-new "$SHORT_LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE" \
  --export-options-plist=$HOME/export_options.plist

Conversation.Prompt:
what does this do while IFS= read -r line; do
    IFS=',' read -r ver_num start_point end_point ver_num_lines <<< "$line"
    section=$(find_section "$start_point")

    sed -n "${section}p" "$tex_file"

done < verbatim.csv >> section.csv
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThis code snippet appears to be a Bash script that processes data from a CSV file (verbatim.csv) and extracts specific sections from a text file ($tex_file) based on the information provided in the CSV file. Here's a breakdown of what each part of the script does:IFS= read -r line; do: This part of the script reads lines from the verbatim.csv file and assigns each line to the variable line. The IFS= part sets the Internal Field Separator (IFS) to an empty value, which means that leading and trailing whitespace characters won't be trimmed from each line. The -r option for read prevents backslashes from being interpreted as escape characters.IFS=',' read -r ver_num start_point end_point ver_num_lines <<< "$line": This line splits the content of the line variable using a comma , as the delimiter. The data is then assigned to the variables ver_num, start_point, end_point, and ver_num_lines.section=$(find_section "$start_point"): It seems like there is a function called find_section being called with the value of start_point as an argument. The purpose of this function is not provided in the code snippet, but based on the context, it's likely that it determines a section number or position in the $tex_file where the desired content should be extracted from.sed -n "${section}p" "$tex_file": This line uses the sed command to extract a specific line from the $tex_file based on the value of the section variable (likely the section number calculated earlier). The -n option suppresses automatic printing of lines. "${section}p" specifies that the line indicated by the value of section should be printed.done < verbatim.csv >> section.csv: The loop defined by the while statement processes each line in the verbatim.csv file. The output of the sed command (the extracted section) is then appended to the file section.csv.In summary, this script processes data from a CSV file containing version-related information and uses that information to extract specific sections from a text file. The extracted sections are then appended to another file named section.csv. The exact functionality of the script depends on the details of the find_section function and the structure of the CSV and text files involved.

Conversation.Prompt: what does this do? paste -d ',' verbatim.csv section.csv > best_verbatim.csv
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThis command uses the paste utility to combine data from two CSV files (verbatim.csv and section.csv) side by side using a comma , as the delimiter, and then redirects the combined output to a new CSV file named best_verbatim.csv.Here's a breakdown of what each part of the command does:paste: This is a command-line utility that is used to merge lines from multiple files. By default, it concatenates lines from each file separated by a TAB character.-d ',': This option specifies the delimiter to be used when merging the lines. In this case, a comma , is used as the delimiter.verbatim.csv section.csv: These are the input files for the paste command. The contents of these two files will be merged together side by side using the specified delimiter.>: This symbol is used for output redirection. It takes the output of the preceding command and writes it to a file instead of displaying it in the terminal.best_verbatim.csv: This is the name of the file where the combined output of the paste command will be written.So, when you run this command, it will combine the data from verbatim.csv and section.csv side by side using a comma as the delimiter and save the result in a new CSV file named best_verbatim.csv. The resulting best_verbatim.csv file will have content that's formed by combining the corresponding lines from verbatim.csv and section.csv with commas in between.

Conversation.Prompt: i have a comma-separated string in bash, how can i split it by commas and loop over each element
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIf you have a comma-separated string in Bash and you want to split it into individual elements and loop over each element, you can use the IFS (Internal Field Separator) variable along with the read command. Here's how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this script:comma_separated_string holds your comma-separated string.OLD_IFS is used to store the current value of IFS so that it can be restored later.IFS=',' sets the IFS to a comma, which will cause the read command to split the string based on commas.read -ra elements <<< "$comma_separated_string" reads the elements separated by commas into an array named elements.for element in "${elements[@]}"; do starts a loop that iterates through each element in the array.Inside the loop, you can access each element using the $element variable. Replace echo "Element: $element" with your actual processing code.After the loop, the IFS value is restored to its original value using IFS=$OLD_IFS.This way, you can split the comma-separated string and process each individual element within the loop.

ListOfCode.Content:
#!/bin/bash

# Your comma-separated string
comma_separated_string="element1,element2,element3,element4"

# Save the current IFS value
OLD_IFS=$IFS

# Set IFS to comma (,) to split the string
IFS=','

# Read the elements into an array
read -ra elements <<< "$comma_separated_string"

# Restore the original IFS value
IFS=$OLD_IFS

# Loop over the elements
for element in "${elements[@]}"; do
    echo "Element: $element"
    # Add your processing code here
done

Conversation.Prompt: i'm already in a loop that needs IFS=":", so i don't think this will work...
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTI understand your situation. If you're already in a loop that requires a different value for IFS and you can't change it, you can achieve the desired result by temporarily storing the original IFS value before your inner loop and then restoring it afterward. Here's an example:Let's assume you're in an outer loop that uses IFS=":" and within that loop, you have a comma-separated string that you want to split and process.[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the outer loop uses IFS=":", and within the outer loop, you can temporarily change the IFS value to , for processing the comma-separated string. The original IFS value is restored afterward to ensure that it doesn't affect the outer loop. This way, you can work within the constraints of your existing loop structure.

ListOfCode.Content:
#!/bin/bash

# Your outer loop with IFS=":"
outer_items="item1:item2:item3:item4"
IFS=":"  # Set IFS for the outer loop

# Outer loop
for outer_item in $outer_items; do
    echo "Outer Item: $outer_item"

    # Your comma-separated string
    comma_separated_string="element1,element2,element3,element4"

    # Save the current IFS value
    OLD_IFS=$IFS

    # Set IFS to comma (,) to split the string
    IFS=','

    # Read the elements into an array
    read -ra elements <<< "$comma_separated_string"

    # Restore the original IFS value
    IFS=$OLD_IFS

    # Inner loop to process elements
    for element in "${elements[@]}"; do
        echo "Inner Element: $element"
        # Add your processing code here
    done

    # Continue with the outer loop
done

Conversation.Prompt: how can i delete the tmux history of a single pane
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTAs of my last knowledge update in September 2021, tmux does not have a built-in feature to delete the history of a single pane directly. The history in tmux is managed at the pane level and is shared among all panes in a window. If you clear the history for a specific pane, it would clear it for all panes in that window.However, you can achieve similar functionality by creating a new pane and switching to it, effectively leaving the old pane's history behind. Here's how you can do it:In the pane for which you want to "delete" history, create a new pane either to the left or right of the existing pane. You can use the following key bindings in tmux to split the pane horizontally or vertically:Split horizontally: Press Ctrl-b %Split vertically: Press Ctrl-b "After splitting, you can switch to the new pane by using the appropriate arrow keys or by pressing Ctrl-b arrow_key, where arrow_key is the arrow key in the direction of the new pane.Once you're in the new pane, you can close the old pane by issuing the command exit. This will effectively remove the old pane and its history from the window.Keep in mind that while this method doesn't truly "delete" the history of the old pane, it achieves a similar effect by creating a new pane without history. The old pane is then closed, effectively leaving its history behind.Remember that the behavior of tmux might have changed after my last update in September 2021. Make sure to check the latest tmux documentation or resources to see if there have been any updates or new features related to this.

Conversation.Prompt: on github, how can i block merging a pr if tests fail?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTOn GitHub, you can set up branch protection rules to prevent merging a pull request (PR) if tests fail. This is done by configuring required status checks for your repository. Status checks are automated tests or checks that need to pass before a pull request can be merged. Here's how you can do it:Create and Configure Required Status Checks:Navigate to your repository on GitHub.Click on "Settings" (usually located on the right side).In the left sidebar, click on "Branches."Under "Branch protection rules," click on "Add rule."Choose the branch you want to protect (usually it's the main or master branch).Check the box next to "Require status checks to pass before merging."You'll see a list of status checks available for your repository. These could be related to continuous integration tools like Travis CI, CircleCI, GitHub Actions, etc. These checks need to be set up beforehand in your repository's CI/CD configuration.Set Up CI/CD and Status Checks:Before you can enforce status checks, you need to have a continuous integration (CI) or continuous deployment (CD) process set up in your repository. This usually involves configuring a CI/CD tool to run tests and other checks whenever changes are pushed to the repository.For example, if you're using GitHub Actions, you would need to create a workflow configuration file (e.g., .github/workflows/main.yml) in your repository. This file defines the steps to run when a pull request is opened or when code is pushed to the repository. Within this workflow, you can define jobs that run tests, linters, and other checks.Here's a simple example using GitHub Actions:[CODE_BLOCK_0]You can replace the comment with actual commands to run your tests. Once you have your CI/CD set up, status checks will automatically appear in the "Require status checks to pass before merging" section of the branch protection settings.Save the Branch Protection Rule:After you've selected the required status checks, click "Create" or "Save changes" to create the branch protection rule.Now, whenever a pull request is opened, the configured status checks will automatically run. If any of these checks fail, GitHub will prevent the pull request from being merged until the checks pass. This helps maintain the quality and stability of your codebase by ensuring that changes are thoroughly tested before being merged.Keep in mind that the exact steps might vary depending on the CI/CD tool you're using and any updates made to GitHub's interface after my knowledge cutoff date in September 2021.

    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Run tests
        run: |
          # Add commands to run your tests here

Author: AdamGoyer
Title: add readme for openbabel to PLEX
Body:
The Chatgpt Thread used to create this pull request:
https://chat.openai.com/share/8bd33825-e8c6-447f-b86e-5827453f3448

Conversation.Prompt:
Good evening Chatgpt,
I'd like your help to write a readme for using the bioinformatics openbabel on the PLEX Platform by LabDAO.
First I'll upload openbabel readme, then PLEX's readme, then we can review the openbabel repo on PLEX, and finally we'll write the readme for the plex openbabel director. Does that sound like a good plan to you?

The openbable readme is located here - https://github.com/openbabel/openbabel/blob/master/README.md - 
I'll load the contents to get us started, but please let me know if you have any questions along the way.

Open Babel
----------

[![GitHub release](https://img.shields.io/github/release/openbabel/openbabel.svg?maxAge=86400)](https://github.com/openbabel/openbabel/releases)
[![Download Open Babel](https://img.shields.io/sourceforge/dt/openbabel.svg?maxAge=86400)](https://github.com/openbabel/openbabel/releases)
[![Travis CI](https://img.shields.io/travis/openbabel/openbabel.svg)](https://travis-ci.org/openbabel/openbabel)
[![Google Scholar Citations](https://openbabel.org/citations.svg?maxAge=86400)](https://scholar.google.com/scholar?oi=bibs&hl=en&cites=13319995025871922899&as_sdt=5)

Open Babel is a chemical toolbox designed to speak the many languages
of chemical data. It's an open, collaborative project allowing anyone
to search, convert, analyze, or store data from molecular modeling,
chemistry, solid-state materials, biochemistry, or related areas.

* Ready-to-use programs, and complete programmer's toolkit
* Read, write and convert over 90 chemical file formats
* Filter and search molecular files using SMARTS and other methods
* Generate 2D and 3D coordinates for SMILES, InChI and other formats
* Supports molecular modeling, cheminformatics, bioinformatics,
  organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, solid-state materials,
  nuclear chemistry...

Open Babel is distributed under the GNU General Public License (GPL).
This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
the Free Software Foundation version 2 of the License. Full details
can be found in the file "COPYING" which should be included in your
distribution.

For more information, check the [Open Babel website](http://openbabel.org/).
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThanks for sharing the README file for Open Babel. I can see it's a comprehensive chemical toolbox with various applications in different chemistry-related fields.Now, in order to create a suitable README for Open Babel's usage on the PLEX Platform by LabDAO, could you please share the README or other detailed information about PLEX Platform? It would also be beneficial if you could provide more context about how Open Babel is being utilized in the PLEX platform.Looking forward to your response.

Conversation.Prompt:
Here is the PLEX readme, I think this will answer part of your questions, and I hope the answer will become more clear once we review the code in the plex openbabel repo. # PLEX 🧫×🧬→💊 ⚡ **Build highly reproducible container workflows on top of a decentralised compute network.** ⚡

PLEX is a simple client for distributed computation. * 🌎 **Build once, run anywhere at any scale:** PLEX is using distributed compute and storage to run containers on a public network. Need GPUs? We got you covered. * 🔗 **Strictly composable:** Every tool in PLEX has declared inputs and outputs. Plugging together tools by other authors should be easy. * 🔍 **Content-addressed by default:** Every file processed by PLEX has a deterministic address based on its content. Keep track of your files and always share the right results with other scientists. PLEX is based on [Bacalhau](https://www.bacalhau.org/), [IPFS](https://ipfs.tech/), and inspired by [Pydantic](https://docs.pydantic.dev/) and the [Common Workflow Language](https://www.commonwl.org/user_guide/introduction/quick-start.html). ## 🚀 PLEX in one minute 1 . Install the client Mac/Linux users open terminal and run ``` source <(curl -sSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/labdao/plex/main/install.sh) ``` Windows users open terminal as an adminstrator and run ``` Invoke-Expression (Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/labdao/plex/main/install.ps1" -UseBasicParsing).Content ``` 2. Submit an example PLEX job ``` ./plex create -t tools/equibind.json -i testdata/binding/abl --autoRun=True ``` ![Getting Started](./readme-getting-started-2x.gif) 3. [Read the docs](https://docs.labdao.xyz/) to learn how to use PLEX with your own data and tools 4. Request Access to our VIP Jupyter Hub Enviroment and NFT Testnet Minting. [VIP Beta Access Form](https://try.labdao.xyz) ## 💡 Use-Cases * 🧬 run PLEX to [design proteins](https://docs.labdao.xyz/protein-folding/run-an-example) with colabfold and RFDiffusion * 💊 run PLEX to run [small molecule docking](https://docs.labdao.xyz/small-molecule-binding/run-an-example) with equibind and diffdock * 🐋 configure your containerised tool to run on PLEX ## 🧑‍💻 Developer Guide ### Building PLEX from source ``` git clone https://github.com/labdao/plex cd plex go build ``` ### Running a compute node This is a script for setting up a compute instance to run LabDAO jobs. Requires linux OS with Nvidia GPU. Tested on Ubuntu 20.04 LTS with Nvidia T4, V100, and A10 GPUs (AWS G4, P3, and G5 instance types) The install script sets up Docker, Nvidia Drivers, Nvidia Container Toolkit, and IPFS ``` curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/labdao/plex/main/scripts/provide-compute.sh | bash && newgrp docker ``` After the script run the following command in a separate terminal to start a Bacalhau server to accept jobs. ``` ipfs daemon ``` Once the daemon is running, configure the Bacalhau node based on the addresses used by the IFPS node. ``` ipfs id # copy the ip4 tcp output and change port 4001 to 5001 then export export IPFS_CONNECT=/ip4/127.0.0.1/tcp/5001/p2p/ # example: export IPFS_CONNECT=/ip4/127.0.0.1/tcp/5001/p2p/12D3KooWPH1BpPfNXwkf778GMP2H5z7pwjKVQFnA5NS3DngU7pxG LOG_LEVEL=debug bacalhau serve --job-selection-accept-networked --limit-total-gpu 1 --limit-total-memory 12gb --ipfs-connect $IPFS_CONNECT ``` To download large bacalhau results the below command may need ran ``` sudo sysctl -w net.core.rmem_max=2500000 ``` ## 💁 Contributing PRs are welcome! Please consider our [Contribute Guidelines](https://docs.labdao.xyz/about-us/contributer_policy) when joining. From time to time, we also post ```help-wanted``` bounty issues - please consider our [Bounty Policy](https://docs.labdao.xyz/about-us/bounty_policy) when engaging with LabDAO.

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTBased on the given information, it looks like Open Babel is being used on the PLEX platform primarily to perform structure-based computational chemistry tasks such as file format conversions and calculating Root Mean Square Deviation (RMSD) of molecular structures. Let's put this information together to create a README that helps users understand how to utilize Open Babel on PLEX for these tasks.Open Babel on the PLEX PlatformOpen Babel is a powerful, open-source chemical toolbox designed to "speak" the many languages of chemical data. The Open Babel container on the PLEX platform brings this versatility to distributed computing, making it an invaluable resource for a variety of computational chemistry and bioinformatics tasks.PLEX leverages the Bacalhau network initiated by IPFS to run containers, such as Open Babel, in a distributed computing environment.Key FeaturesStructure Conversions: Convert files between various chemical structure formats (e.g., from PDB to SDF) using Open Babel's extensive format support.Chemical Analysis: Compute structural metrics like RMSD to compare different molecular conformations.How to UseInstallation: Follow the instructions in the PLEX README to install and set up PLEX on your machine.Starting a Job: You can submit a job using Open Babel with the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Replace <json-file> with the specific tool file you want to use (e.g., pdb-to-sdf-openbabel.json or rmsd-openbabel.json), and <your-input-file> with the path to your input file.Retrieving Results: You can retrieve the results of your job from the Bacalhau network once it has completed. Check the PLEX documentation for more information.ExamplesConvert a PDB file to an SDF file:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Calculate the RMSD between two molecular structures:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Community and SupportIf you encounter issues or have questions about using Open Babel on PLEX, don't hesitate to reach out to the LabDAO community.Feel free to modify this draft as needed. The specific command examples may need adjustment based on how exactly users need to specify input files and options in the -t and -i parameters of the ./plex create command.

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThese JSON files are indeed configuration files for running different tasks with Open Babel on the PLEX platform. They define a workflow specification in a format known as the Common Workflow Language (CWL). Here's what each part of these files means:class: Specifies the type of executable being defined. In this case, "CommandLineTool" indicates a command-line executable.name: A human-readable name for the tool.description: A description of what the tool does.baseCommand: The command-line command to execute.arguments: Arguments to provide to the command. This usually involves some operation on the inputs, and producing outputs.dockerPull: Specifies the Docker image to use when executing this tool.gpuBool: Indicates whether the tool needs access to a GPU. In this case, it's set to false.networkBool: Indicates whether the tool needs network access. In this case, it's also set to false.inputs: Defines the inputs to the tool. Each input has a type (e.g., "File"), and a glob pattern (glob) to specify the expected file type(s).outputs: Defines the outputs from the tool. Like inputs, each output has a type and a glob pattern.Now let's see how this applies to the two JSON files:pdb-to-sdf-openbabel.json specifies a tool that uses Open Babel to convert a PDB file to an SDF file. The pdb_file input expects a .pdb file, and the tool produces an sdf_file output which is an .sdf file.rmsd-openbabel.json specifies a tool that uses Open Babel to calculate the RMSD of a reference small molecule and a docked small molecule. The tool expects two .sdf files as inputs (reference_structure and comparison_structure) and produces a .csv file (scores) with the RMSD results.

tools/openbabel/Dockerfile
# Use an official Python base image
FROM python:3.9-slim-buster

# Update the package list and install necessary packages
RUN apt-get update \
    && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends \
        openbabel \
        libopenbabel-dev \
    && apt-get clean \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Set the working directory
WORKDIR /app

# Copy the current directory contents into the container
COPY . .

CMD [ "bash"]
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThis Dockerfile is used to create a Docker image with a suitable environment for running Open Babel. Here's a breakdown of what it does:FROM python:3.9-slim-buster: It starts with an official Python base image. The tag 3.9-slim-buster indicates that this is a slim version of the Python 3.9 image, built on Debian Buster.RUN apt-get update \ && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends \ openbabel \ libopenbabel-dev \ && apt-get clean \ && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*: It then updates the list of available packages and installs necessary packages, specifically Open Babel and its development libraries. After the installation, it cleans up the apt cache and removes lists of packages to keep the image size small.WORKDIR /app: It sets /app as the working directory inside the Docker container. Any subsequent actions (e.g., RUN, CMD, ENTRYPOINT, COPY, ADD) will be taken from this directory inside the Docker container.COPY . .: It copies the current directory (i.e., where the Dockerfile is located) into the Docker container. The . signifies the current directory on the host and in the Docker container, so it copies everything in the host directory into the /app directory inside the Docker container.CMD [ "bash"]: It sets the default command that the container will execute when it runs. In this case, it will start a Bash shell.So, the Docker image created from this Dockerfile will have Python 3.9, Open Babel, and its development libraries installed, and it will start in the /app directory with a Bash shell.Here is how the readme might be updated to incorporate this information:PLEX utilizes Docker to ensure reproducibility and ease of use across different platforms. In the context of Open Babel, a Docker image is prepared with the necessary software environments required to run Open Babel applications.For example, in our Dockerfile:We use a base image that has Python 3.9 installed.We install Open Babel and its development libraries.We set up an /app directory as the working directory inside the Docker container.We copy the content of the current directory into the /app directory in the Docker container.We start the container with a Bash shell by default.This setup ensures that no matter where you run the Docker container, the environment will always be consistent, thus maintaining the reproducibility of your scientific computation tasks. You can check out the Dockerfile here.

Conversation.Prompt: convert strings to arabic
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo convert strings to Arabic, you can use a Unicode character encoding that supports Arabic characters, such as UTF-8. Most programming languages and text editors natively support UTF-8 encoding, so you don't need to perform any specific conversion. Here's an example in Python:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This code takes a string that contains non-Arabic characters ("Hello, 世界!") and converts it to a Unicode string that includes Arabic characters. The encode('utf-8') method encodes the string as UTF-8, and decode('utf-8') decodes it back into a Unicode string. The resulting arabic_string will contain the original string with Arabic characters.Note that if your input string already contains Arabic characters, you don't need to perform any conversion. Arabic characters are generally represented as their Unicode code points in most programming languages and text encodings.

ListOfCode.Content:
string = "Hello, 世界!"
arabic_string = string.encode('utf-8').decode('utf-8')

print(arabic_string)

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIf you've accidentally committed a .DS_Store file (or any other unwanted file) to your Git repository, you can remove it with the following steps:Remove the file from the repository:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Commit the change:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Push the change to the remote repository (if you're using one):[CODE_BLOCK_2]Prevent .DS_Store from being committed in the future by adding it to your .gitignore file. If you don't have a .gitignore file, you can create one in the root of your repository. Add the following line to it:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Commit the .gitignore file (if you've just created or modified it):[CODE_BLOCK_4]If you want to remove all .DS_Store files from your entire project (not just the root directory), you can use the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_5]Then commit and push the changes as described in steps 2 and 3.Remember, if you've shared this repository with others, and they've pulled the changes with the .DS_Store file, they'll also need to pull the changes where you've removed it. Otherwise, they might accidentally re-add it in future commits.

git push origin <your-branch-name>
.DS_Store

git push origin <your-branch-name>
find . -name .DS_Store -print0 | xargs -0 git rm --ignore-unmatch

Author: somzoli
Title: Update Win_Chocolatey_Manage_Apps_Bulk.ps1
Body: Added foreach to upgrade option for use multiple software upgrade

Conversation.Prompt:
Is this right?
<#
      .SYNOPSIS
      This will install software using the chocolatey, with rate limiting when run with Hosts parameter
      .DESCRIPTION
      For installing packages using chocolatey. If you're running against more than 10, include the Hosts parameter to limit the speed. If running on more than 30 agents at a time make sure you also change the script timeout setting.
      .PARAMETER Mode
      3 options: install (default), uninstall, or upgrade.
      .PARAMETER Hosts
      Use this to specify the number of computer(s) you're running the command on. This will dynamically introduce waits to try and minimize the chance of hitting rate limits (20/min) on the chocolatey.org site: Hosts 20
      .PARAMETER PackageName
      Use this to specify which software('s) to install eg: PackageName googlechrome. You can use multiple value with semicolon separated. 
      .EXAMPLE
      -Hosts 20 -PackageName googlechrome
      -Hosts 30 -PackageName googlechrome,vlc
      .EXAMPLE
      -Mode upgrade -Hosts 50
      .EXAMPLE
      -Mode upgrade -Hosts 50 -PackageName chocolatey
      .EXAMPLE
      -Mode uninstall -PackageName googlechrome
      .NOTES
      9/2021 v1 Initial release by @silversword411 and @bradhawkins 
      11/14/2021 v1.1 Fixing typos and logic flow
  #>

param (
    [Int] $Hosts = "0",
    [string[]] $PackageName,
    [string] $Mode = "install"
)

$ErrorCount = 0

if ($Mode -ne "upgrade" -and !$PackageName) {
    write-output "No choco package name provided, please include Example: `"-PackageName googlechrome`" `n"
    Exit 1
}

if ($Hosts -ne "0") {
    $randrange = ($Hosts + 1) * 6
    # Write-Output "Calculating rnd"
    # Write-Output "randrange $randrange"
    $rnd = Get-Random -Minimum 1 -Maximum $randrange; 
    # Write-Output "rnd=$rnd"
}
else {
    $rnd = "1"
    # Write-Output "rnd set to 1 manually"
    # Write-Output "rnd=$rnd"
}

if ($Mode -eq "upgrade") {
    # Write-Output "Starting Upgrade"
    Start-Sleep -Seconds $rnd; 
    if (!$PackageName) {
        choco upgrade -y all
    }
    else {
        foreach ($package in $PackageName)
        {
            choco upgrade $package -y
        }
    }
    # Write-Output "Running upgrade"
    Exit 0
}

# write-output "Running install/uninstall mode"
Start-Sleep -Seconds $rnd; 
choco $Mode $PackageName -y
Exit 0
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe script you've provided is a PowerShell script that uses Chocolatey, a package manager for Windows, to install, uninstall, or upgrade software packages. The script also includes logic to introduce a delay when running against multiple hosts to avoid hitting rate limits on the Chocolatey website.Here's a brief review of the script:Synopsis, Description, Parameters, Examples, and Notes: These sections provide documentation for the script, explaining its purpose, how to use it, and its history.Parameters:Hosts: The number of computers you're running the command on.PackageName: The software package(s) you want to install, uninstall, or upgrade.Mode: The operation mode (install, uninstall, or upgrade).Logic:If the mode is not "upgrade" and no package name is provided, the script exits with an error message.If the Hosts parameter is provided, a random delay is calculated based on the number of hosts. This is to avoid hitting rate limits.Depending on the Mode, the script will either upgrade, install, or uninstall the specified package(s).Potential Improvements and Observations:The script assumes that if the mode is "upgrade" and no package name is provided, all packages should be upgraded (choco upgrade -y all). This is a potentially dangerous operation, so you might want to include a warning or confirmation prompt.The script uses Start-Sleep to introduce a delay based on the number of hosts. This is a simple way to avoid rate limits, but it might not be the most efficient approach, especially if you're running the script on a large number of hosts.The script uses Exit 0 to indicate successful completion and Exit 1 to indicate an error. This is a common convention in scripting, but you might want to include more detailed error handling and logging, especially if you're using this script in a production environment.The script includes some commented-out Write-Output lines. These are likely for debugging purposes. You might want to remove them or replace them with proper logging.Overall, the script looks functional for its intended purpose. However, as with any script, especially one that makes changes to software installations, it's essential to test it thoroughly in a safe environment before using it in production.

// GoogleCredentialPluginKubeconfigTemplate requires the following inputs for rendering a kubeconfig that works
// 1. cluster endpoint ip
// 2. cluster cert-authority data
// 3. base64 encoded google service account key
const GoogleCredentialPluginKubeconfigTemplate = `
apiVersion: v1
kind: Config
current-context: kube-context
contexts: [{name: kube-context, context: {cluster: kube-cluster, user: kube-user}}]
clusters:

    server: https://%s
    certificate-authority-data: %s
users:

`

import os

from PIL import Image
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify

from email.mime.text import MIMEText
import os
from email.mime.base import MIMEBase
from email import encoders
import requests

#--------Code block for "QR generation" to be Generated,modified and updated by @GowriParvathyy--------

def generate_qr_code(data, filename):
    qr = qrcode.QRCode(
        version=1,
        error_correction=qrcode.constants.ERROR_CORRECT_L,
        box_size=10,
        border=2,
    )
    qr.add_data(data)
    qr.make(fit=True)
    qr_img = qr.make_image(fill_color="black", back_color="white")
    qr_img.save(filename)

#--------Code block for "Ticket generation" to be Generated,modified and updated by @niranjana_2004--------

def tgen():
    qr_images_folder = "QRImages"
    ticket_output_folder = "Ticket"
    ticket_design_path = "custom_ticket.png"

    if not os.path.exists(ticket_output_folder):
        os.makedirs(ticket_output_folder)

    ticket_design = Image.open(ticket_design_path)

    # Ticket size
    ticket_width = ticket_design.width
    ticket_height = ticket_design.height

    # Calculate the size of the QR code based on the specified height
    qr_size = (ticket_height // 2)-2

    # Get a list of all QR code image files in the QRImages folder
    qr_code_files = sorted(file for file in os.listdir(qr_images_folder) if file.endswith(".png"))

    with tqdm(total=len(qr_code_files), desc="Generating Tickets") as pbar:
        # Loop through each QR code image
        for qr_file in qr_code_files:
            # Construct the path to the QR code image
            qr_code_path = os.path.join(qr_images_folder, qr_file)

            # Load and resize the QR code
            qr_code = Image.open(qr_code_path)
            qr_code = qr_code.resize((qr_size, qr_size))

            # Calculate the position to place the QR code at the bottom right
            x = ticket_width - qr_size-80
            y = ticket_height - qr_size-160

            # Create a copy of the ticket design to avoid modifying the original
            ticket_with_qr = ticket_design.copy()

            # Paste the QR code onto the ticket copy
            ticket_with_qr.paste(qr_code, (x, y))

            # Construct the output path for the generated ticket
            ticket_name = os.path.splitext(qr_file)[0] + "_ticket.png"
            output_path = os.path.join(ticket_output_folder, ticket_name)

            # Save the generated ticket image with QR code
            ticket_with_qr.save(output_path)
            pbar.update(1)

    print("Tickets generated and saved in the 'Ticket' folder.")
    send_mail()

#--------Code block for "Mailing Service" to be Generated,modified and updated by @Devaah07--------
def send_mail():
    try:
        auto_mailer = "src\Mail_service.py"
        auto_mail_process = subprocess.Popen(['python', auto_mailer])
    except:
        print("Unable to start Mail Service!!")
    url = 'http://localhost:5000/send_email'

    data = {
        "subject": "Test Email",
        "to_email": "youaedrin@gmail.com",
        "message": "This is a test email sent from the API.",
        "attachment_path": "F:\TicketWave\TicketWave\Ticket\qr_1_ticket.png"
    }

    response = requests.post(url, json=data)

    if response.status_code == 200:
        auto_mail_process.terminate()
        print("Email sent successfully")
    else:
        auto_mail_process.terminate()
        print("Failed to send email")
        print("Response:", response.text)

#Main function to be updated by @GowriParvathyy, @Niranjana_2004 and @Devaah07

def main():
    # Path to the folder where you want to save the generated QR
    qr_output_folder = "QRImages"

    if not os.path.exists(qr_output_folder):
        os.makedirs(qr_output_folder)

    # Find all CSV files in the current directory
    csv_files = glob.glob("*.csv")

    if len(csv_files) == 0:
        print("No CSV files found in the current directory.")
        exit()

    # Assuming there is only one CSV file, you can take the first one
    csv_file_path = csv_files[0]

    qr_data_list = []

    with open(csv_file_path, "r") as csv_file:
        csv_reader = csv.reader(csv_file)
        next(csv_reader)  # Skip header row
        for row in csv_reader:
            qr_data_list.append(row[0])  # Assuming QR data is in the first column

    with tqdm(total=len(qr_data_list), desc="Generating QR Codes") as pbar:
        for qr_data in qr_data_list:
            qr_code_filename = os.path.join(qr_output_folder, f"qr_{pbar.n + 1}.png")
            generate_qr_code(qr_data, qr_code_filename)
            pbar.update(1)

    print("QR code generation completed.")
    tgen()

if __name__ == "__main__":

Author: asl3
Title: LRU Vector Store Policy
Body:
Implement an LRU vector store policy which evicts disk-stored vector files once the vector store directory exceeds a set maximum size

### Tests
Added tests to `tests/test_ai_tools.py`

Conversation.Prompt:
help me write a python class. It takes a file_path and max_size for init.
there is APIs to read or create new files under the file_path. When the total size exceeds max_size, evict the least recent accessed file (LRU policy).
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTCertainly! Below is a Python class that fulfills the described requirements:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Here's how the class works:It uses an OrderedDict to keep track of the files and their sizes. When a file is accessed (read or created), it is moved to the end of the OrderedDict. The least recently accessed file is always at the beginning.When the total size exceeds max_size, the _evict_files method is called, which keeps evicting the least recently accessed files until the current size is within limits.The read_file method lets you read a file's content. After reading, the file is considered accessed and is moved to the end of the OrderedDict.The create_file method lets you create (or overwrite) a file with the specified content. After creation, the file is considered accessed.The delete_file method lets you delete a file from the directory and cache.Note: Ensure to handle possible exceptions when interacting with file operations in a real-world use case. This example is kept simple for clarity.

ListOfCode.Content:
import os
from collections import OrderedDict

class LRUFileCache:
    def __init__(self, file_path: str, max_size: int):
        self.file_path = file_path
        self.max_size = max_size
        self.current_size = 0
        self.files = OrderedDict()  # {filename: size}

        # initialize the file cache
        for file in os.listdir(file_path):
            file_full_path = os.path.join(file_path, file)
            file_size = os.path.getsize(file_full_path)
            self.current_size += file_size
            self.files[file] = file_size

    def _evict_files(self):
        while self.current_size > self.max_size:
            _, evicted_size = self.files.popitem(last=False)  # pop the least recently accessed item
            self.current_size -= evicted_size

    def read_file(self, filename: str) -> str:
        file_full_path = os.path.join(self.file_path, filename)
        if not os.path.exists(file_full_path):
            raise ValueError(f"{filename} doesn't exist!")

        with open(file_full_path, 'r') as f:
            content = f.read()

        # Move accessed file to the end to maintain LRU order
        file_size = self.files.pop(filename)
        self.files[filename] = file_size

        return content

    def create_file(self, filename: str, content: str):
        file_full_path = os.path.join(self.file_path, filename)
        with open(file_full_path, 'w') as f:
            f.write(content)

        file_size = os.path.getsize(file_full_path)
        self.current_size += file_size
        self.files[filename] = file_size

        self._evict_files()

    def delete_file(self, filename: str):
        if filename in self.files:
            file_full_path = os.path.join(self.file_path, filename)
            os.remove(file_full_path)
            size = self.files.pop(filename)
            self.current_size -= size

# Usage
file_cache = LRUFileCache("path/to/files", 5000)  # max_size in bytes, for example: 5 KB
file_cache.create_file("sample.txt", "Hello World")
content = file_cache.read_file("sample.txt")

import unittest
from freezegun import freeze_time

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPT안녕하세요! 네, Axios를 사용하여 비동기 통신을 할 때 TypeScript에서 성공 및 실패 응답 타입을 처리하는 방법에 대해 설명해 드리겠습니다.일반적으로 Axios를 사용하여 API 요청을 보낼 때, HTTP 응답 상태에 따라 다른 처리를 해야 할 수 있습니다. 이를 TypeScript에서 잘 다루려면 다음과 같이 할 수 있습니다.먼저, 각각의 응답 타입을 정의합니다.[CODE_BLOCK_0]Axios 요청을 보낼 때, .then()과 .catch()를 사용하여 성공 및 실패 시의 응답을 처리합니다.[CODE_BLOCK_1]위 코드에서 <SuccessResponse> 및 <FailedResponse>는 각각 Axios의 제네릭 타입으로 사용되며, 이를 통해 해당 응답 타입을 지정합니다.이러한 방식은 성공 및 실패 응답을 각각의 타입으로 구분하여 처리하는 좋은 방법 중 하나입니다. 이렇게 하면 코드 가독성이 향상되며, TypeScript가 컴파일 시에 타입 검사를 수행하여 타입 관련 오류를 찾아낼 수 있습니다.따라서 별도의 라이브러리나 패턴보다는 이런 방식을 사용하는 것이 TypeScript에서 Axios를 활용하는 일반적인 패턴 중 하나입니다.

#!/bin/sh
set -e
goal="Fix npm ERR! notarget for docsify-cli@^4.4.7"
echo "Plan:"

Conversation.Prompt:
why is this happening:

>>> a = "GH_GGGGGGGGGGGGGGGA"
>>> b = a.lstrip("GH_")
>>> b
'A'
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe behavior you're observing is because the lstrip method in Python does not work the way you might expect in this context.When you call a.lstrip("GH_"), it does not remove the substring "GH_" from the beginning of the string a. Instead, it removes any characters that are in the set "GH_" from the left side (beginning) of the string until it encounters a character that is not in that set.In your case, the string "GH_" contains the characters 'G' and 'H', and it's treating both 'G' and 'H' as characters to be removed from the left side of the string. So, it starts removing 'G' characters from the left until it encounters 'A', which is not in the "GH_" set. Therefore, it stops at 'A', and that's why you get 'A' as the result.If you want to specifically remove the substring "GH_" from the beginning of the string, you can use slicing like this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This will correctly remove "GH_" from the beginning of the string, and you will get the desired result:[CODE_BLOCK_1]

ListOfCode.Content:
a = "GH_GGGGGGGGGGGGGGGA"
b = a.replace("GH_", "", 1)
print(b)
GGGGGGGGGGGGGGA

Hello! Below I will share a template for a markdown file. Can you please write a CLI script that takes a string as an argument and creates a new folder with this template in it, please?

---
title: 
date: 
description:
---

## In Summary (tl;dr)

---
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTHello! Sure, I can help you create a CLI script to achieve that. Below is a Python script that takes a string as an argument and creates a new folder with the provided template in it. Save the following code in a file named create_markdown.py:[CODE_BLOCK_0]To use this script, open a terminal or command prompt, navigate to the directory where you saved create_markdown.py, and run the script with the desired title as an argument. For example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]

ListOfCode.Content:
import os
import sys

def create_markdown_folder(title):
    template = f"""---
title: {title}
date: 
description:
---

## In Summary (tl;dr)

---"""

    folder_name = title.lower().replace(" ", "_")

    try:
        os.mkdir(folder_name)
    except FileExistsError:
        print(f"Folder '{folder_name}' already exists. Please provide a unique title.")
        return

    file_path = os.path.join(folder_name, f"{folder_name}.md")

    with open(file_path, "w") as file:
        file.write(template)

    print(f"Markdown file created: {file_path}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    if len(sys.argv) != 2:
        print("Usage: python create_markdown.py [TITLE]")
    else:
        title = sys.argv[1]
        create_markdown_folder(title)
python create_markdown.py "My New Markdown File"

Conversation.Prompt: Can we do this as a pure bash script?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, we can create a pure Bash script to achieve the same functionality. Below is the Bash script that takes a string as an argument and creates a new folder with the provided template in it. Save the following code in a file named create_markdown.sh:[CODE_BLOCK_0]To use this Bash script, open a terminal or command prompt, navigate to the directory where you saved create_markdown.sh, and make the script executable using the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Then, you can run the script with the desired title as an argument. For example:[CODE_BLOCK_2]The script will create a new folder with the title in lowercase and underscores as spaces and generate a markdown file inside the folder with the provided template.

#!/bin/bash

if [ $# -ne 1 ]; then
  echo "Usage: $0 [TITLE]"
  exit 1
fi

title="$1"
template="---
title: $title
date: 
description:
---

## In Summary (tl;dr)

---"
