def __getitem__(self, val):
    def normalize_int(e, i, dim_sz):
      if -dim_sz <= e < dim_sz: return e if e != -1 else dim_sz-1
      raise IndexError(f"index {e} is out of bounds for dimension {i} with size {self.shape[i]}")
    orig_slices = list(val) if isinstance(val, tuple) else [val]
    if (num_slices := sum(isinstance(v, (slice, int, Tensor)) for v in orig_slices)) > len(self.shape):
      raise IndexError(f"too many indices for tensor of dimension {len(self.shape)}")
    ellipses_found = [i for i, v in enumerate(orig_slices) if v is Ellipsis]
    if len(ellipses_found) > 1: raise IndexError("an index can only have a single ellipsis ('...')")
    ellipsis_idx = ellipses_found[0] if ellipses_found else len(orig_slices)
    orig_slices[ellipsis_idx:ellipsis_idx+1] = [slice(None)] * (len(self.shape) - num_slices)

    tensor_found = [(i,v) for i, v in enumerate(orig_slices) if isinstance(v, Tensor)]
    orig_slices = [slice(None) if isinstance(v, Tensor) else v for v in orig_slices]
    valid_slices = [s for s in orig_slices if s is not None]
    valid_slices = [v if isinstance(v, slice) else slice(y := normalize_int(v, i, dim_sz), y+1) for i, (v, dim_sz) in enumerate(zip(valid_slices, self.shape))]
    start, stop, strides = zip(*y) if (y := [s.indices(dim_sz) for s, dim_sz in zip(valid_slices, self.shape)]) else ((), (), ())
    new_slice = tuple((s, e) if st > 0 else (e+1, s+1) for s, e, st in zip(start, stop, strides))
    # Shrink
    sliced_tensor = self.shrink(new_slice)
    new_shape = sliced_tensor.shape
    # Flip
    if (flip_axes := tuple(i for i, s in enumerate(strides) if s < 0)):
      sliced_tensor = sliced_tensor.flip(axis=flip_axes)
    if any(s > 1 or s < 0 for s in strides):
      # normalize if negative strides
      strides = tuple(abs(s) for s in strides)
      def num_zeros(step, dim_sz): return 0 if step == 1 or (y := dim_sz % step) == 0 else (step - y)
      # Pad: add pad at the end: [dim_sz] -> [dim_sz_padded]
      paddings = tuple((0, num_zeros(s, dim_sz)) for s, dim_sz in zip(strides, sliced_tensor.shape))
      padded_tensor = sliced_tensor.pad(paddings)
      # Reshape: [dim_sz_padded] -> [dim_sz_padded // s, s]
      new_shape = flatten([sh // s, s] for sh, s in zip(padded_tensor.shape, strides))
      reshaped_tensor = padded_tensor.reshape(new_shape)
      # Shrink: do [:, 0]
      new_shape = new_shape[::2]
      final_slice = tuple(flatten(((0, sh), (0, 1)) for sh in new_shape))
      sliced_tensor = reshaped_tensor.shrink(final_slice)
    final_shape, it_shape = [], iter(new_shape)
    sub = [0] * len(tensor_found)
    for i,s in enumerate(orig_slices):
      if isinstance(s, (int, slice)):
        dim_shape = next(it_shape)
        if isinstance(s, slice): final_shape.append(dim_shape)
        elif tensor_found:
          for i_ in range(len(tensor_found)):
            if tensor_found[i_][0] > i: sub[i_] -= 1
      else: # s is None
        final_shape.append(1)
    ret = sliced_tensor.reshape(tuple(final_shape))  # Reshape
    if tensor_found: # Fancy/tensor indexing
      for i,s in enumerate(sub): tensor_found[i] = (tensor_found[i][0]+s, tensor_found[i][1])
      dim = [i[0] for i in tensor_found]
      idx = [i[1].sign().contiguous().__neg__().contiguous().relu() * ret.shape[i[0]] + i[1] for i in tensor_found] # TODO first contiguous fixes torch+cpu_only CI, but it causes llvm to fail. Second one fixes llvm
      max_dim = max(i.ndim for i in idx)
      idx = [i.reshape(*[1]*(max_dim-i.ndim), *i.shape) for i in idx]
      sum_dim = [d+max_dim-n for n,d in enumerate(dim)]
      new_idx = idx[0].reshape(*[1]*dim[0], 1,*idx[0].shape, *[1]*(ret.ndim-dim[0]-1))
      arange = Tensor.arange(ret.shape[dim[0]], dtype=dtypes.int32, requires_grad=False, device=self.device).reshape(*[1]*dim[0], ret.shape[dim[0]], *[1]*idx[0].ndim, *[1]*(ret.ndim-dim[0]-1))
      ret = (ret.reshape(*ret.shape[:dim[0]+1], *[1]*idx[0].ndim, *ret.shape[dim[0]+1:]) * (arange == new_idx)).sum(dim[0])
      for idx_,d in zip(idx[1:],sum_dim[1:]):
        new_idx = idx_.reshape(*[1]*dim[0], *idx_.shape, *[1]*(ret.ndim-dim[0]-idx_.ndim))
        arange = Tensor.arange(ret.shape[d], dtype=dtypes.int32, requires_grad=False, device=self.device).reshape(*[1]*(d), ret.shape[d], *[1]*(ret.ndim-d-1))
        ret = ((new_idx == arange) * ret).sum(d)
      if dim[0] != 0 and dim != list(range(dim[0], dim[-1]+1)) and len(dim) != 1: # special permute case
        order = list(range(ret.ndim))
        order = order[dim[0]:dim[0]+idx[0].ndim] + order[:dim[0]] + order[dim[0]+idx[0].ndim:]
        ret = ret.permute(order=order)
    return ret

  # - Negative indices are taken relative to the end of the sequence, so X[-2] returns the 2nd-to-last element

def __getitem__(self, val):
    normalize_int = lambda e, i, dim_sz: e if -dim_sz <= e < dim_sz else dim_sz-1 if e == -1 else IndexError(f"index {e} is out of bounds for dimension {i} with size {self.shape[i]}")
    
    orig_slices = list(val) if isinstance(val, tuple) else [val]
    num_slices = sum(isinstance(v, (slice, int, Tensor)) for v in orig_slices)
    
    if num_slices > len(self.shape): raise IndexError(f"too many indices for tensor of dimension {len(self.shape)}")
    if orig_slices.count(Ellipsis) > 1: raise IndexError("an index can only have a single ellipsis ('...')")
    
    ellipsis_idx = orig_slices.index(Ellipsis) if Ellipsis in orig_slices else len(orig_slices)
    orig_slices[ellipsis_idx:ellipsis_idx+1] = [slice(None)] * (len(self.shape) - num_slices)
    
    tensor_found = [(i,v) for i, v in enumerate(orig_slices) if isinstance(v, Tensor)]
    orig_slices = [slice(None) if isinstance(v, Tensor) else v for v in orig_slices]
    valid_slices = [v if isinstance(v, slice) else slice(y := normalize_int(v, i, dim_sz), y+1) for i, (v, dim_sz) in enumerate(zip(orig_slices, self.shape))]
    
    start, stop, strides = zip(*[s.indices(dim_sz) for s, dim_sz in zip(valid_slices, self.shape)]) or ((), (), ())
    new_slice = tuple((s, e) if st > 0 else (e+1, s+1) for s, e, st in zip(start, stop, strides))
    
    sliced_tensor = self.shrink(new_slice).flip(axis=[i for i, s in enumerate(strides) if s < 0])
    
    if any(abs(s) != 1 for s in strides):
        paddings = [(0, -dim_sz % s if dim_sz % s != 0 else 0) for s, dim_sz in zip(strides, sliced_tensor.shape)]
        padded_tensor = sliced_tensor.pad(paddings)
        reshaped_tensor = padded_tensor.reshape(flatten([sh // s, s] for sh, s in zip(padded_tensor.shape, strides)))
        sliced_tensor = reshaped_tensor.shrink(tuple(flatten(((0, sh), (0, 1)) for sh in reshaped_tensor.shape[::2])))
    
    final_shape, it_shape = [], iter(sliced_tensor.shape)
    for i, s in enumerate(orig_slices):
        if isinstance(s, (int, slice)): 
            dim_shape = next(it_shape)
            if isinstance(s, int) and tensor_found: [tensor_found[i] for i in range(len(tensor_found)) if tensor_found[i][0] > i][0][0] -= 1
        elif s is None: final_shape.append(1)
    
    ret = sliced_tensor.reshape(final_shape)
    
    # Further fancy/tensor indexing handling here (omitted for brevity, as the logic remains largely the same).
    
    return ret

Author: Shinigami92
Title: ci: check mergable by label
Body:
This ci blocks PRs by the labels on hold and do not merge yet, so it cannot accidentally be merged by not reading the labels

Code is slightly copied from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71502652/prevent-merging-of-branch-conditionally-based-on-label

Conversation.Prompt: Write a GitHub Action yml file that blocks the PR from merging when there is a label named "do NOT merge yet" or "s: on hold"
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo create a GitHub Actions workflow that blocks a pull request from merging when it has a label named "do NOT merge yet" or "s: on hold," you can use the following YAML configuration:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This workflow is triggered whenever a pull request is labeled or unlabeled. It checks if the labels include any of the specified blocking labels. If any of the blocking labels are found, the workflow will exit with a non-zero status code, preventing the PR from being merged. If no blocking labels are found, the workflow allows the PR to be merged.Make sure to save this YAML file in the .github/workflows directory in your repository. When you create a pull request with the "do NOT merge yet" or "s: on hold" label, the workflow will block the PR from being merged.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Block Merge on Label

on:
  pull_request:
    types:
      - labeled
      - unlabeled

jobs:
  block_merge:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
    - name: Check for blocking labels
      id: check_labels
      run: |
        BLOCKING_LABELS=("do NOT merge yet" "s: on hold")
        PR_LABELS=$(jq -r '.pull_request.labels[].name' "$GITHUB_EVENT_PATH")
        
        for LABEL in "${BLOCKING_LABELS[@]}"; do
          if [[ "$PR_LABELS" == *"$LABEL"* ]]; then
            echo "This PR has a blocking label: $LABEL"
            exit 1
          fi
        done
        
        echo "No blocking labels found"
      env:
        GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

    - name: Unblock Merge
      if: ${{ steps.check_labels.outcome == 'success' }}
      run: |
        echo "The PR does not have any blocking labels. Merging is allowed."

Conversation.Prompt: im using angular, how can i detect if im on a wildcard route in a parent component of the router? Can i for example use ActivatedRoute if im in a parent layout component?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn Angular, you can detect if you're on a wildcard route in a parent layout component by using the ActivatedRoute service. The ActivatedRoute service provides various observables and snapshot properties that help you get route information. However, it is generally associated with the component that is directly linked with the route.For a parent layout component that may not be directly linked to a specific route, you could use Angular's Router service to detect the active route. Here's a simplified example using Angular's Router service:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, we listen to the router's events observable and filter it for instances of NavigationEnd, which signals that a route change has completed.We then traverse the ActivatedRoute tree to get to the most deeply nested active route, which is where wildcard routes would be defined. We check the routeConfig.path of this route's snapshot against '**', which is the path usually used for wildcard routes. If they match, we know we are on a wildcard route.This should give you a starting point to identify whether you're currently on a wildcard route from within a parent layout component.

https://www.figma.com/file/0qInyxtj8DZ6thDesNat5M/Empty-screens-exploration?type=design&node-id=81-83069&mode=design&t=CfZIYa7YXq8H6fR7-4

Conversation.Prompt: im using angular, how can i detect if im on a wildcard route in a parent component of the router? Can i for example use ActivatedRoute if im in a parent layout component?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn Angular, you can detect if you're on a wildcard route in a parent layout component by using the ActivatedRoute service. The ActivatedRoute service provides various observables and snapshot properties that help you get route information. However, it is generally associated with the component that is directly linked with the route.For a parent layout component that may not be directly linked to a specific route, you could use Angular's Router service to detect the active route. Here's a simplified example using Angular's Router service:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, we listen to the router's events observable and filter it for instances of NavigationEnd, which signals that a route change has completed.We then traverse the ActivatedRoute tree to get to the most deeply nested active route, which is where wildcard routes would be defined. We check the routeConfig.path of this route's snapshot against '**', which is the path usually used for wildcard routes. If they match, we know we are on a wildcard route.This should give you a starting point to identify whether you're currently on a wildcard route from within a parent layout component.

Author: alexgleason
Title: nip19: use template literal types

Conversation.Prompt:
I have some duplication in my TypeScript code. I resolve it, I want to create a discriminated union based on the keys and values of the interface. My code is blow. Is it possible to do what I want?

type PrefixMap = {
  nprofile: ProfilePointer
  nrelay: string
  nevent: EventPointer
  naddr: AddressPointer
  nsec: string
  npub: string
  note: string
}

type DecodeValue<Prefix extends keyof PrefixMap, Data> = {
  type: Prefix
  data: Data
}

export type DecodeResult =
  | DecodeValue<'nprofile', ProfilePointer>
  | DecodeValue<'nrelay', string>
  | DecodeValue<'nevent', EventPointer>
  | DecodeValue<'naddr', AddressPointer>
  | DecodeValue<'nsec', string>
  | DecodeValue<'npub', string>
  | DecodeValue<'note', string>
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, you can simplify this code by leveraging TypeScript's Mapped Types and Lookup Types to create your Discriminated Union in a more concise way. Here's how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This should give you the equivalent result to what you had, but with less repetition. Here, DecodeValue has been redefined to automatically infer the correct type of data based on the type key.The DecodeResult type is then created by mapping DecodeValue over each key of PrefixMap and creating a union of the results.Please note that you must ensure that you're using TypeScript 2.1 or later because Mapped Types were introduced in TypeScript 2.1.

Author: MichaelSnowden
Title: Add a schema for Prometheus rules test files
Body:
<!--
Thank you for submitting a pull request to SchemaStore.

Before continuing, please read the guidelines:
https://github.com/SchemaStore/schemastore/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

Adding a JSON schema file to the catalog is required.
Add tests files. (.json, .yml, .yaml or .toml)
Use the lowest possible schema draft needed, preferably Draft v4.
JSON formatted according to the .editorconfig settings.

-->

This PR adds a schema for Prometheus rules test files, to resolve https://github.com/SchemaStore/schemastore/issues/3001.

> Adding a JSON schema file to the catalog is required.

Added to src/api/json/catalog.json

> Add tests files. (.json, .yml, .yaml or .toml)

Added src/test/prometheus.rules.test/rules.test.yaml

> Use the lowest possible schema draft needed, preferably Draft v4.

I just borrowed what prometheus.rules used

> JSON formatted according to the .editorconfig settings.

I don't use VSCode, so I didn't run it this way, then I saw this in the contributing guide:

> If you don't have Visual Studio (using macOS or Linux?), you can check your modifications are fine by running make

However, I did not see any Makefile in this repo, so I ran the npm build referenced [here](https://github.com/SchemaStore/schemastore/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#run-build-locally) instead, and that passed. I also verified that adding an error to the positive test and then rerunning the build rule caused a failure.

Each expectation includes expected labels with their corresponding values and an expected metric value.Feel free to modify this schema according to your specific needs.

The default is 1m.group_eval_order: The order in which group names are listed for evaluation. Conversation.Prompt: how can I create muliple dataframes in python from one dataframe group by a date column?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo create multiple DataFrames in Python from one DataFrame by grouping it based on a date column, you can use the groupby() function from the pandas library. Here's an example of how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the groupby() function is used to group the DataFrame df by the 'date' column. The pd.Grouper() function is used to specify the frequency of grouping, in this case, 'D' for daily grouping. You can adjust the frequency based on your specific requirements, such as 'M' for monthly grouping or 'Y' for yearly grouping.Inside the loop, a new DataFrame named new_df is created for each group using the pd.DataFrame() constructor. You can perform any additional operations or analysis on each new DataFrame as needed.Note that the above example assumes you have a pandas DataFrame named 'df' with a column named 'date' containing datetime values. Adjust the code accordingly if your DataFrame or column names differ.

ListOfCode.Content:
import pandas as pd

# Assuming you have a DataFrame named 'df' with a 'date' column

# Convert the 'date' column to datetime type if it's not already
df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date'])

# Group the DataFrame by the 'date' column
grouped = df.groupby(pd.Grouper(key='date', freq='D'))

# Iterate over the groups and create individual DataFrames
for group_name, group_data in grouped:
    # 'group_name' is the date value
    # 'group_data' is the corresponding data for that date
    
    # Create a new DataFrame for each group
    new_df = pd.DataFrame(group_data)
    
    # Perform any additional operations or analysis on the new DataFrame
    
    # Print the new DataFrame for demonstration purposes
    print(f"DataFrame for {group_name}:")
    print(new_df)

Conversation.Prompt: GPT야 JPA를 사용할 때 DB에서 id값을 가져와야되 이럴때 entity의 생성자에서는 굳이 id에 관한 생성자를 만들어 줄 필요는 없는거야? 왜 그런거야?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPT맞습니다, JPA를 사용할 때 Entity의 생성자에서 ID에 관한 생성자를 만들어 주지 않아도 됩니다. JPA에서는 Entity의 ID 값을 관리하는 방식과 객체 생성 방식 때문에 해당 생성자를 만들 필요가 없습니다.JPA에서 Entity의 ID 값을 관리하는 방식은 크게 두 가지로 나뉩니다:자동 생성 (Auto-generated ID): 일반적으로 RDBMS에서 많이 사용되는 방식으로, 데이터베이스가 Entity가 저장될 때 자동으로 ID 값을 생성해주는 방식입니다. 대표적으로 AUTO_INCREMENT와 같은 기능이 이에 해당합니다.수동 생성 (Manual ID assignment): 개발자가 직접 ID 값을 설정하는 방식입니다. 주로 외부 시스템과의 데이터 동기화 등 특수한 경우에 사용됩니다.대부분의 경우, ID 값은 데이터베이스에서 자동으로 생성되기 때문에 생성자에서 ID 값을 명시적으로 받을 필요가 없습니다. JPA는 Entity가 영속성 컨텍스트에 추가될 때 ID 값을 확인하고 적절한 방식으로 설정해주기 때문입니다.Entity 클래스는 보통 기본 생성자를 만들어주는 것이 권장됩니다. 이렇게 기본 생성자를 만들어두면 JPA가 객체를 생성하고 초기화할 때 사용하게 됩니다. 만약 개발자가 특정 생성자를 정의하고 있는데 기본 생성자가 없다면 JPA가 Entity를 올바르게 생성할 수 없을 수 있습니다.예를 들어, JPA가 기본 생성자를 찾지 못해 오류가 발생하는 상황:[CODE_BLOCK_0]이 경우, JPA는 기본 생성자를 찾을 수 없기 때문에 오류가 발생할 수 있습니다. 따라서 기본 생성자를 추가하는 것이 좋습니다:[CODE_BLOCK_1]결론적으로, JPA에서 ID 값을 가져오는 경우 Entity의 생성자에 ID에 관한 매개변수를 추가할 필요는 없습니다. JPA가 올바른 방식으로 ID 값을 설정하고 객체를 생성하도록 기본 생성자를 제공하는 것이 중요합니다.

Author: erobitschek
Title: Initial commit
Body: Initial commit with better modularization

Conversation.Prompt: Explain Python enums with an example.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn Python, an enumeration (enum) is a symbolic name for a set of values. Enums are implemented as classes, and you can use them to create sets of constants for use with variables and properties.Here's a quick example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, we import Enum and auto from the enum standard library module. We then define a Color enum with three members: RED, GREEN, and BLUE. Using auto(), Python automatically assigns values starting from 1.Enumerations are iterable, immutable, and hashable. You can compare them using identity (is) or equality (==), but not with ordering comparisons (<, >, etc.).

ListOfCode.Content:
from enum import Enum, auto

class Color(Enum):
    RED = auto()
    GREEN = auto()
    BLUE = auto()

# Accessing enum members
print(Color.RED)  # Output: Color.RED
print(Color.RED.name)  # Output: 'RED'
print(Color.RED.value)  # Output: 1 (auto() assigns values starting from 1)

# Iterating through enum
for color in Color:
    print(color)

# Output:
# Color.RED
# Color.GREEN
# Color.BLUE

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTPurpose of Type Hints in PythonReadability: Type hints make the code more self-explanatory, improving readability.Editor Support: Tools like IDEs can use the type information for better code completion, refactoring, and error highlighting.Static Analysis: Type checkers like mypy can catch potential bugs before runtime.Checking Type Hints in a Whole Python RepoMypyThe most common tool for this is mypy. Install it via pip:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Run mypy on the entire repo:[CODE_BLOCK_1]PyrightAnother option is pyright, a static type checker from Microsoft. It's generally used as a Visual Studio Code extension but also has a CLI version.Continuous IntegrationIt's good practice to add the type checking step in your CI pipeline to ensure that all new code complies.Configuration FilesBoth mypy and pyright allow you to create configuration files (mypy.ini or pyrightconfig.json) to customize behavior.Pre-commit HooksYou can also use pre-commit hooks to run type checking before allowing commits.[CODE_BLOCK_2]SummaryUse mypy or pyright to check type hints.Integrate it into your CI/CD pipeline for automated checks.Customize behavior using config files.

Author: MichaelSnowden
Title: Make all Go source file names snake case
Body: **What changed?** I renamed all of our Go source code files so that they're snake case instead of camel case. **Why?** This was an annoying inconsistency we carried over from much older code in the repo. **How did you test it?** The renaming process was part of an automated script (https://gist.github.com/MichaelSnowden/47576fffe27aa1cae6b26eaccec7ab55), so it should be consistent. Also, I don't see us doing anything in our codebase that involves parsing our own source files by path: *PS: here's a link to the GPT convo I had to generate this renaming script: https://chat.openai.com/share/7f2d011a-a8da-4fa4-9c6d-e09102fdd49f* **Potential risks** Mainly merge conflicts, but I used `git mv` so that these are renames instead of deletes/adds, so that shouldn't be a big issue. **Is hotfix candidate?** No.

Conversation.Prompt: My codebase has a lot of old Go code which uses camel case file names like `tlsConfigHelper.go`. I'd like for all of these files to be renamed to use snake case like `tls_config_helper.go`. Can you write a bash script which will do this?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTCertainly! Here's a bash script that can help you rename the Go files from camel case to snake case:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Make sure to replace /path/to/your/codebase with the actual path to your codebase's root folder.Here's how the script works:It changes the current directory to your codebase root folder.It uses the find command to search for all Go files with camel case names.The resulting file paths are filtered using grep to exclude files that don't have a lowercase followed by an uppercase letter in their paths.For each file, it extracts the directory and base name.It converts the camel case base name to snake case using sed and tr.It constructs the new file name by appending the snake case base name to the original directory path.It renames the file using the mv command.Finally, it prints a message indicating the file has been renamed.Please be cautious when running scripts that modify your codebase, and consider making a backup or using version control before executing this script.

ListOfCode.Content:
#!/bin/bash

# Change directory to your codebase root folder
cd /path/to/your/codebase

# Find all Go files with camel case names
files=$(find . -type f -name "*.go" | grep -P '.*\/[a-z]+[A-Z]+.*')

# Loop through each file and rename it
for file in $files; do
  # Get the file's directory and base name
  dir=$(dirname "$file")
  base=$(basename "$file")

  # Convert camel case to snake case
  snake_case=$(echo "$base" | sed -E 's/([^A-Z])([A-Z])/\1_\2/g' | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')

  # Construct the new file name
  new_name="$dir/$(dirname "$base")_$snake_case"

  # Rename the file
  mv "$file" "$new_name"

  echo "Renamed $file to $new_name"
done

Conversation.Prompt: grep: invalid option -- P
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTI apologize for the confusion. It seems like the version of grep installed on your system doesn't support the -P flag for Perl-compatible regular expressions. We can modify the script to use a different approach. Please try the updated script below:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this updated version, we use the -E flag with grep to enable extended regular expressions instead of Perl-compatible regular expressions (-P). The rest of the script remains the same.Again, make sure to replace /path/to/your/codebase with the actual path to your codebase's root folder before running the script.

ListOfCode.Content:
#!/bin/bash

# Change directory to your codebase root folder
cd /path/to/your/codebase

# Find all Go files with camel case names

import os
import re

# Change directory to your codebase root folder
os.chdir('/path/to/your/codebase')

# Regex pattern to match camel case file names
pattern = re.compile(r'.*/([a-z]+[A-Z]+.*)\.go$')

# Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
    for file in files:
        # Check if the file is a Go file with camel case name
        match = pattern.match(os.path.join(root, file))
        if match:
            old_name = match.group(1)
            new_name = re.sub(r'([a-z])([A-Z])', r'\1_\2', old_name).lower() + '.go'
            new_path = os.path.join(root, new_name)

            # Rename the file
            os.rename(os.path.join(root, file), new_path)
            print(f"Renamed {os.path.join(root, file)} to {new_path}")

#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import re
import subprocess

def camel_to_snake(name):
    """Converts a camel case string to snake case."""
    result = ""
    for i, char in enumerate(name):
        if char.isupper() and (i == 0 or (i > 0 and name[i-1].islower())):
            result += char.lower()
        elif char.isupper() and i > 0:
            result += "_" + char.lower()
        else:
            result += char.lower()
    return result

def git_mv(old_path, new_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv'."""
    subprocess.run(['git', 'mv', old_path, new_path])

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command
        pattern = r'//go:generate\s+mockgen\s+.*-destination\s+(\S+)\s*'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                old_path = match
                new_path = camel_to_snake(match)
                updated_content = content.replace(old_path, new_path)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

def main():
    # Change directory to your codebase root folder
    os.chdir(os.path.join(os.environ['HOME'], 'src/temporalio/temporal'))

    # Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith('.go'):
                old_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                new_name = camel_to_snake(file[:-3]) + '.go'
                new_path = os.path.join(root, new_name)

                # Rename the file using 'git mv'
                git_mv(old_path, new_path)
                print(f"Renamed {old_path} to {new_path}")

                # Update go:generate statements in the file
                update_generate_statements(new_path)
                print(f"Updated go:generate statements in {new_path}")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import re
import subprocess

def camel_to_snake(name):
    """Converts a camel case string to snake case."""
    name = name.replace("nDC", "ndc")

    result = ""
    prev_char = ""
    for char in name:
        if char.isupper() and prev_char.islower():
            result += "_" + char.lower()
        else:
            result += char.lower()
        prev_char = char
    return result

def git_mv(old_path, new_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv'."""
    subprocess.run(['git', 'mv', old_path, new_path])

def rename_file(old_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv' and updates go:generate statements."""
    base_name = os.path.basename(old_path)
    new_name = None

    if base_name.endswith("Test.go"):
        prefix = base_name[:-len("Test.go")]
        new_name = "test_" + camel_to_snake(prefix) + ".go"
    else:
        new_name = camel_to_snake(base_name)

    new_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(old_path), new_name)
    git_mv(old_path, new_path)
    print(f"Renamed {old_path} to {new_path}")

    update_generate_statements(new_path)
    print(f"Updated go:generate statements in {new_path}")

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command
        pattern = r'//go:generate\s+mockgen\s+.*-destination\s+(\S+)\s*'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                old_path = match
                new_path = camel_to_snake(match)
                updated_content = content.replace(old_path, new_path)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

def main():
    # Change directory to your codebase root folder
    os.chdir(os.path.join(os.environ['HOME'], 'src/temporalio/temporal'))

    # Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith('.go'):
                file_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                rename_file(file_path)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements
        pattern = r'(?m)^//go:generate\s+(.*)$'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                generate_line = match
                updated_line = generate_line

                # Find Go source code file names on the line
                file_names = re.findall(r'\b(\w+\.go)\b', generate_line)
                if file_names:
                    for old_name in file_names:
                        new_name = camel_to_snake(old_name)
                        updated_line = updated_line.replace(old_name, new_name)

                # Replace the go:generate line with the updated one
                updated_content = content.replace(generate_line, updated_line)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

class ScriptTest(unittest.TestCase):

        # Create a dummy Go file
        file_path = os.path.join(self.test_dir, "testFile.go")
        with open(file_path, "w") as file:
            file.write("//go:generate mockgen -source TestFile.go -destination TestFile_mock.go")

        # Rename the file
        rename_file(file_path)

        # Check if the file is renamed
        self.assertFalse(os.path.exists(file_path))
        self.assertTrue(os.path.exists(os.path.join(self.test_dir, "test_file.go")))

        # Check if go:generate statement is updated
        with open(os.path.join(self.test_dir, "test_file.go"), "r") as file:
            content = file.read()
            self.assertIn("-source test_file.go -destination test_file_mock.go", content)

    def test_update_generate_statements(self):
        # Create a dummy Go file
        file_path = os.path.join(self.test_dir, "testFile.go")
        with open(file_path, "w") as file:
            file.write("//go:generate mockgen -source TestFile.go -destination TestFile_mock.go")

        # Update go:generate statements
        update_generate_statements(file_path)

        # Check if go:generate statement is updated
        with open(file_path, "r") as file:
            content = file.read()
            self.assertIn("-source test_file.go -destination test_file_mock.go", content)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    unittest.main()
python test_script.py

Author: maro114510
Title: Feature/fix reload
Body:
## Merge Overview

* プレビュー中のファイルの変更を画面に反映させるように修正

## Scope of Influenced

* .mainProcess.js

### Work

* 2023/06/10

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTこのコードでは、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドでファイルの変更を監視しており、変更があるとhandleLoadメソッドを呼び出しています。しかし、handleWatchFileChangesメソッド内でhandleLoadメソッドを呼び出す際に、引数としてfilePathしか渡していません。修正するには、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドでhandleLoadメソッドを呼び出す際に、適切な引数で呼び出す必要があります。具体的には、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドの定義を以下のように修正します：[CODE_BLOCK_0]handleWatchFileChangesメソッドの呼び出し元で、handleGetFileEncodingメソッドを使用してencodingを取得し、handleWatchFileChangesメソッドに渡す必要があります。具体的には、handleMainメソッドの以下の部分を修正します：[CODE_BLOCK_1]これにより、handleLoadメソッドが正しい引数で呼び出され、不要な追加のリロードとコンソールログが発生しなくなるはずです。

ChatGPThandleWatchFileChangesメソッド内でファイルの変更を監視する際に、イベントハンドラーが2回呼び出されることが原因です。これは、fs.watchメソッドが変更イベント(change)が発生した場合に複数回呼び出されることがあるためです。この問題を解決するには、handleWatchFileChangesメソッド内で最初の変更イベントが発生した時点でイベントハンドラーを一時的に無効化し、2回目以降の呼び出しを無視する必要があります。以下は修正例です：[CODE_BLOCK_0]上記の修正では、最初の変更イベントが発生した後、1秒間の間は監視フラグが無効化されます。その間に発生する変更イベントは無視されます。1秒後に監視フラグが再度有効化されるため、その後の変更イベントが再び処理されるようになります。この修正により、1回のファイル変更に対して1回のコンソールログと1回のリロードが行われるはずです。必要に応じて、無視する時間間隔を調整してください。

Conversation.Prompt: How to rebase on master?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIf you want to rebase a feature branch onto master, you're effectively moving the base of the feature branch to the latest commit in the master branch, and reapplying your changes from the feature branch on top of that. Here's a step-by-step guide to doing this with Git:Ensure you're on the feature branch: Before you start the rebase, make sure you're on the feature branch you want to rebase.[CODE_BLOCK_0]Fetch the latest changes from the remote repository: Before rebasing, it's a good idea to make sure you have the latest changes from the master branch.[CODE_BLOCK_1]Start the rebase process: Now, you can start the rebase onto master.[CODE_BLOCK_2]Resolve conflicts, if any: During the rebase process, you might encounter conflicts. If so:Edit the conflicting files to resolve the issues.After resolving the conflict in a file, mark the file as resolved using:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Once all conflicts are resolved, continue the rebase with:[CODE_BLOCK_4]If you want to abort the rebase and go back to where you were, you can use:[CODE_BLOCK_5]Push the rebased branch to the remote repository: Once the rebase is complete and you're satisfied with the changes, you can push the rebased branch to the remote repository. Since the history of the branch has changed due to the rebase, you'll need to use the --force option (use with caution).[CODE_BLOCK_6]Note: Rebasing rewrites the history of your commits. This can lead to problems if other people are also working on the same branch, as their history will differ from yours. It's usually a good idea to communicate with your team before doing a rebase and force push, especially on branches that are shared.

Author: Wissididom
Title: Migrate to use StreamElements IDs in `.env` instead of twitch loginnames

Conversation.Prompt: Is there a way I can StreamElements Account IDs and twitch loginnames apart programmatically
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo retrieve StreamElements account IDs and Twitch login names programmatically, you would typically need to interact with the StreamElements API and the Twitch API. Here's a general outline of the steps involved:Obtain API credentials: Register your application on both the StreamElements Developer Portal (https://streamelements.com/dashboard/account/developer) and the Twitch Developer Portal (https://dev.twitch.tv/). This will give you the necessary API credentials (API keys, client IDs, and client secrets) to authenticate your requests.Authenticate with StreamElements API: Use your StreamElements API credentials to authenticate your requests. You'll typically need to make an OAuth authentication request to obtain an access token that allows you to access the user's StreamElements account details. Refer to StreamElements API documentation for the specific authentication process.Retrieve StreamElements Account ID: Once you have an authenticated request, you can make API calls to retrieve the StreamElements account ID associated with the user. The specific API endpoint or method for this may vary based on the StreamElements API documentation. Look for methods such as "Get Account Details" or similar.Authenticate with Twitch API: Use your Twitch API credentials to authenticate your requests. This will typically involve generating an access token using the OAuth flow provided by the Twitch API. Refer to the Twitch API documentation for the authentication process.Retrieve Twitch Login Name: With an authenticated request to the Twitch API, you can make API calls to retrieve the user's Twitch login name. This information is usually available through the Twitch API's user endpoints, such as "Get User" or similar.By following these steps and utilizing the StreamElements API and the Twitch API, you should be able to programmatically retrieve the StreamElements account ID and Twitch login name for a user. Keep in mind that the specific API endpoints and methods may vary, so consult the respective documentation for the most up-to-date information.

Conversation.Prompt: I don't want to get the info as I already have it. I just want to find out if a string is a twitch loginname or StreamElements Account ID based on it's format
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo determine if a string is a Twitch login name or a StreamElements account ID based on its format, you can use regular expressions. Regular expressions are a powerful tool for pattern matching and can help identify specific patterns within strings.Here's an example of how you can use regular expressions to differentiate between Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the regular expression patterns twitch_pattern and streamelements_pattern are used to define the expected formats for Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs, respectively. The re.match() function is used to check if the input string matches the patterns. If a match is found, it returns the corresponding identification ("Twitch login name" or "StreamElements Account ID"). If no match is found, it returns "Unknown".You can adjust the regular expressions to match the specific format requirements for Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs, if necessary.

ListOfCode.Content:
import re

def identify_string(string):
    # Regular expression patterns for Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs
    twitch_pattern = r"^[A-Za-z0-9_]{4,25}$"
    streamelements_pattern = r"^[a-fA-F0-9]{24}$"

    if re.match(twitch_pattern, string):
        return "Twitch login name"
    elif re.match(streamelements_pattern, string):
        return "StreamElements Account ID"
    else:
        return "Unknown"

# Example usage
string1 = "mytwitchusername123"
string2 = "5eb63bbbe01eeed093cb22bb8f5acdc3"
string3 = "invalid_string"

print(identify_string(string1))  # Output: Twitch login name
print(identify_string(string2))  # Output: StreamElements Account ID
print(identify_string(string3))  # Output: Unknown

Conversation.Prompt:
# 命令書:
あなたはReact v18やNext.js v13.4.0のApp Routerに精通したベテランのフロントエンドエンジニアです。
以下の制約条件と入力文をもとに、想定されるプログラミングのソースコードを出力してください。

# 制約条件:
・英語の文献を中心に調べて日本語に翻訳して回答して。
・文章を簡潔に。
・参照ソースがあれば出力文の末尾に一覧形式でURLを記載する。
・重要なキーワードを取り残さない。
・Next.jsの公式ドキュメントのデータを元に出力してください。

# 入力文:
Next.jsのプロジェクトにおいてファイルシステムルーティング内のリンクに対してリンクを実装する場合はnext/linkのLinkコンポーネントを使用すると思いますが、Next.jsのプロジェクトとは関係のない外部のURLを使用してリンクを実装する場合もLinkコンポーネントを使用していいでしょうか？

# 出力文:
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTFinished browsingShow workHide workNext.jsの<Link>コンポーネントは、HTMLの<a>要素を拡張し、プリフェッチングとクライアントサイドのナビゲーションを提供するReactコンポーネントです。これはNext.jsのルート間を移動する主要な方法です【7†source】。しかし、Next.jsのドキュメントや一部の開発者の意見では、外部のURLへのリンクを作成する場合は、通常は<Link>コンポーネントを使用しない方が良いとされています。その代わりに、通常のHTMLの<a>タグを使用することが推奨されています【8†source】【15†source】【16†source】。しかし、Next.jsの<Link>コンポーネント内で外部リンクを作成したい場合は、passHrefという属性を使用することができます。この属性はデフォルトでfalseに設定されていますが、trueに設定することで、<Link>コンポーネントがhrefプロパティをその子要素に渡すことを強制します【14†source】。以下に、通常のHTMLの<a>タグを使用する例と、passHref属性を使用する例を示します：[CODE_BLOCK_0]また、外部リンクと内部リンクを切り替えるためのカスタムコンポーネントを作成することも可能です。以下にその例を示します：[CODE_BLOCK_1]このように、<Link>コンポーネントは内部のリンクに対して使用されるべきですが、特定の状況下では外部のリンクに対しても使用可能です。ただし、外部のURLへのリンクには通常のHTMLの<a>タグを使用することが推奨されています。参照ソース：Components: <Link> | Next.js (nextjs.org) https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/linkjavascript - External link is not working in Next.js when you want to use Link component - Stack Overflow (stackoverflow.com) https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63558320/external-link-is-not-working-in-next-js-when-you-want-to-use-link-component

Author: hoshotakamoto
Title: Get backfilledResults to show non-empty.

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYour existing implementation already has a lot of the functionality you're seeking. The Game class has methods to interact with localStorage, get and set user data, and display results.However, to render the contents of localStorage on every page load, you need to make sure you call the initialize() function at the start of each page load. It seems your code currently only creates a new instance of the Game class, but it does not call the initialize() function unless initializeImmediately is set to true.Update the last few lines in your game.js file as follows to call the initialize() function whenever a new Game instance is created:[CODE_BLOCK_0]By passing true as an argument when creating a new Game instance, you're enabling immediate initialization, which includes displaying the current user and the backfilled results.Regarding unit tests, here is an example of how you might write tests to check these functionalities using a testing framework like Jest:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Note: You would need to adjust the tests depending on the specifics of your implementation and the testing environment. This is just a starting point to give you an idea.

ChatGPTYour tests are failing likely because the initialize() function is called immediately upon the creation of the Game object. This function attaches event listeners to the respective buttons and selects. If initializeImmediately is set to true in your tests, the initialize() function will execute before you can set up your mock elements, which is why the tests fail.In your tests, game = new Game(); is being called in the beforeEach() block, which means initialize() is being called before any of the tests are set up. One way to fix this is to call initialize() separately in each test after you've set up your mock elements.Also, remember that if you want to check whether a method has been called, you need to spy on it. So instead of expect(game.initialize).toBeCalled();, you would use jest.spyOn(game, 'initialize') and then expect(spy).toBeCalled();.So here's how you could modify your tests:[CODE_BLOCK_0]

ChatGPTIt's understandable you'd want to prevent the automatic initialization of your Game class during the import, especially when running tests. It can be problematic because it could lead to unexpected side effects during testing, as it's running before the test environment is fully set up.A common way to handle this issue in JavaScript is to have a separate function or method to bootstrap the application. This function/method should be the one that creates new instances of your main classes and calls any necessary startup methods.For instance, you could create a new initGame function in your game.js file:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Then, in your application's main entry point file (which might be a different JavaScript file that gets loaded in your HTML), you'd call this initGame function to start the game. This separation ensures that merely importing the Game class doesn't automatically create a new instance and run the initialize method.However, you need to make sure you're not auto-initializing Game elsewhere in your code. This approach requires your application to manually initialize Game in the actual application code (outside of tests).Finally, you'd import Game in your tests without it auto-initializing:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Now your beforeEach setup in your tests should run correctly without being interfered with by the initialize method. Your tests can create new Game instances and call initialize as needed.

Author: mikaylathompson
Title: Add MetricsLogger to the Capture Proxy
Body: ### Description Adds a MetricsLogger to the Capture Proxy. For now, it creates a limited number of events, with a limited number of dimensions. Events: - Component of request received (logged on `LoggingHttpRequestHandler::channelRead`) - Full request received (logged on `LoggingHttpRequestHandler::channelFinishedReadingAnHttpMessage`) - Sending message to Kafka (logged on `KafkaCaptureFactory::createOffloader` in the handler for a completed CodedOutputStream) - Message to Kafka failed (same as above) - Component of a response received (logged on `LoggingHttpResponseHandler::write`) All messages are logged with the `channelId` which corresponds to the `connectionId`/`diagnosticId` used throughout the Replayer. Some messages have additional context info, e.g. full request received also has the http method & endpoint. The event I would like to include but wasn't able to find already existing in our code is when a full response is received. I don't think this is an essential enough event that it's worth adding a HTTP accumulator to the pipeline, but if I missed a spot where this message is accumulated already, I'd like to add it. Events are logged in a json format (see example below). After playing with various text based log formats, this was by far the cleanest way to extract components as an AWS Metrics Filter, and should give us flexibility in the docker solution as well. To test this out, I created a metrics filter that looked specifically for "Full request received" events and plotted them while I did two `./runTestBenchmarks.sh` runs. Example logs: This shows MetricsLogger events mixed in with default logger events from the docker solution: ``` [DEBUG] 2023-09-07 04:33:27.088 [nioEventLoopGroup-3-1] FrontsideHandler - channelRead Conversation.Prompt: I'm looking at some logging code that uses Slf4j's MDC to keep track of some extra context.  I'm in a highly concurrent environment though & MDC will carry its own risks.  Can I setup the same context directly through a log.atLevel()... fluent approach?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTSLF4J (Simple Logging Facade for Java) provides the MDC (Mapped Diagnostic Context) feature to associate metadata with current thread logs. This is especially helpful for tasks like tracking user sessions across application layers. However, in highly concurrent environments, especially when dealing with asynchronous programming (like using CompletableFuture, reactive streams, etc.), thread-local storage like MDC can be problematic.Let me explain the potential issues with MDC in asynchronous contexts:Thread-local Leakage: If thread-local variables are not cleaned up before a thread is reused (as in thread pools), there can be unintended leakage of the MDC values from one task to another.Lost Context: In asynchronous operations, the thread handling the initial part of a request might be different from the one handling the continuation. Thus, the MDC values can get lost if not explicitly propagated.If you're using the Logback logging framework (a popular choice with SLF4J), Logback does provide some utilities to assist with this, like the LogbackMDCAdapter which helps to manage MDC values.Now, as for your specific question about using a fluent approach with log.atLevel()..., you're probably referring to the newer, more fluent logging APIs (like the one introduced in Log4j 2).With the fluent approach, you can directly attach context data to a log message without storing it in a thread-local storage. Here's a basic example using Log4j 2:[CODE_BLOCK_0]To achieve this with SLF4J, you'd need to integrate or extend it with a logging framework that supports this fluent style.If you can switch or are already using Log4j 2, then it provides these capabilities out of the box. Otherwise, if you're committed to SLF4J, and if it doesn't natively support the feature you want (depending on the underlying logging framework), you might have to write some custom utility or wrapper to make it more fluent and context-aware without relying on MDC.A final note: If you decide to continue using MDC in asynchronous contexts, consider tools/libraries/frameworks like ContextAwareExecutorService or solutions like Project Reactor's Context (for reactive programming) to help propagate context correctly.

ListOfCode.Content:
Logger logger = LogManager.getLogger();
logger.atInfo().withKeyValue("userId", "12345").log("User logged in");

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe diff you provided showcases changes to the file src/handlers/wildcard/unassign.ts. I'll walk you through the changes and provide an interpretation of what the contributor likely intended:Import Changes:A new import from ../../types was added for UserType.A new import from ../shared was added for deadLinePrefix.Code Changes:The contributor added a new block of code that focuses on finding the last comment made by a bot that includes both the assignee's name and a certain prefix (deadLinePrefix).Here's a more in-depth look at the code block:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This block does the following:From all comments, it filters out those that:Are made by a bot (UserType.Bot).Include the first assignee's name (assignees[0]).Include a specific prefix (deadLinePrefix).It then sorts these comments based on their creation date in descending order.If there's at least one such comment, its creation date is added to the activities array.Interpretation:Given the comments and the context of the file (from its name and other code blocks), it appears that the contributor is enhancing a function that determines the last activity time on an issue. Specifically, the contributor wants to account for a particular type of bot comment that mentions an assignee and has a specific prefix (deadLinePrefix). This suggests that these bot comments have some significance in determining issue activity, perhaps related to assigning deadlines or milestones to the issue's assignee.Without broader context or accompanying documentation, it's challenging to pin down the exact intention. However, this change likely helps improve the accuracy or comprehensiveness of the lastActivityTime function by accounting for these special bot comments.

ListOfCode.Content:
const lastAssignCommentOfHunter = comments
    .filter((comment) => 
        comment.user.type === UserType.Bot && 
        comment.body.includes(assignees[0]) && 
        comment.body.includes(deadLinePrefix))
    .sort((a: Comment, b: Comment) => 
        new Date(b.created_at).getTime() - new Date(a.created_at).getTime());
if (lastAssignCommentOfHunter.length > 0) activities.push(new Date(lastAssignCommentOfHunter[0].created_at));

Conversation.Prompt: I have a react application and I have component that when property is true it will use provider from different library. Can I dynamicly import this library only when the condition is met?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, you can dynamically import a module in a React application based on a condition using the import() function. This is particularly useful for code splitting and lazy-loading components or libraries.Here's a basic example of how you might use dynamic imports in a React component:Setting up a new React app:If you don't have a React app already, you can create one using Create React App:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Using dynamic imports:Let's say you want to conditionally import and use a hypothetical library called SomeLibraryProvider. Here's how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Points to consider:import() returns a promise, so you can use .then() to handle the imported module.SomeLibraryProvider is dynamically set in the component state only after the library is imported.This approach will create a separate chunk for the some-library during the build process if you're using a bundler like Webpack (which is used by Create React App by default). This means the library will be loaded only when required, potentially improving the initial load performance of your application.Always remember to handle potential errors when using dynamic imports, like network failures. You can add a .catch() to the promise to handle these cases.That's it! You've successfully set up dynamic imports based on a condition in a React component.

ListOfCode.Content: npx create-react-app dynamic-import-example

Author: Ashk2a
Title: Feat/matches ids ulid
Body:
# Summary
Add possibility to match ULID route key.

## FYI
- [Laravel documentation](https://laravel.com/docs/10.x/routing#parameters-regular-expression-constraints)
- Use same regex than [`whereUlid`](https://github.com/laravel/framework/blob/53b02b3c1d926c095cccca06883a35a5c6729773/src/Illuminate/Routing/CreatesRegularExpressionRouteConstraints.php#L48) method when defining routes.

Conversation.Prompt: Hello can you give me a regex to match ULID format ?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTCertainly! The following regular expression can be used to match the ULID (Universally Unique Lexicographically Sortable Identifier) format:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Explanation:^ asserts the start of the string.[0-9A-HJKMNP-TV-Z] matches any character in the range 0-9, A-H, J-K, M-N, P-T, or V-Z.{26} specifies that the preceding character class should occur exactly 26 times (the length of a ULID).$ asserts the end of the string.Note that ULIDs are case-sensitive and use a modified base32 encoding, excluding the characters I, L, O, and Q to avoid confusion with numerals.

ListOfCode.Content: ^[0-9A-HJKMNP-TV-Z]{26}$

Author: simonbukin
Title: Add map view
Body:
# Taxonium Map View

This PR adds a map view to Taxonium, which allows for tracking origins of samples in the tree.

## Screenshots

TBA

### [Video](https://streamable.com/7ozvpl)  (will need to be updated with a permanent link after expiry in a few days)

This is a pretty large PR, and I think some of the merge difficulty may come from the swap of naming from `taxonium_web_client` to `taxonium_component` (it took a little while to get this working locally).

The other more major change in the layout of the code was in `useView.js`, in which I switched to checking the `viewId` and using `setViewState` to compartmentalize the viewState updates. This was necessary because keeping both the map state (like zoom, latitude, longitude, etc) and tree state in the same viewState led to tons of problems and unexpected crashes when a viewState update for one view overwrote another. I'm a little weary that this change didn't introduce bugs in other parts of Taxonium, since I was mostly focused on the map view, so this is definitely something to check on.

Can definitely add more to this PR and fix any problems you may find. Thanks!

However, you can create a custom layer to display pie charts on the map by extending one of the existing layers or writing a new one from scratch.Here is an example of how you might create a custom DeckGL layer for pie charts by extending the CompositeLayer. This example uses the SolidPolygonLayer to draw each slice of the pie. The data should include the longitude, latitude, and an array of values for each pie chart.Below is a basic example of how you can create such a layer:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Note: This code is not complete and is meant to be a starting point. You would need to fill in the details and handle edge cases according to your specific requirements. You also need to implement the getRadiusInPixel and toRadians utility functions, and the getArc function to generate polygons representing each slice of the pie based on the start and end angles and the radius of the pie.You would also need to provide the getColor prop to determine the color of each slice, and the radius prop to determine the size of the pie charts. The data prop should be an array of objects, each containing a position property with the longitude and latitude, and a values property with the array of values for the pie chart.

Author: nipe0324
Title: Wrap ActiveRecord::Base with ActiveSupport.on_load
Body:
This PR try to fix #198

Cause
---

### Before: Rails initialization order is NOT good.

First. Set `ActiveRecord::Base.filter_attributes` which is empty array.

```rb
# https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v7.0.5/activerecord/lib/active_record/railtie.rb#L318-L322
initializer "active_record.set_filter_attributes" do
  ActiveSupport.on_load(:active_record) do
    self.filter_attributes += Rails.application.config.filter_parameters
  end
end
```

Second. Initialize `Rails.application.config.filter_parameters`

```rb
# My Rails Application
# config/initializers/filter_parameter_logging.rb
Rails.application.config.filter_parameters += [
  :passw, :secret, :token, :_key, :crypt, :salt, :certificate, :otp, :ssn
]
````
### After: Rails initialization order is good.

First. Initialize `Rails.application.config.filter_parameters`

```rb
# My Rails Application
# config/initializers/filter_parameter_logging.rb
Rails.application.config.filter_parameters += [
  :passw, :secret, :token, :_key, :crypt, :salt, :certificate, :otp, :ssn
]
````

Second. Set `ActiveRecord::Base.filter_attributes` which is NOT empty array.

```rb
# https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v7.0.5/activerecord/lib/active_record/railtie.rb#L318-L322
initializer "active_record.set_filter_attributes" do
  ActiveSupport.on_load(:active_record) do

end
```

Test
---

Use fixed gem

```

=> 
#<ActiveSupport::ParameterFilter:0x0000000111df2188

when using activerecord-multi-tenant library in my rails  project, filters does not work. I prepared a fix and now I want to unit test it to see that fix is actually working.

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTCertainly! I can help you with a unit test to verify that the fix for filtering sensitive parameters in logs is working correctly. Here's an example test using RSpec that you can use as a starting point:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, we create a mock controller and override the params method to return a hash containing sensitive parameter values. Then, we invoke the action that logs the parameters. After that, we fetch the logs from the logger and assert that the sensitive values are filtered out.Make sure you replace action_that_logs_parameters with the actual method name in your code that logs the parameters. Additionally, modify the example to fit your project's file structure and testing framework if necessary.Remember to include the necessary dependencies, such as rails_helper, in the test file, and configure your testing environment to load the required files.This test should help you verify that the fix properly filters out the sensitive parameter values from the logs.

ListOfCode.Content:
# spec/your_fix_spec.rb

require 'rails_helper'

RSpec.describe "Filtering sensitive parameters in logs" do
  it "filters out secret values from logs" do
    # Mocking a controller action with sensitive parameters
    params = { 
      passw: "password",
      secret: "secret_value",
      token: "access_token",
      _key: "api_key",
      crypt: "encrypted_value",
      salt: "salt_value",
      certificate: "certificate_data",
      otp: "123456",
      ssn: "123-45-6789"
    }
    
    controller = ApplicationController.new
    allow(controller).to receive(:params).and_return(params)
    
    # Trigger the action that logs the parameters
    controller.action_that_logs_parameters
    
    # Fetch the logs
    logs = Rails.logger.instance_variable_get(:@logdev).dev.string
    
    # Ensure that the sensitive parameters are filtered in logs
    expect(logs).not_to include("password")
    expect(logs).not_to include("secret_value")
    expect(logs).not_to include("access_token")
    expect(logs).not_to include("api_key")
    expect(logs).not_to include("encrypted_value")
    expect(logs).not_to include("salt_value")
    expect(logs).not_to include("certificate_data")
    expect(logs).not_to include("123456")
    expect(logs).not_to include("123-45-6789")
  end
end

Author: displague
Title: Support deep frontmatter property setting using pydash
Body:
Adds support for deep frontmatter property setting using pydash. This allows, for example, the ability to define additional `tags` or set `author` details when there are multiple authors with multiple fields per author.

Dependencies were also updated to include `pydash` and bumping Python version to 3.11 (minimum stays at 3.7).

A Contributions section was added to the README.md with some of the tips that I picked up while trying to ensure the contribution met the project's expectations.

Fixes #5 

Credit to ChatGPT 🤖: https://chat.openai.com/share/56cc6f3c-6581-41f9-afa7-4021c9ef1b07

(also see https://common-changelog.org/)

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe Python script you posted appears to be a command line interface (CLI) program that reads and writes YAML front matter in Markdown files. The front matter is a block of YAML, JSON, or TOML formatted text at the beginning of a Markdown file enclosed by triple hyphen or triple tilde characters (--- or ~~~).This script uses the click and frontmatter Python libraries. click is a package for creating CLI applications, while frontmatter is used for loading, manipulating, and writing YAML front matter from and to Markdown files.Here's a brief overview of the key parts of your script:validate_extra_context: This function validates input given in the format of key-value pairs separated by an equals sign (=), e.g., "key=value". This input is later used to update the metadata in the Markdown file.cli: This function serves as the main entry point for the command-line interface. It uses the click.group decorator to group multiple command-line commands together.main: This is the main command of the CLI. It takes as arguments an input file, an output file, and any additional context (metadata) to be added to the Markdown file. It then reads the Markdown file, updates the metadata if any extra context is provided, and writes the result to the output file.Here's an example usage:python script.py --extra_context key=value input.md output.mdIn this example, script.py is the Python script, key=value is the extra context, input.md is the input file, and output.md is the output file. The script will read the YAML front matter from input.md, update the metadata with the extra context, and then write the result to output.md.Remember to install the required packages (click, frontmatter, and click-default-group) if you haven't already:pip install click python-frontmatter click-default-group

Conversation.Prompt:
It would be useful to be able to work with more elaborate, bespoke, frontmatter formats.

For example, I'd like this behavior:
```
$ echo "hello" | frontmatter-cli --versions[0].version="1.2.3" - -
---
versions:
- version: 1.2.3
---

hello
The current behavior results in:

$ echo "hello" | frontmatter-cli --versions[0].version="1.2.3" - -
---
versions[0].version: 1.2.3
---

hello
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn its current form, the frontmatter-cli script treats each extra context as a flat key-value pair and directly updates the metadata. To support a more complex structure like versions[0].version, you'd need to modify the script to interpret and apply these updates as nested properties instead of flat properties.Below is a modified version of your script that supports dot notation for nested properties. It makes use of the dpath library, which you can install using pip:[CODE_BLOCK_0]And here's the modified script:[CODE_BLOCK_1]The dpath library allows us to create and manipulate nested dictionary properties using slash-separated paths (like file paths). In the case of versions[0].version="1.2.3", versions/0/version is used as the path to create or update the nested property.Note: The dpath library doesn't currently support dot notation (e.g., versions.0.version) out of the box, so you'd need to replace dots with slashes for nested properties. You can either do this manually in your extra context, or add logic to the script to automatically replace dots with slashes.

ListOfCode.Content: pip install dpath

Conversation.Prompt: Is there a python library that does support a dot notation, like a javascript style of notation?
Conversation.Answer: The previous model used in this conversation is unavailable. We've switched you to the latest default model.ChatGPTYes, there is a Python library called python-dotenv that provides dot notation for accessing nested properties in a dictionary-like structure. It is commonly used for working with environment variables, but it can also be used for general-purpose nested property access.To use python-dotenv, you can install it using pip:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Here's an example of how you can modify your script to utilize python-dotenv for nested property access:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In this modified version, we use the dotenv_values function from python-dotenv to load the extra context into a dictionary-like structure that supports dot notation. Then, we use the set_key function to set the nested property in the metadata.With this modification, you can now use dot notation in the extra context. For example:[CODE_BLOCK_2]This will set the versions[0].version property in the metadata to "1.2.3".

ListOfCode.Content: pip install python-dotenv
python script.py --extra_context versions.0.version="1.2.3" input.md output.md

Conversation.Prompt: When I use `scanf("%lld", p);`, it shows warning on Linux. When I use `scanf("%ld", p);`, it shows warnings on macos. What should I do? I think it is related to gcc vs clang. `p` is declared as `int64_t *`.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe warnings you are encountering when using scanf are related to format specifiers not matching the type of the pointer you're using. To fix this issue and ensure your code is portable across different platforms (Linux with GCC and macOS with Clang), you should use the correct format specifier for int64_t and make sure you pass a pointer to the appropriate type.On most platforms, including Linux with GCC and macOS with Clang, int64_t is a 64-bit integer type, so you should use the %lld format specifier. However, you need to pass a pointer to int64_t when using scanf. Here's how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this code, we use SCNd64 for the format specifier, which is a macro from the <inttypes.h> header that corresponds to the correct format specifier for int64_t. Similarly, we use PRId64 to print the value, which is the correct format specifier for int64_t.This code should work without warnings on both Linux with GCC and macOS with Clang, ensuring portability across different platforms.

Conversation.Prompt: Please can you tell me how to roll back a Spring repository save when an exception is thrown outside of the Spring repository? So not a database exception but something else after the repository has invoked and completed a save operation?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn Spring, the process of rolling back a transaction when an exception occurs outside of the Spring repository involves using transaction management and the appropriate configuration. By default, Spring uses declarative transaction management, which allows you to define transaction boundaries declaratively using annotations or XML configuration.Here's an approach you can follow to roll back a Spring repository save when an exception is thrown outside of the repository:Enable transaction management: Ensure that transaction management is enabled in your Spring application. This can be done by configuring the appropriate transaction manager bean, such as DataSourceTransactionManager for database transactions.Define transaction boundaries: Specify the boundaries of your transaction by annotating the service method that calls the repository save operation with the @Transactional annotation. This annotation can be applied to class-level or method-level, depending on your requirements.For example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Handle exceptions: Make sure to catch any exceptions that occur outside of the repository, either in your service layer or any higher layer. In the catch block, you can either log the exception or perform any necessary error handling.Trigger rollback: To trigger a rollback when an exception occurs, you can re-throw the caught exception or throw a new exception from your catch block. By default, Spring's transaction management will roll back the transaction when a runtime exception is thrown.For example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]By following this approach, when an exception occurs outside of the Spring repository, the transaction will be marked for rollback, and any changes made during the repository save operation will be rolled back.It's worth noting that for this approach to work, you need to ensure that your Spring repository is invoked within the transactional boundaries defined by the @Transactional annotation.
