Conversation.Prompt:
Following is a github action which builds the packages given.

How do I disable the internet access during the build process? And reopen it once the build is done or failed?

```
   - name: Build
      run: |
        colcon build --event-handlers console_cohesion+ \
          --packages-above-and-dependencies ${{ inputs.target-packages }} \
          --cmake-args -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=${{ inputs.cmake-build-type }} \
          --mixin coverage-gcc coverage-pytest compile-commands
      shell: bash
```
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo disable internet access during the build process and then restore it afterward, you can utilize iptables (assuming you're on a Linux-based runner). Here's a step-by-step explanation and how you can modify your GitHub Actions workflow:Before the build step, run a step that disables outgoing internet connections using iptables. This would block all outgoing requests.After the build step, run another step to restore the network connectivity by flushing the iptables rules.Here's how your modified workflow would look:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Some explanations:The sudo iptables -P OUTPUT DROP command sets the default policy for the OUTPUT chain to DROP, effectively cutting off internet access for outgoing requests.The sudo iptables -A OUTPUT -o lo -j ACCEPT command allows local connections to be maintained (e.g., localhost).The sudo iptables -F command flushes the iptables rules, restoring the previous network connectivity.The if: always() condition for the "Restore Internet" step ensures that it always runs, regardless of whether the previous step succeeded or failed.Do note, however, that you might need to ensure that your runner has iptables installed. Most standard Linux distributions have it by default, but some minimal images might not. Also, remember that this only stops outgoing internet access; incoming requests would still be allowed unless you add rules to block those as well.

ListOfCode.Content:
- name: Disable Internet
     run: |
       sudo iptables -P OUTPUT DROP
       sudo iptables -A OUTPUT -o lo -j ACCEPT
     shell: bash

   - name: Build
     run: |
       colcon build --event-handlers console_cohesion+ \
         --packages-above-and-dependencies ${{ inputs.target-packages }} \
         --cmake-args -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=${{ inputs.cmake-build-type }} \
         --mixin coverage-gcc coverage-pytest compile-commands
     shell: bash

   - name: Restore Internet
     if: always()
     run: |
       sudo iptables -F
     shell: bash

Author: Enprogames
Title: Added Additional and Multiple Submission Types for Quest Submissions
Body:
## What?
I created the models that will allow us to support quests having multiple questions. I also created CRUDL views to allow teachers to create/view/edit/delete questions for quests. For any quest, they can access these views by clicking the new "Edit Questions" button beside the "Edit Prerequisites" button. Finally, I added the functionality for students to submit their answers to questions. 

The new models implement the following ER diagram:

![question_uml](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/2fa687b5-8602-422b-8ebb-760db0f92fe1)

The dashed lines indicate weak relationships, meaning, for example, that a Question cannot exist without a Quest.

## Why?
With these changes, teachers can add multiple submissions to quests. This will make it easier for them to enforce that students answer certain questions, and will make multi-question quests easier for students to understand.

## How?

### Question and QuestionSubmission Models

Everything related to questions, except for how they are used in the quest_manager app, has been moved to a new app called "questions".

❗ **Edit**: I've made a few crucial design decisions since the last review, and these decisions should be evaluated:
#### on_delete behavior for Questions and QuestionSubmissions
- When a Question's Quest is deleted, so is the Question.
- When a QuestionSubmission's Comment is deleted, so is the QuestionSubmission.
- When a QuestionSubmission's Question is deleted, the QuestionSubmission is *not* deleted. This reflects the same relationship that Quests have to QuestSubmissions.

#### `__str__` String representations of Questions and QuestionSubmissions
This was tricky to come up with. The string represenations needed to be different from other string representations. I thought it would make sense for a Question to be represented as `<Quest Name> (<Question Ordinal in Quest>)`, but this format is already used by QuestSubmissions, so I had to come up with something new. Below is what I went with for each object:

```py
class Question(models.Model):
...
    def __str__(self):
        """Return string representation in format of: [Quest Name] ([Question Type] - [Question Ordinal])
        e.g. "Quest 1 (short_answer - 1)" for the first question in the quest with name "Quest 1"
        """
        return f"{self.quest.name} ({self.type} - {self.ordinal})"
...
class QuestionSubmission(models.Model):
...
    def __str__(self):
        """Return string representation in format of: [Comment datetime string] - ([question ordinal])
        e.g. "2022-3-22 1:00PM - (1)" for the first question in the student's quest submission
        If the question is None, return: [Comment datetime string] - (?)
        """
        comment_time = self.comment.timestamp.strftime("%Y-%m-%d %-I:%M%p")
        if self.question:
            return f"{comment_time} - ({self.question.ordinal})"
        else:
            return f"{comment_time} - (?)"
```

#### `next_ordinal(cls, quest)` Question Class Method
Deciding how to handle incrementing ordinal values was tricky. We want to ensure that Questions can be added, deleted, and reordered by teachers, and we want to avoid the problems that occurred with the Quest Submission ordinals. I tried overriding the `save()` method, overriding the `delete()` method, and creating a `reorder(self, new_position)` method, but each of these would have been out of the scope of this task. So instead, we opted for creating a simple `new_ordinal(cls, quest)` class method for the Question model. It is implemented as follows:
```py
class Question(models.Model):
...
    @classmethod
    def next_ordinal(cls, quest):
        """Return the next ordinal value for a question in this quest"""
        max_ordinal = Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).aggregate(Max('ordinal'))['ordinal__max']
        return (max_ordinal or 0) + 1
```

This can be called like so:
```py
from quest_manager.models import Quest, Question

quest1 = Quest.objects.get(...)
next_ordinal_in_quest = Question.next_ordinal(quest1)

next_question = Question.objects.create(quest=quest1, ordinal=next_ordinal_in_quest, instructions='')
```

Go to `src/questions/models.py` for the full implementation of the question models.

### Question CRUDL Views

These views can accessed through the following URLS:
```py
path('<int:quest_id>/questions/', views.QuestionListView.as_view(), name='question_list'),
path('<int:quest_id>/questions/create/<str:question_type>', views.QuestionCreateView.as_view(),
     name='question_create'),
path('<int:quest_id>/questions/<int:pk>/', views.QuestionUpdateView.as_view(), name='question_update'),
path('<int:quest_id>/questions/<int:pk>/delete/', views.QuestionDeleteView.as_view(), name='question_delete'),
```

The full implementations for these views can be seen in `src/questions/views.py`.

### QuestionSubmission Views
With these changes, when a student fills in their responses for a multi-question quest, they will be shown a form for each question. And teachers can view their responses in a dropdown menu underneath their submission comment.

Please see the screenshots below.

## Testing?
- Tests for Question and QuestionSubmission models in `questions/tests/test_models.py`.
    - 23 new tests
- Tests for Question CRUDL views in `questions/tests/test_views.py`
    - 20 new tests
- Tests for QuestionSubmissions in `quest_manager/tests/test_views.py`
    - SubmissionViewTests
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_has_changes`
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_question_has_changes`
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_question_file_upload`
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_question_file_wrong_type_rejected`
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_questions_no_changes`
    - `test_question_submission_form_fields_for_types`
    - `test_students_can_view_past_question_submissions`
    - `test_teachers_can_view_past_question_submissions`
    - `test_student_cannot_see_solutions_or_notes`
    - `test_teachers_can_see_solutions_and_notes`
    - `test_question_submissions_created_for_new_submission`
    - `test_question_submissions_and_comment_not_created_with_existing_submissions`
    - `test_comment_and_questions_deleted_on_drop`
    - SubmissionCompleteViewTest
    - `test_submit_questions`
    - `test_submit_file_question`
    - `test_students_must_complete_required_questions`
    - `test_questions_allowed_file_type`
- Revised tests for QuestSubmissions in `quest_manager/tests/test_models.py` (due to change of draft_text to draft_comment)
    - `test_submission_mark_completed`

## Screenshots (if front end is affected)
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/ef3fa24c-2b03-4834-88cb-cd5b7c239d61)

![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/9b6a734c-6cb9-4e17-894b-67d99f50a10c)

![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/3735f9a0-1207-4afd-b6d1-3595037ba482)

Instructors can see a table of questions, and can easily click to edit or delete them.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/9e963381-da99-447d-9471-14d3caf8a782)

Students can see a list of questions for a quest in their version of the quest detailed view.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/ad23f4f5-f467-4abe-8080-2eeaebd01d7f)

Above the original quest submission field, a formset of question response fields is shown. This is where the student responds to the quest questions.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/5ecc2b47-9242-448b-b2db-e81fda89cea6)

Question responses can be viewed in a table by clicking the "Question Submissions" dropdown.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/a9da9674-4714-496d-9f3e-7e581197454d)

Teachers are shown a different view of question submissions that includes solutions and marker notes:
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/2fb0ba92-0e0f-451e-a313-7a223b2d7d2b)

## Anything Else?
None of the frontend code is setup to look good on mobile devices. I suggest that we create an issue for it, and work on doing that in a brand-new PR, after this one is merged.

I also wanted to mention that a lot of the question content is truncated, since it is difficult to show a lot of content in a table. For this reason, I added tooltips to the question table shown below. I'm not sure how to show this in a screenshot, but the full content of the instructions and solutions can be seen in a bootstrap tooltip by hovering over the content.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/8d6d26d9-b719-4759-8198-bf1c6eca1469)

## Review request
@tylerecouture

Conversation.Prompt:
What SQL is generated by Django for this queryset:
`Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).last()`
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe Django queryset Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).last() retrieves the last (most recent) Question object that matches the given filter condition quest=quest. The generated SQL query for this queryset would look something like:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Here, "yourapp_question" should be replaced with the actual database table name for the Question model in your Django application, and 'desired_quest_value' should be replaced with the specific value you are filtering on.The query first filters the rows based on the quest column value, orders the results in descending order by the primary key column (id is a common primary key field name in Django), and then limits the result to just one row using the LIMIT 1 clause to retrieve the last matching Question object.

ListOfCode.Content:
SELECT *
FROM "yourapp_question"
WHERE "yourapp_question"."quest" = 'desired_quest_value'
ORDER BY "yourapp_question"."id" DESC
LIMIT 1;

Conversation.Prompt:
What SQL is generated by Django for this queryset: 
`Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).aggregate(Max('ordinal'))['ordinal__max']`
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe Django queryset Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).aggregate(Max('ordinal'))['ordinal__max'] calculates the maximum value of the ordinal field among the Question objects that match the given filter condition quest=quest. The generated SQL query for this queryset would look something like:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Here, "yourapp_question" should be replaced with the actual database table name for the Question model in your Django application, and 'desired_quest_value' should be replaced with the specific value you are filtering on.The query calculates the maximum value of the ordinal column for rows that satisfy the filter condition. The result is aliased as "ordinal__max" for easy retrieval in the Python code.

Conversation.Prompt: laravel redirect with flush message
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo redirect a user to a new page in Laravel and include a flash message, you can make use of Laravel's session flashing feature. Here's an example of how you can achieve this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, redirectToNewPage is a controller method that handles the logic for redirecting to a new page. Within the method, we flash a message to the session using session()->flash('message', 'Your message goes here'). Replace 'Your message goes here' with the actual message you want to display.Next, we use redirect()->route('new-page') to create a redirect response to the desired page. Make sure to replace 'new-page' with the actual route name or URL of the new page you want to redirect to.On the new page, you can access the flashed message and display it using the session helper. For example, in your Blade template:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This code checks if there's a flashed message in the session (session('message')). If it exists, it displays an alert div with the message inside. You can customize the HTML and styling as needed.Remember to include the appropriate CSS classes or styles for the alert message to be displayed properly.

Restructuring the code and adding more classes (Option 1) can make the code more maintainable and modular. Author: aliabid94
Title: Fixes audio streaming issues
Body:
Two issues fixed (linked):
1. Was originally skipping first chunk yielded
2. Streaming really only works with mp3 types so convert wav files to mp3 if streaming.

Fixes: #5168

Conversation.Prompt: How can I use fastapi StreamingResponse to stream several wav files as chunks?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIf you want to stream several .wav files as chunks using FastAPI's StreamingResponse, you can do so by reading each file in chunks and yielding those chunks to the client. Here's a step-by-step approach:First, make sure you have FastAPI and Uvicorn installed:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Create a simple FastAPI application:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Run your FastAPI application:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Replace your_filename with the name of the Python file you saved the code in.Access the /stream_wav endpoint in your browser or with a tool like curl:[CODE_BLOCK_3]This will save the streamed .wav files into a single combined.wav file. If you're using this for a real application, you might need to add some WAV header management, especially if you want the combined file to be playable. Otherwise, it would just be a concatenation of the individual WAV file bytes.Remember, the approach above doesn't modify or adjust WAV headers. It just sends raw WAV files one after another. This might be okay if you're just archiving or moving data, but if you want the result to be a single, playable WAV file, you'd need to adjust headers accordingly.

ListOfCode.Content: pip install fastapi uvicorn
uvicorn your_filename:app --reload
curl http://127.0.0.1:8000/stream_wav -o combined.wav

Conversation.Prompt: What do you mean by "you'd need to adjust headers accordingly"
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTWAV files follow the RIFF (Resource Interchange File Format) structure. The header of a WAV file contains metadata about the file, such as its format, number of channels, sample rate, byte rate, block align, bits per sample, and more.When WAV files are concatenated naively (just putting one after the other), you end up with the headers of the second and subsequent files in the middle of the resulting file. This is usually not what you want and can lead to issues when trying to play the file. In essence, the resulting file won't be a valid WAV file.To concatenate WAV files properly and end up with a valid, playable WAV file, you would need to:Strip the headers from the second and subsequent files.Adjust the header of the first file to reflect the combined length and (possibly) other metadata changes.Concatenate the raw audio data.If you're considering concatenating WAV files to form a continuous audio stream, here's a rough idea:Read the header from the first WAV file and extract the necessary metadata. This includes the size field, which you'll need to adjust.For each subsequent WAV file, skip its header and only read the audio data.Update the size fields in the header of the first file to account for the total size of the concatenated audio data.Write out the adjusted header from the first file followed by the audio data from all files.There are libraries and tools designed to handle WAV and other audio formats that can assist with this, such as pydub:[CODE_BLOCK_0]With pydub, the WAV headers are handled automatically when you load, concatenate, and export audio.

ListOfCode.Content:
from pydub import AudioSegment

# Load the first WAV file
combined = AudioSegment.from_wav("file1.wav")

# Concatenate other WAV files
other_files = ["file2.wav", "file3.wav"]  # Add as many as needed
for file in other_files:
    sound = AudioSegment.from_wav(file)
    combined += sound

# Export the combined audio
combined.export("combined.wav", format="wav")

Conversation.Prompt: Can you make typescript interfaces?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, I can help you with TypeScript interfaces. TypeScript is a statically typed superset of JavaScript that adds static typing capabilities to the language. Interfaces in TypeScript are used to define the structure and shape of objects, specifying the names and types of properties and methods that an object should have.Here's an example of how you can create TypeScript interfaces:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the example above, we defined an interface called Person with three properties: name, age, and email. The name property is of type string, the age property is of type number, and the email property is optional (? denotes optional properties).We then created an object person that conforms to the Person interface. We assigned values to the name and age properties. Since the email property is optional, we omitted it in this case.You can also use interfaces to define the structure of functions:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In this example, we defined an interface called MathFunction that describes a function with two parameters of type number and a return type of number. We then created a function add that conforms to this interface and performs addition.Interfaces in TypeScript are powerful tools for creating well-defined object structures and ensuring type safety. You can use them to enforce consistent shapes and types across your codebase, making it easier to catch errors and maintain your code.

Conversation.Prompt: Ok yeah forget all that, I am looking for the optimal way to set up an array of objects. I'd like for each object to have either a single variable, isHr: boolean and no other variables, or I'd like for the object to have a series of optional variables, var1: number, var2: string, var3: boolean, but this second object must not contain an isHr: boolean variable. What's the best way to set this up?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo set up an array of objects with the requirements you mentioned, you can define a union type for the objects and use TypeScript's type assertions to enforce the structure.Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, we defined two types: ObjectWithHr represents an object with only the isHr property of type boolean, and ObjectWithVariables represents an object with optional properties var1, var2, and var3.Then, we defined a union type MyObject that represents either an object with isHr or an object with the optional variables. This ensures that an object can have either the isHr property or the optional properties, but not both.Finally, we created an array objects of type MyObject[] that can hold objects conforming to the defined structure. You can add objects with either the isHr property or the optional variables to this array.Using this approach, TypeScript will provide type checking and prevent you from adding objects that violate the defined structure.

Conversation.Prompt: Would the type checking allow the array to include an object such as { isHr: true, var1: 5 }?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTNo, the type checking in TypeScript would prevent an object like { isHr: true, var1: 5 } from being included in the array because it violates the defined structure.In the example I provided, the MyObject type is a union of ObjectWithHr and ObjectWithVariables, which means that an object must conform to one of those types, but not both simultaneously. An object cannot have properties from both ObjectWithHr and ObjectWithVariables at the same time.If you try to add an object like { isHr: true, var1: 5 } to the array, TypeScript will raise a type error because it does not conform to either ObjectWithHr or ObjectWithVariables independently. It has both the isHr property and the var1 property, which is not allowed by the defined structure.The type checking ensures that objects in the array adhere to one of the defined structures, preventing mixing incompatible properties in the same object.

Conversation.Prompt: I copied your code exactly as above and typescript is allowing me to pass the object with isHr and var1. Is it possible I have some typescript setting that is allowing this? Or are you incorrect in your understanding of typescript?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTI apologize for the confusion caused by my previous response. You are correct, TypeScript does allow the object { isHr: true, var1: 5 } to be passed in the example I provided. I made an oversight in my explanation.If you want to enforce stricter type checking to disallow objects with both isHr and the optional variables, you can use TypeScript's discriminated unions. Discriminated unions are a way to define a common property that can be used to determine the specific shape of an object within a union.Here's an updated example using discriminated unions:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this updated example, I added a type property to both ObjectWithHr and ObjectWithVariables. The type property acts as a discriminant, allowing TypeScript to differentiate between the two types.Now, if you try to add an object with both isHr and the optional variables, such as { type: 'hr', isHr: true, var1: 5 }, TypeScript will raise a type error because it violates the discriminated union's structure.I apologize for the confusion caused by my previous response, and I appreciate you bringing it to my attention.

Conversation.Prompt: I don't like the inclusion of a type property. Is there a simpler way to do this with the never type?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTCertainly! You can use the never type along with conditional types to achieve a similar effect without introducing a separate type property. Here's an updated example using the never type:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this updated example, I defined ObjectWithHr to have the isHr property and the optional properties (var1, var2, and var3) with a type of never. The never type represents a type that should never occur.Conversely, in ObjectWithVariables, I set isHr to have the never type, which means it should never be present, while the optional properties (var1, var2, and var3) are allowed.By using the never type in this way, you achieve a similar effect of disallowing objects with both isHr and the optional variables. If you try to add an object like { isHr: true, var1: 5 } to the array, TypeScript will raise a type error.This approach simplifies the structure without introducing an additional property like type to discriminate between the object types.

Conversation.Prompt:
音声合成の誤読がある場合、なんらかの修正する必要があります。
直接テキスト欄を書き換えるとか、辞書登録をするとか、読み変更するとか。
頻繁に出てくる単語であれば辞書登録が最適解ですが、1回しか出てこない場合はだいたいテキストを書き換えると思います。
ただテキストを書き換えてしまうと、字幕を表示する場合に動画作成ソフト側でもう一度書き換える必要があるので不便です。

字幕（テキスト書き出し内容）をそのままにして読みだけを変えられると便利そうです。
テキスト欄に{漢字|かんじ}とあった場合、音声合成では「漢字」が無視され、字幕では「かんじ」が無視されるようになれば完了です。

このような実装を、読み部分を残すskipWritingPartと、漢字部分を残すskipReadingPart関数としてTypeScriptで書いてください。
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPT以下に、指定された要件に基づいてskipWritingPartとskipReadingPart関数をTypeScriptで実装した例を示します。この実装では、テキスト内の特定のパターン（{漢字|かんじ}）を探し、それぞれの関数で異なる部分をスキップします。[CODE_BLOCK_0]このコードを実行すると、以下のような出力が得られます：[CODE_BLOCK_1]このように、skipReadingPart関数はテキスト内の{漢字|かんじ}パターンを探し、漢字部分だけを残します。一方、skipWritingPart関数は同じパターンを探し、かんじ部分だけを残します。

ListOfCode.Content:
Original Text:  これはテストです。{漢字|かんじ}の部分は読み替えられます。
Reading Part:  これはテストです。漢字の部分は読み替えられます。
Writing Part:  これはテストです。かんじの部分は読み替えられます。

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe way you are handling this is generally correct and idiomatic. The never type is used to ensure that all cases are handled and that new cases aren't forgotten. The technique is called Exhaustiveness checking in TypeScript.However, instead of using an inline arrow function, you could use a helper function to assert exhaustiveness. This would improve readability and remove the necessity for eslint disabling:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the assertNever function, we are throwing an error if an unexpected value is encountered. This could be useful during development because it would crash your application at the source of the problem if you forget to add a case when extending your provider. Of course, the thrown error would be a problem in a production application, so you need to make sure that your switch is exhaustive during testing and before deployment.

Author: LuchoTurtle
Title: [PR] Using cid with entry upload metadata
Body: fixes #62 This changes how the `CID` is created with the entry data. It uses the entry's name, the relative path, the size and the content type to try and generate a `CID` closest to the file's contents with its metadata. Unfortunately, we cannot use the file's contents to create a `CID` because, with this method (as described in the [LiveView's documentation](https://hexdocs.pm/phoenix_live_view/uploads.html), which is _different from the [regular file upload-way that is used in the API](https://hexdocs.pm/phoenix/file_uploads.html)_) we do not have access to the file's contents. I've tried doing this in both LiveView and also in the `js` client but there is no information about where the File is stored (it's not stored anywhere). I've also tried checking if there's a discernable way of seeing the contents of the file in the entry that is used in the Javascript client (e.g. check the screenshot below) So the closest we can do with the LiveView format is to use its metadata and create the `CID` off of that.

Conversation.Prompt: Write a script to upload an image to AWS S3 using the Elixir programming language
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTSure! Here's an example script to upload an image to AWS S3 using the Elixir programming language and the ex_aws library:[CODE_BLOCK_0]To use this script, you'll need to add the ex_aws dependency to your mix.exs file:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Then, run mix deps.get to fetch the dependencies.To upload an image, you can call the upload_image/3 function from the S3Uploader module, providing the bucket name, file path, and key as arguments:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Make sure to replace "your-bucket-name" with the actual name of your S3 bucket, "/path/to/image.jpg" with the path to the image file you want to upload, and "images/my-image.jpg" with the desired key under which the image will be stored in the S3 bucket.Note: Ensure that you have set up the necessary AWS credentials in your environment variables or other appropriate credential provider methods supported by ex_aws.

ListOfCode.Content:
defmodule S3Uploader do
  @moduledoc """
  A module for uploading images to AWS S3.
  """

  def upload_image(bucket, file_path, key) do
    {:ok, credentials} = ExAws.Credentials.from_env()

    # Configure ExAws with your AWS credentials
    ExAws.Config.put_credential_provider(:default, credentials)

    # Configure ExAws with your desired AWS region
    ExAws.Config.put_region(:default, "us-east-1")  # Replace with your desired region

    {:ok, binary} = File.read(file_path)

    {:ok, _} = ExAws.S3.upload(bucket, key, binary)

    IO.puts "Image uploaded successfully!"
  end
end

defp deps do
  [
    {:ex_aws, "~> 2.1"},
    {:hackney, "~> 1.15"},
    {:poison, "~> 4.0"}
  ]
end

Conversation.Prompt: is it possible to write a validation code in php which checks whether uploaded file size is under 1MB?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, it is possible to write a validation code in PHP to check whether an uploaded file size is under 1MB. Here's an example code snippet that demonstrates how you can achieve this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this code, we first check if the form was submitted using the $_SERVER["REQUEST_METHOD"] variable. If it was a POST request, we access the uploaded file information using $_FILES["fileUpload"].We check if there are no errors during the file upload using the UPLOAD_ERR_OK constant. Then, we retrieve the file size using $file["size"]. We compare the file size to the maximum allowed size (1MB in this case) and display an appropriate message based on the result.Remember to adjust the maxSize variable according to your specific requirements if you want to allow a different maximum file size.Note: It's important to consider additional security measures when dealing with file uploads, such as validating file types, using file extensions, and preventing code execution from uploaded files.

ListOfCode.Content:
<?php
// Assuming you have a file upload form with the input name "fileUpload"

if ($_SERVER["REQUEST_METHOD"] == "POST") {
    $file = $_FILES["fileUpload"];

    // Check if there are no errors during file upload
    if ($file["error"] == UPLOAD_ERR_OK) {
        // Check the file size
        $fileSize = $file["size"]; // Size in bytes

        $maxSize = 1048576; // 1MB in bytes

        if ($fileSize <= $maxSize) {
            // File size is within the limit
            // Proceed with further processing or storing the file
            echo "File uploaded successfully.";
        } else {
            // File size exceeds the limit
            echo "File size should be under 1MB.";
        }
    } else {
        // Error occurred during file upload
        echo "Error uploading file.";
    }
}
?>

The 'fileUpload' field is defined as required and file type, and the max rule is used to limit the file size to 1024 kilobytes (1MB).If the validation fails, the code redirects back with the validation errors. Otherwise, you can proceed with further processing or storing the file. Access the uploaded file using $request->file('fileUpload') and perform the necessary operations.Remember to adjust the 'max' rule parameter according to your specific requirements if you want to allow a different maximum file size.It's recommended to follow Laravel's file upload security best practices as well, such as validating file types and using storage mechanisms to store the uploaded files securely.

ListOfCode.Content:
<?php
use Illuminate\Http\Request;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Validator;

// Assuming you have a file upload form with the input name "fileUpload"

public function uploadFile(Request $request)
{
    $validator = Validator::make($request->all(), [
        'fileUpload' => 'required|file|max:1024', // Max file size in kilobytes (1MB = 1024KB)
    ]);

    if ($validator->fails()) {
        // Validation failed
        return redirect()->back()->withErrors($validator);
    }

    // File size is within the limit
    // Proceed with further processing or storing the file
    // Access the uploaded file using $request->file('fileUpload')
    // e.g., $request->file('fileUpload')->store('path-to-store');

    return redirect()->back()->with('success', 'File uploaded successfully.');
}
?>

Conversation.Prompt: which is better change maximum file size in dockerfile or create a javascript method which rejects files over maximum file size
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTBoth approaches have their advantages and considerations. Let's look at each approach:Changing maximum file size in Dockerfile:This approach involves adjusting the maximum file size at the server level using the Dockerfile or server configuration.It ensures that the file size limit is enforced consistently across the application.The limitation is set on the server, so the user cannot bypass it even if they modify or disable JavaScript on the client-side.However, it may not provide immediate feedback to the user, as the file is uploaded to the server before validation occurs. The user may have to wait for the server response to know if the file exceeds the limit.Creating a JavaScript method to reject files over the maximum file size:This approach involves implementing client-side validation using JavaScript to check the file size before submitting the form.It provides immediate feedback to the user, as they can be informed right away if the file exceeds the size limit.It reduces unnecessary server requests and bandwidth, as the validation occurs on the client-side.However, client-side validation can be bypassed or modified by knowledgeable users, so server-side validation is still necessary for security.Additionally, relying solely on client-side validation may not be sufficient if the application is used in environments where JavaScript may be disabled or not supported.Ideally, it is recommended to implement both server-side and client-side validation to ensure maximum security and user experience. By having server-side validation, you guarantee that the file size limit is enforced, regardless of client-side manipulation. Adding client-side validation provides a better user experience by providing immediate feedback to the user without the need for a server roundtrip.

Conversation.Prompt: i am trying to access localhost in laravel project but get rejected
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIf you are experiencing connection issues when trying to access the localhost in a Laravel project, there could be several reasons for the rejection. Here are a few troubleshooting steps you can try:Check your server configuration: Ensure that your local development server (e.g., Apache, Nginx) is running correctly and listening on the correct port (usually port 80 or 8000).Verify the project's URL: Make sure you are accessing the correct URL in your browser. By default, Laravel projects are accessed via http://localhost or http://127.0.0.1.Check firewall or antivirus settings: Temporarily disable any firewall or antivirus software that might be blocking the connection to the localhost. This step is particularly relevant if you recently installed or updated security software on your system.Clear browser cache and cookies: Sometimes, cached data or cookies can interfere with the connection. Clear your browser's cache and cookies or try accessing the application using a different browser.Verify Laravel's server configuration: Check the config folder within your Laravel project for any specific server-related configurations, such as the .env file or the config/app.php file. Ensure that the APP_URL variable is correctly set to http://localhost or http://127.0.0.1.Check your hosts file: Ensure that your hosts file (located at /etc/hosts on Unix-based systems or C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts on Windows) does not have any custom entries that could be causing conflicts. The file should typically include a line like 127.0.0.1 localhost.Restart your development server: Try stopping and restarting your local development server to ensure that any recent changes or configurations are properly applied.If you have followed these steps and are still experiencing issues, it may be helpful to provide more specific details about the error message or behavior you are encountering in order to receive more targeted assistance.

Conversation.Prompt: what is the point of using DATE(date).
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe DATE() function in the SQL query is used to extract the date part from the date column. It ensures that only the date portion is selected and included in the result.In some cases, the date column may store values that include both the date and time components. By using DATE(date), you extract only the date part from the column value, effectively removing the time portion.For example, if your date column has values like '2023-06-11 12:34:56', using DATE(date) will convert it to '2023-06-11'. This can be useful when you want to group the records by date and perform operations based on the date alone, disregarding the time.In the context of the code you provided, DATE(date) is used in conjunction with the groupBy() method to group the records by date. It ensures that the sum of hour is calculated and grouped based on the date part only.If your date column already contains values with only the date part and doesn't include time information, you can omit the DATE() function. However, if the date column does include time information and you want to work with the date part only, using DATE(date) ensures consistent and accurate grouping based on the date.

This configuration ensures that Nginx will accept file uploads or POST requests with a size of up to 2GB.Additionally, the configuration includes common security headers such as X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection, and X-Content-Type-Options to enhance security.The server block listens on port 80 and points to the /work/web/public directory as the root of the server.The configuration handles various common scenarios, including serving index.html, index.htm, and index.php files, handling 404 errors by directing to index.php, and ignoring access and error logging for /favicon.ico and /robots.txt files.PHP files are processed using FastCGI with fastcgi_pass pointing to app:9000, assuming a separate PHP-FPM service is running on the same network.Lastly, the configuration denies access to any files or directories starting with a dot (.), except for those starting with .well-known.Overall, this configuration allows large file uploads, sets necessary security headers, and handles common scenarios for a web application running on Nginx with PHP-FPM.

Conversation.Prompt: as best practise, should you import with .js sufix
Conversation.Answer:
ChatGPTIn JavaScript, whether to include the .js suffix when importing modules depends on the specific syntax and context of your code. Here are some guidelines:Importing ES6 Modules (recommended):
If you are using ES6 module syntax to import modules, you should not include the .js suffix. Here's how you typically import modules in ES6:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this case, modulePath should point to the JavaScript module file (without the .js extension). The browser or Node.js environment will automatically look for the module and append .js if necessary.Importing CommonJS Modules (Node.js):
In Node.js, when using CommonJS modules (e.g., require), you don't include the .js extension either. Node.js will resolve and load the module correctly. For example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Importing External Libraries:
When importing third-party libraries or packages, you usually specify the module name without the .js extension. For example:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Importing Other File Types:
If you are importing non-JavaScript files, such as JSON, CSS, or other assets, you might need to include the file extension. For instance:[CODE_BLOCK_3]In summary, including the .js suffix when importing JavaScript modules is generally unnecessary and not recommended in modern JavaScript development, especially when using ES6 module syntax. However, when dealing with non-JavaScript files, you should include the appropriate file extension. Always follow the guidelines and conventions of the module system you are using (e.g., ES6, CommonJS) and the tools or environments (browser, Node.js) you are working with.

const moduleName = require('./modulePath');
import axios from 'axios'; // No '.js' extension

import './styles.css';

Author: Nubebuster
Title: Interaction and api updates
Body:
This branch contains some bug fixes and code improvements.
Most notable changes:

- RSModel interaction now no longer tries to click points that are not in collision with the polygons of the model. This means the success rate for clicking a model is drastically increased. It now gets a random polygon and finds a point within that to click on.
- Added withdrawAll function to Bank
- Added hasAction to RSObject

### Bugs found
See Inventory.java:175 the condition is always true. Author: @Fire-Swan
See RSModel.java:343 this loop always returns with n=0. Author(s): @PhobicHD and/or @GigiaJ

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe getPointNearCenter method is trying to find a point near the center of a set of polygons. It does this by first finding the bounding rectangle of all the points of the polygons. Then it computes the center of that rectangle (which may not be on any of the polygons). Finally, it generates a point based on a gaussian distribution with the center as the mean and a third of the width and height as the standard deviation.However, the Gaussian (or normal) distribution is not restricted to a specific range - it can theoretically generate any number from negative infinity to positive infinity. While the numbers it generates are more likely to be close to the mean, there's still a chance they could be beyond the minimum and maximum coordinates of the polygons, which means the point it generates might not land on the polygons at all.To fix this, you might want to generate a point that is definitely within one of the polygons. You could do this by picking a random polygon and then a random point within that polygon. For simplicity, let's assume that these polygons are triangles. Then you can generate a random point within a triangle using barycentric coordinates:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This function first chooses a random triangle from the set of triangles. Then it generates two random numbers between 0 and 1. These numbers are used as barycentric coordinates to generate a point that is guaranteed to be within the chosen triangle.

ChatGPTThe author's question about the conditional statement if (c >= 0 && c < 4 && r >= 0 && r < 7) being always true is valid. It's a condition to check if the calculated c and r values fall within an expected range. These values represent column and row in an inventory with maximum of 4 columns and 7 rows, respectively.The problem is the way these indices are calculated. They are computed from the loop index index and should map to a position in a 4 columns x 7 rows grid, which matches the inventory layout of many games. If leftToRight is true, it loops through the grid left to right, top to bottom (more natural way). If it is false, it loops through the grid top to bottom, left to right.However, these calculations are based on the size of inventory (28 slots in a 4x7 grid), which means c and r should always be within their respective bounds. That's why the condition if (c >= 0 && c < 4 && r >= 0 && r < 7) is always true.This condition seems redundant and can be removed. The adjusted part of the code could be as follows:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this code, the condition has been removed and now we directly get the id from the inventory and proceed with the logic to drop items not included in the exception list. The assumption is that inventory is correctly initialized and the indices c and r always fall within the bounds of the inventory array.

ChatGPTThe issue here is that there is a return statement inside the inner loop, so the method returns on the first iteration, no matter what. This means it will always return the first point of the first triangle within the range.If you want to get all the points in the triangles within a specified range, you need to store them in a collection like a List, and return that instead of just a single point. However, if you just want to get the first point that meets a certain condition, then the condition should be specified in an if statement within the inner loop.Without knowing the exact purpose of this function, it's hard to suggest a precise fix, but here's a sample adjustment assuming you want to collect all points in the triangles within the specified range:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This version of the function will return a list of points from all triangles in the specified range. If there are no triangles within the range, it will return an empty list. It's generally better to return an empty list rather than null to avoid NullPointerExceptions.

Conversation.Prompt: in python, how get the result of exec()
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn Python, the exec() function is used to execute dynamically created program, which is either a string or object code. If it is a string, the string is parsed as a suite of Python statements which is then executed. If it is an object code, it is simply executed.The exec() function does not return any value, hence you can't directly get a result from it like you would from a function that returns a value.However, the exec() function optionally takes a globals and locals parameter (both must be dictionaries), which it uses for global and local variables during execution. If you want to get a result from exec, you can pass a dictionary for locals, execute an assignment statement, and then retrieve the result from the locals dictionary.Here is a small example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the code to be executed is a string that declares two variables a and b and a third variable result which is the sum of a and b. After executing this code with exec, the locals_ dictionary is updated with the values of a, b, and result, and you can get the value of result by looking it up in the dictionary.Please note, using exec() can potentially make your code vulnerable to code injection if you are executing code that comes from an untrusted source or includes user inputs. It is generally best to avoid using exec() if possible.

ListOfCode.Content:
code = """
a = 1
b = 2
result = a + b
"""

locals_ = {}
exec(code, {}, locals_)
print(locals_['result'])  # Output: 3

Author: JackuB
Title: Run E2E tests in containers
Body:
![mfw](https://github.com/CodeIntelligenceTesting/cifuzz/assets/1788727/21db6108-11a4-4727-90de-ce03b3c4530f)

- We want to E2E test our new cifuzz container commands and those rely on Docker socket being available (*for now! :partyparrot:). To make this work, we need a working Docker Engine/Socket. This is possible to achieve on GitHub Actions runners.
- With this PR, every single E2E test case runs in its own container - preventing test cross-pollination and hopefully enabling more parallelisation options. Seeing how genhtml (and similar issues) threw off our tests and a release pipelines, I’d say we should strive for better test environment isolation and reproducibility. Working with [cached] and predictable containers could be a way for us to achieve that.
- We also want to test more and more complex setups and environments and being able to containerize sample projects, their dependencies and configuration should allow us to greatly extend our E2E coverage.

This PR only updated the E2E Runner, no changes to the tests were needed. Code changes are not that major, as the current E2E structure was kept, but I moved some of the logic into separate functions and files for brevity.

But this PR is also dropping testing pipeline for macOS (we can introduce a limited (--short?) version of E2E verification just for macOS in a following PRs).

This PR is also removing release pipeline testing, as we should consider a slightly different approach. And the current one is not being used beyond a PoC.

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe code you provided is a valid and functional way to remove empty strings from a slice of strings. It iterates through the input slice and only appends non-empty strings to a new result slice, which is then returned.While this code works correctly, there are alternative approaches to achieve the same result with potentially better performance or more concise syntax. Here are a couple of alternatives:In-place modification of the input slice:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This version modifies the input slice in place, avoiding the need to create a new slice and potentially reducing memory allocation overhead. It uses an additional index n to keep track of the non-empty strings, and after the loop, it returns a sub-slice of the original slice containing only the non-empty strings.Using a slice comprehension (supported from Go 1.18 onwards):[CODE_BLOCK_1]The Go programming language introduced slice comprehensions in version 1.18, which allows for a more concise way of creating slices. The above code creates a new slice r containing only the non-empty strings from the original slice s. Note that this approach requires Go 1.18 or later.Overall, the original code you provided is functional and straightforward. However, the alternatives provided above may offer performance improvements or a more concise syntax in certain situations. Choose the one that best fits your needs and the version of Go you are using.

Author: t-hamano
Title: Top Toolbar: Prevent the focus outline of the button from being cut off
Body:
## What?
This PR prevents the focus outline of the device preview button from cutting off when the top toolbar is enabled.

### Site Editor

#### Before

![site-editor-before](https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/assets/54422211/5934072a-d095-43d3-a8d2-fe65d9edb10a)

#### After

![site-editor-after](https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/assets/54422211/afbf8d88-8a25-4a09-8917-15c2f26c75b4)

### Post Editor

#### Before

![post-editor-before](https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/assets/54422211/e28b1960-da31-4a0e-89a4-eb77ab9fc65b)

#### After

![post-editor-after](https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/assets/54422211/399ad873-508b-4f68-945a-ca8250249186)

## Why?

### Site Editor

The fixed toolbar dynamically has its own width, minus the total width of the other UI in the header, margins, etc. However, when the first button (device preview button) in the right header is focused, the outline has a width of 2px, so it is hidden under the top toolbar.

### Post Editor

The Post Editor is a little more complicated. In #47177, the sidebar now always has the scrollbar to prevent sidebar UI shifting. At the same time, `scrollbar-gutter: stable;` was added to align the header icons with the sidebar. This will push the right-hand header to the left by the width of the scrollbar. As a result, even if the top toolbar has the correct width, it will overlap by the width of this scrollbar.

## How?

### Site Editor

When calculating the fixed toolbar width, I took the outline into account and subtracted 2px.

### Post Editor

Removed `scrollbar-gutter:stable` from the right header. This causes problems in Windows OS and Mac OS (where scrollbars are always set to appear), where the scrollbar has a physical width that prevents the header and sidebar icons from aligning.

However, this approach also has the effect of removing unnecessary spacing on the right side of the header when the sidebar is not displayed.

So far I haven't found an approach that would ideally solve everything, so if anyone has any ideas, I'd love to hear them.

## Testing Instructions

- Enable top toolbar.
- Select a block.
- Focus the device preview button.
- Make sure the outline is not cut off.
- Check in both the Post Editor and the Site Editor.

Note: I've noticed an issue with the widget editor where the top toolbar obscures the header on the right. I would like to address this issue in another PR.

![widget-editor](https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/assets/54422211/eb862f00-61ba-46b1-b8d1-030d1e0ff129)

Conversation.Prompt: How to get the width of the scrollbar with JavaScript, even when the scrollbar is not displayed in the browser
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo get the width of the scrollbar with JavaScript, even when the scrollbar is not displayed in the browser, you can follow these steps:Create a hidden element that has an overflow property set to scroll. This will force the scrollbar to appear, even if the content doesn't overflow.Measure the width of the scrollbar by calculating the difference in width between the container's client width and its scroll width.Remove the hidden element from the DOM if you no longer need it.Here's an example of how you can do this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, we create a hidden div with the class scrollbar-measure and set its overflow property to scroll. We then calculate the scrollbar width by subtracting the client width from the offset width of this element. Finally, we remove the scrollbar-measure element from the DOM.This approach should give you the scrollbar width even when the scrollbar is not displayed in the browser.

Author: latonv
Title: WEBDEV-6167 Make tiles show creator matching letter filter, if one is applied
Body:
Currently, search results in grid view & compact list view only show the first creator when there are multiple creators for the item. However, the “initial letter” filters (available when sorting by creator) match _any_ of the creators in the list, not just the first. So it can look strange when such a filter is applied, but results still show a creator that doesn’t match the filter.

This PR makes search results with multiple creators adjust to show the first _matching_ creator on the tile, rather than the first overall.

Conversation.Prompt:
```js
      const firstLetter = this.selectedCreatorFilter;
      displayedCreator =
        this.model.creators.find(creator =>
          creator.toUpperCase().startsWith(firstLetter)
        ) ?? displayedCreator; // Fall back to the original if needed
```


This has a bug, where "Émile" is not selected as the displayed creator when "E" is the selected filter letter.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe problem seems to be related to the toUpperCase() method and the handling of diacritical marks. JavaScript's toUpperCase() method doesn't consider diacritical marks, so when you transform "Émile" to uppercase, you get "ÉMILE", not "EMILE". As a result, when you check if "ÉMILE".startsWith("E"), you get false.To solve this problem, you can normalize the string to remove diacritical marks using the normalize() method with the "NFD" form, which splits an accented letter into the ASCII letter and a separate diacritic. You can then remove the diacritics using a regular expression that matches all non-ASCII characters. Here's how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this code, normalize("NFD") splits each accented character into its ASCII base and a diacritic, then replace(/[\u0300-\u036f]/g, "") removes the diacritics (which are in the Unicode range 0300-036F). The toUpperCase() and startsWith(firstLetter) work as before.Note that this will change the matching behavior for all names, not just names starting with "É". If you want to maintain the original behavior for names starting with ASCII characters, you would need to add a separate condition for that case.

Author: bsmth
Title: chore(CI): disable prettier check on pull requests

Disabling the Prettier check on pull requests due to some speedbumps in reviewing

### Motivation

We have some contributors hitting this which is causing some friction, particularly on PRs opened from GitHub's UI. There is no option to [downgrade the errors to warnings](https://prettier.io/docs/en/cli.html#exit-codes) that I'm aware of.

### Additional details

We <strike>may want to instead</strike> already have this scheduled auto fix PR run Prettier instead:

https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/.github/workflows/markdown-lint-fix.yml#L30 

i.e.:

```yaml
      - name: Lint markdown files
        run: |
          yarn fix:md
          yarn fix:fm
```

Conversation.Prompt: How can I implement a health check in Docker Compose for Keycloak 21?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo implement a health check for Keycloak 21 in Docker Compose, you can use the healthcheck configuration option available in Docker Compose version 2.1 or higher. The healthcheck option allows you to define a command or script that Docker will periodically run to check the health of a container.Here's an example of how you can implement a health check for Keycloak 21 in Docker Compose:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example:We define a service named keycloak.We specify the Keycloak Docker image (jboss/keycloak:11.0.0 in this case).We map the container's port 8080 to the host's port 8080 to access Keycloak.We define the healthcheck configuration block for the keycloak service.In the test field, we specify the command ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:8080/auth/realms/master"]. This command uses curl to make an HTTP request to Keycloak's /auth/realms/master endpoint. The -f flag ensures that curl returns a non-zero exit code if the request fails.We set the interval to 30s, indicating that Docker should run the health check every 30 seconds.We set the timeout to 10s, specifying the maximum time Docker waits for the health check command to complete.We set the retries to 5, which means Docker will attempt the health check command up to 5 times before considering the container unhealthy.With this configuration, Docker will periodically run the curl command to check the health of the Keycloak container. If the command fails (returns a non-zero exit code) or exceeds the specified timeout, Docker will consider the container unhealthy.

ListOfCode.Content:
version: '3.8'
services:
  keycloak:
    image: jboss/keycloak:11.0.0
    ports:
      - 8080:8080
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:8080/auth/realms/master"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 5

Author: WickyNilliams
Title: fix(#147): improve handling of anyOf
Body:
fixes #147

as far as i can tell, this is closer to the real behavior of json-schema, from which openapi inherits `anyOf`.

in my testing, given two object types `A` and `B`, anyOf these is equivalent to:

```ts
z.union([A.passthrough(), B.passthrough()])
```

that is, `anyOf` is satisfied if any of the types match, and it stops validating after that allowing any additional properties. hence, `passthrough`

primitive types are special cased since passthrough does not make sense for them. resulting in:

```ts
z.union([APrimitiveType, AnObjectType.passthrough()])
```

i've prepared a small playground for experimenting with json-schema behavior, in case it's useful for validating the logic here https://stackblitz.com/edit/json-schema-anyof-test?file=index.tsx

Conversation.Prompt: what's the difference between openapi oneOf vs anyOf ?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn OpenAPI, oneOf and anyOf are JSON Schema keywords used to define the validation rules for request or response payloads. They are used to specify alternative schemas that a given value must conform to.Here's the difference between oneOf and anyOf:oneOf: It specifies that a value must match exactly one of the provided schemas. In other words, the value must adhere to the constraints of exactly one of the defined schemas. If a value matches multiple schemas, it would be considered invalid. It enforces a mutually exclusive choice.Example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the above example, the value must either be a string with a maximum length of 5 or a number greater than or equal to 10.anyOf: It specifies that a value must match at least one of the provided schemas. The value can conform to any of the defined schemas, allowing for multiple valid options. If a value matches multiple schemas, it is considered valid.Example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In the above example, the value can be a string with a maximum length of 5 or a number greater than or equal to 10. It can satisfy either condition.To summarize, oneOf enforces a single, exclusive choice among the provided schemas, while anyOf allows for multiple valid options by matching any of the provided schemas.

ListOfCode.Content:
oneOf:
  - type: string
    maxLength: 5
  - type: number
    minimum: 10

anyOf:
  - type: string
    maxLength: 5
  - type: number
    minimum: 10

Conversation.Prompt: Using c++, how can I convert a timestamp from the 'Europe/Amsterdam' that uses a YYMMDDhhmmss format, to a Unix timestamp?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo convert a timestamp in the format YYMMDDhhmmss from the 'Europe/Amsterdam' timezone to a Unix timestamp in C++, you can use the following steps:Parse the input timestamp string and extract its components (year, month, day, hour, minute, second).Create a tm structure that represents the timestamp in the local time zone ('Europe/Amsterdam'). You can use the strptime() function to parse the input string and fill the tm structure with its components. The strptime() function requires a format string that specifies the format of the input string, which in this case is "%y%m%d%H%M%S".Convert the tm structure to a Unix timestamp by calling the mktime() function. This function takes a pointer to a tm structure and returns the corresponding Unix timestamp, which is the number of seconds since the Unix epoch (January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 UTC).Here's some sample C++ code that implements these steps:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Note that this code assumes that the local time zone is set to 'Europe/Amsterdam'. If your system is set to a different time zone, you may need to adjust the code accordingly.

Conversation.Prompt: Now, suppose the time is ambiguous, e.g. I'm the 2 am - 3 am local time.window on a day that is on a DST to non-DST switch; how can I disambiguate such a time?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTWhen a time is ambiguous due to a Daylight Saving Time (DST) transition, it is important to disambiguate it to obtain a correct Unix timestamp. In the case of the 'Europe/Amsterdam' timezone, there is a DST transition on the last Sunday of March at 2:00 AM, when the clock is set forward by one hour, and another transition on the last Sunday of October at 3:00 AM, when the clock is set back by one hour. This means that any time between 2:00 AM and 3:00 AM on the day of the transition occurs twice: once during DST and once during standard time.To disambiguate such a time, you can use the tm_isdst field of the tm structure, which indicates whether the time is in DST or standard time. This field can be set to -1 to indicate that the mktime() function should determine whether DST is in effect for the specified time. If the tm_isdst field is set to 0 or 1, the mktime() function will use the specified DST flag, regardless of whether DST is actually in effect.Here's an updated version of the code that disambiguates an ambiguous time by checking whether DST is in effect for that time:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this updated code, we set the tm_isdst field to -1 before calling mktime(), which tells the function to determine the DST flag for the specified time. After calling mktime(), the tm_isdst field is updated with the DST flag that was used to convert the time to a Unix timestamp. This flag can be used to determine whether the time is in DST or standard time.

Conversation.Prompt:
In some situations, the time.formatbis actually YYMMDDhhmmssX, where X='S' means DST and X='W'  means non-DST. How can I use this info to convert the timestamp properly? Also, the devices where the c++ code runs may be connected to a tome source where, the X element ulis NOT present, ie only the YYMMDdhhmmss format is sent over the connection. How should I detect this, and how disambiguate ambigiuous time stamps  where the code detects the X element is NOT present? 
Additional info: timestamps arrive typically multiple times per minute (so, previous timestamps may help in detecting whether it's the first or second time a time between 2 and 3 am occcur). Moreover, the devices are usially not installed between 2 am and 3 am. The device is an ESP32 device that is completely  off between measurements, so remembering requires storing any info from previous measurement persistently  preferably nvs on ESP32 nmeasurements that should be stores betweennmeasurements s
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIf the timestamp format can include an additional X character that indicates whether the time is in DST or standard time, you can use this information to correctly convert the timestamp to a Unix timestamp. The X character can have two possible values: S for DST and W for standard time.Here's an updated version of the code that takes into account the X character in the timestamp string:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this updated code, we first parse the timestamp string without the X character by using a substring of the first 14 characters. We then check if the X character is present in the timestamp string. If it is, we set the DST flag based on the value of the X character. If the X character is 'S', we set the DST flag to 1 (DST is in effect). If the X character is 'W', we set the DST flag to 0 (DST is not in effect). If the X character is not present in the timestamp string, we set the DST flag to -1 to let mktime() determine the DST flag.To disambiguate an ambiguous timestamp where the X character is not present in the timestamp string, you can use the following approach:Keep track of the most recent timestamp that was received before the current timestamp.If the current timestamp occurs between 2:00 AM and 3:00 AM and the previous timestamp occurred before the DST transition time (2:00 AM), assume that the current timestamp is in standard time. If the previous timestamp occurred after the DST transition time (3:00 AM), assume that the current timestamp is in DST.If the current timestamp occurs between 2:00 AM and 3:00 AM and the previous timestamp occurred during the hour that occurs twice due to the DST transition, use the DST flag in the previous timestamp to disambiguate the current timestamp.If none of the above conditions apply, let mktime() determine the DST flag for the current timestamp.To implement this approach, you would need to store the most recent timestamp persistently between measurements, preferably using non-volatile storage (NVS) on the ESP32 device. You could also

Conversation.Prompt: Continue
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTkeep track of the previous DST flag so that you can use it to disambiguate the current timestamp if necessary.Here's an example implementation of this approach:[CODE_BLOCK_0]

Conversation.Prompt: Continue

ListOfCode.Content:
In this implementation, we use the NVS to store the previous timestamp and DST flag between measurements. We first load the previous timestamp and DST flag from the NVS and use them to determine the DST flag for the current timestamp if necessary. We then store the current timestamp and DST flag in the NVS for the next measurement.

If the X element is not present in the timestamp, we can assume that the timestamp is in standard time. We can use the same approach as above to disambiguate ambiguous timestamps and keep track of the previous DST flag if necessary.

Note that this implementation assumes that the device's clock is synchronized with the local time zone. If this is not the case, you may need to adjust the timestamp accordingly before converting it to a Unix timestamp.

Author: hoshotakamoto
Title: Set up npm test in a github action.
Body:
https://chat.openai.com/share/c18aff35-93b2-4274-83c3-dc005b4812a2

I'm trying to set up the github action for running npm test but it complains that there's no package-lock.json

ChatGPT
GitHub Actions is a tool that enables you to automate, customize, and execute your software development workflows right in your GitHub repository.

You're seeing an error message because your repository doesn't have a package-lock.json file. The package-lock.json file is automatically generated when npm install is run and it describes the exact tree that was generated such that subsequent installs are able to generate identical trees, regardless of intermediate dependency updates.

Here are a few ways to resolve this:

Add a package-lock.json file:
Run npm install in your project's root directory locally. This will create a package-lock.json file if there isn't one already.
Commit and push the package-lock.json file to your GitHub repository.
Use npm ci instead of npm install:
If you're using npm install in your GitHub Actions workflow, you may want to switch to npm ci. npm ci is a more reliable and faster alternative for continuous integration environments. However, it requires a package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json file to be present.
Here's a basic example of a GitHub Actions workflow file for running npm test:

```yaml
name: Node.js CI

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    strategy:
      matrix:
        node-version: [14.x]

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
    - name: Use Node.js ${{ matrix.node-version }}
      uses: actions/setup-node@v2
      with:
        node-version: ${{ matrix.node-version }}
    - run: npm ci
    - run: npm test
```

Remember that you still need to commit and push your package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json file to your GitHub repository to use npm ci.

Disable the package-lock.json check:
If you don't want to use a package-lock.json file, you can disable the check in your .npmrc file by adding the following line:

```npm
package-lock=false
```

Please note that by doing this, you lose the benefits of having a package-lock.json file. Also, make sure to update your GitHub Actions workflow to use npm install instead of npm ci, because npm ci requires a package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json file to work.

User
Added package-lock.json to the repo.

```
Run npm ci
npm ERR! Cannot read property 'text-encoding' of undefined

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /home/runner/.npm/_logs/2023-07-04T20_22_56_587Z-debug.log
Error: Process completed with exit code 1.
```

ChatGPT
This error is indicating that there is an issue in your package-lock.json file. The error you're seeing is typically caused by a mismatch between the versions of npm that were used to create the package-lock.json file and the version that you are currently using. The npm ci command requires an accurate package-lock.json to work, otherwise it can produce errors.

Here are some steps you can take to fix this:

Update npm: If your npm is not up to date, some inconsistencies can occur. Make sure you're using the same version locally as in your workflow. You can update npm using the command npm install -g npm.

Regenerate package-lock.json: If updating npm didn't solve the problem, try deleting package-lock.json and node_modules then run npm install to generate a new package-lock.json. Make sure to push the new package-lock.json to your repository.

```shell
rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json
npm install
git add package-lock.json
git commit -m "Updated package-lock.json"
git push
```

Specify the Node.js and npm version in the workflow: You can specify the Node.js and npm version in your workflow to ensure the same versions are used in your local and CI environment.

```yaml
steps:
- uses: actions/checkout@v2
- name: Use Node.js 14.x
  uses: actions/setup-node@v2
  with:
    node-version: 14.x
- name: Install npm
  run: npm install -g npm@6
- run: npm ci
- run: npm test
```

Check for npm bugs: If you're still having issues, it's possible that there's an npm bug. You can check the [npm GitHub page](https://github.com/npm/cli) for similar issues and possible workarounds.

Remember, npm ci is specifically designed to be used in CI/CD environments and it can behave differently than npm install. Its main benefit is that it will catch and prevent inconsistencies between project dependencies, which is accomplished by being more strict in how it installs packages.

User
The github actions do npm 14, 16, and 18 so how am I going to force it to be a certain version

ChatGPT
You can specify the Node.js version you want to use with the actions/setup-node@v2 action in your GitHub Actions workflow. To test your project against multiple Node.js versions, you can specify those versions in a matrix in the workflow file.

Here's an example that sets up a test matrix to run your tests against Node.js 14, 16, and 18:

```yaml
name: Node.js CI

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    strategy:
      matrix:
        node-version: [14.x, 16.x, 18.x]

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
    - name: Use Node.js ${{ matrix.node-version }}
      uses: actions/setup-node@v2
      with:
        node-version: ${{ matrix.node-version }}
    - run: npm ci
    - run: npm test
```

This will run the npm ci and npm test commands in a separate job for each Node.js version. If you want to use a specific version of npm, you can install it in a run step:

```yaml
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
    - name: Use Node.js ${{ matrix.node-version }}
      uses: actions/setup-node@v2
      with:
        node-version: ${{ matrix.node-version }}
    - run: npm install -g npm@7
    - run: npm ci
    - run: npm test
```

This will install npm version 7 before running the npm ci and npm test commands. You could adjust the npm@7 to whatever version you want to use, just make sure it's compatible with the Node.js versions you're testing against.

Also, remember to push a consistent package-lock.json file to your repository that corresponds with the npm version you want to use. This file should be generated using the npm install command with the npm version you are installing in the workflow.

User
They already do that but you just said the npm ci step is complaining about the wrong version - so how can I have it support all 3

ChatGPT
The problem is likely due to the mismatch between the npm version used to generate the package-lock.json file and the npm version in your GitHub workflow environment.

To support multiple Node.js versions, you need to ensure that the package-lock.json is generated using the npm version that's compatible with all these Node.js versions.

This is what you can do:

Generate package-lock.json using the lowest compatible npm version: On your local machine, downgrade your npm to the lowest version that is compatible with all of your testing Node.js versions, delete node_modules and package-lock.json, and then do npm install to regenerate package-lock.json.
```bash
npm install -g npm@6  # adjust the version as per your compatibility needs
rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json
npm install
```

Then commit and push this package-lock.json to your repository.

Install the same npm version in the workflow: In your workflow, after setting up Node.js, install the same npm version that you used to generate the package-lock.json.
```yaml
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
    - name: Use Node.js ${{ matrix.node-version }}
      uses: actions/setup-node@v2
      with:
        node-version: ${{ matrix.node-version }}
    - run: npm install -g npm@6  # use the same version here
    - run: npm ci
    - run: npm test
```

This should solve your problem, as npm ci will now use the same version of npm that was used to generate the package-lock.json file, avoiding inconsistencies. However, this solution assumes that the npm version you choose is compatible with all your testing Node.js versions.

If you're using certain features or packages that require different npm versions for different Node.js versions, you may need to reconsider your testing matrix or find a different approach that accommodates your specific needs.
