Author: ikawrakow
Title: k-quants
Body:
### What

This PR adds a series of 2-6 bit quantization methods, along with quantization mixes, as proposed in #1240 and #1256. Scalar, `AVX2`, `ARM_NEON`, and `CUDA` implementations are provided.

### Why

This is best explained with the following graph, which shows perplexity on the `wikitext` dataset as a function of model size:
![ppl_vs_size](https://github.com/ggerganov/llama.cpp/assets/48489457/07aa49f0-4951-407f-9789-0b5a01ce95b8)

Note that the x-axis (model size in GiB) is logarithmic. The various circles on the graph show the perplexity of different quantization mixes added by this PR (see details below for explanation). The different colors indicate the LLaMA variant used (7B in black, 13B in red, 30B in blue, 65B in magenta). The solid squares in the corresponding color represent (model size, perplexity) for the original `fp16` model. The dashed lines are added for convenience to allow for a better judgement of how closely the quantized models approach the `fp16` perplexity. As we can see from this graph, generation performance as measured by perplexity is basically a fairly smooth function of quantized model size, and the quantization types added by the PR allow the user to pick the best performing quantized model, given the limits of their compute resources (in terms of being able to fully load the model into memory, but also in terms of inference speed, which tends to depend on the model size). As a specific example, the 2-bit quantization of the 30B model fits on the 16 GB RTX 4080 GPU that I have available, while the others do not, resulting in a large difference in inference performance. 

Perhaps worth noting is that the 6-bit quantized perplexity is within `0.1%` or better from the original `fp16` model.

Another interesting observation is that the relative quantization error (as measured by perplexity) **does not decrease** with increasing number of weights in the base model, as one might hypothesize based on the lower quantization error observed at 13B compared to 7B (see, e.g., [this table on the main page](https://github.com/ggerganov/llama.cpp#quantization)). The 13B model is indeed somehow better amenable to quantization, but relative quantization error goes back to the 7B level for the 30B and 65B models. This is illustrated with the following graph, which represents an alternative view of the data in the above graph, by showing the relative difference to the `fp16` model in percent. Note that now the x-axis, being the ratio of the quantized size to the `fp16` model size, is linear, while the y-axis (percent error) is logarithmic. 
 
![ppl_vs_size_relative](https://github.com/ggerganov/llama.cpp/assets/48489457/365b503c-086a-4f41-8a7a-3c0957f75219)


### How (Details)

In the existing `ggml` quantization types we have "type-0" (`Q4_0`, `Q5_0`) and "type-1" (`Q4_1`, `Q5_1`). In "type-0", weights `w` are obtained from quants `q` using `w = d * q`, where `d` is the block scale. In "type-1", weights are given by `w = d * q + m`, where `m` is the block minimum. I use this to describe the quantizations being added by this PR.

The following new quantization types are added to `ggml`:
*  `GGML_TYPE_Q2_K` - "type-1" 2-bit quantization in super-blocks containing 16 blocks, each block having 16 weight. Block scales and mins are quantized with 4 bits. This ends up effectively using `2.5625` bits per weight (bpw)
*  `GGML_TYPE_Q3_K` - "type-0" 3-bit quantization in super-blocks containing 16 blocks, each block having 16 weights. Scales are quantized with 6 bits. This end up using `3.4375` bpw.
*  `GGML_TYPE_Q4_K` - "type-1" 4-bit quantization in super-blocks containing 8 blocks, each block having 32 weights. Scales and mins are quantized with 6 bits. This ends up using `4.5` bpw.
* `GGML_TYPE_Q5_K` - "type-1" 5-bit quantization. Same super-block structure as `GGML_TYPE_Q4_K` resulting in `5.5` bpw
* `GGML_TYPE_Q6_K` - "type-0" 6-bit quantization. Super-blocks with 16 blocks, each block having 16 weights. Scales are quantized with 8 bits. This ends up using `6.5625` bpw
* `GGML_TYPE_Q8_K` - "type-0" 8-bit quantization. Only used for quantizing intermediate results. The difference to the existing `Q8_0` is that the block size is 256. All 2-6 bit dot products are implemented for this quantization type.

This is exposed via `llama.cpp` quantization types that define various "quantization mixes" as follows:
* `LLAMA_FTYPE_MOSTLY_Q2_K` - uses `GGML_TYPE_Q4_K` for the `attention.vw` and `feed_forward.w2` tensors, `GGML_TYPE_Q2_K` for the other tensors.
* `LLAMA_FTYPE_MOSTLY_Q3_K_S` - uses `GGML_TYPE_Q3_K` for all tensors
* `LLAMA_FTYPE_MOSTLY_Q3_K_M` - uses `GGML_TYPE_Q4_K` for the `attention.wv`, `attention.wo`, and `feed_forward.w2` tensors, else `GGML_TYPE_Q3_K`
* `LLAMA_FTYPE_MOSTLY_Q3_K_L` - uses `GGML_TYPE_Q5_K` for the `attention.wv`, `attention.wo`, and `feed_forward.w2` tensors, else `GGML_TYPE_Q3_K`
* `LLAMA_FTYPE_MOSTLY_Q4_K_S` - uses `GGML_TYPE_Q4_K` for all tensors
* `LLAMA_FTYPE_MOSTLY_Q4_K_M` - uses `GGML_TYPE_Q6_K` for half of the `attention.wv` and `feed_forward.w2` tensors, else  `GGML_TYPE_Q4_K`
* `LLAMA_FTYPE_MOSTLY_Q5_K_S` - uses `GGML_TYPE_Q5_K` for all tensors
* `LLAMA_FTYPE_MOSTLY_Q5_K_M` - uses `GGML_TYPE_Q6_K` for half of the `attention.wv` and `feed_forward.w2` tensors, else  `GGML_TYPE_Q5_K`
* `LLAMA_FTYPE_MOSTLY_Q6_K`- uses 6-bit quantization (`GGML_TYPE_Q8_K`) for all tensors

Not mentioned explicitly above is the fact that with this PR, all quantization variants use 6-bit quantization for the `output.weight` tensor. This lowers the perplexity of, e.g., `Q4_0` by about `0.03` at 7B.

The code is quite lengthy, so it is added via separate files `k_quants.h, k_qunats.c` instead of being added to `ggml.c`. I think that it would be better to also factor out all other quantization types from `ggml.c`, but that is up to @ggerganov to decide.

### Performance

The following table summarizes the performance results (perplexity, model size, run time for single token prediction). It is basically designed after the corresponding table on the [main page](https://github.com/ggerganov/llama.cpp#quantization)).

| Model|Measure|F16|Q2_K|Q3_K_S |Q3_K_M |Q3_K_L|Q4_K_S|Q4_K_M |Q5_K_S|Q5_K_M|Q6_K|
|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:|
|    7B | perplexity            | 5.9066 | 6.7764 | 6.4571   | 6.1503   | 6.0869   | 6.0215   | 5.9601 | 5.9419 | 5.9208 | 5.9110|
|    7B | file size             |  13.0G |  2.67G |  2.75G   |  3.06G   |  3.35G   |  3.56G   |  3.80G |  4.33G |  4.45G |  5.15G|
|    7B | ms/tok@4th, M2 Max  |    116 |     56 |   81     |     69   |     76   |     50   |  55    |  70    |  71    |  75   |   
|    7B | ms/tok@8th, M2 Max  |    111 |     36 |     46   |     36   |     46   |     36   |  40    |  44    |  46    |  51   |   
|    7B | ms/tok@4th, RTX-4080|     60 |   15.5 |   18.6   |   17.0   |   17.7   |  15.5    |  16.0  |  16.7  |  16.9  |  18.3 |
|    7B | ms/tok@4th, Ryzen7950X   |    214 |   57   |   58     |   61     |   67     |  68      |  71    |  81    |  82    |  93   |   
|   13B | perplexity            | 5.2543 | 5.8545 | 5.6033   | 5.4498   | 5.4063   | 5.3404   | 5.3002 | 5.2785 | 5.2638 | 5.2568|
|   13B | file size             |  25.0G |  5.13G |  5.27G   |  5.88G   |  6.45G   |  6.80G   |  7.32G | 8.36G  | 8.60G  | 9.95G |
|   13B | ms/tok@4th, M2 Max  |  216   |   103  |   156    |    148   |   144    |   95     |  102   |  132   |  134   |  142  |
|   13B | ms/tok@8th, M2 Max  |  213   |    67  |    83    |   77     |    83    |   68     |   73   |   81   |   84   |  95   |

I realize the above table is not easy to read, so adding a shortened version that shows a subset of the above data:

| Model | Measure               | F16    | Q2_K   | Q3_K_M   | Q4_K_S   | Q5_K_S | Q6_K  |
|------:|-----------------------|-------:|-------:|---------:|---------:|-------:|-------|
|    7B | perplexity            | 5.9066 | 6.7764 | 6.1503   | 6.0215   | 5.9419 | 5.9110|
|    7B | file size             |  13.0G |  2.67G |  3.06G   |  3.56G   |  4.33G |  5.15G|

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTI see that you have posted three kernel functions, namely kernel_mul_mat_q2_k_f32, kernel_mul_mat_q3_k_f32, and kernel_mul_mat_q4_k_f32. You mentioned that there is an issue with kernel_mul_mat_q3_k_f32. Let me analyze this particular function.The code in kernel_mul_mat_q3_k_f32 is quite complex and dense. It seems to be performing a highly parallelized computation on matrices, potentially with some form of quantization. It is difficult to pinpoint the exact issue without more context or understanding of the expected behavior. However, here are a few pointers that might help in debugging:Type Casting and Bit Manipulation: There are several bit manipulations and type casts involved in this kernel. Please double-check if they are as per your intended behavior. For example, the line const char4 sc1 = as_type<char4>(utmp[0]); casts an uint32_t to a char4 type. Make sure the bit manipulations are producing the desired results and not causing unintended side-effects.Memory Accesses: Make sure the accesses to the arrays x, y, q, hm, etc., are within bounds. Out-of-bounds memory accesses can cause undefined behavior or crashes. In particular, check the calculation of the indices.Thread Synchronization: The kernel uses barriers (threadgroup_barriers). Make sure that all threads reach the barrier; otherwise, you can run into deadlocks or race conditions.Accuracy of Computations: The kernel seems to be doing fixed-point arithmetic. Be mindful of the precision and rounding errors that might accumulate.Logic for Condition Checks: For example, in the lines:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Make sure that the logic and conditions are correct. Check the parenthesis and order of operations.Inputs: Ensure that the input data passed to this kernel function is valid. Sometimes the issue might be with the data that is passed to the function rather than the function itself.Hardware Limitations: Make sure that you're not exceeding the hardware limitations of the device it is running on, especially regarding threadgroup sizes and memory usage.If after checking these points the issue still persists, I would recommend isolating the problematic section by using a process of elimination. You can try using simpler inputs, gradually commenting out code sections to see when it starts working, and print statements (or equivalent) to understand what is happening inside the kernel.

Author: mskwon
Title: clickhouse-backup: Add support for sharded backup
Body:
This change adds a new configuration 'general.sharded_operation' which shards tables for backup across replicas, allowing for a uniform backup and restore call to the server without consideration for table replication state.

Fixes #639

Author: josecelano
Title: E2E test: torrent upload
Body:
E2E test for torrent upload.

### Strategy

I want to:

- Generate a random torrent file on-the-fly
- Select the torrent and submit the form
- Assert that the app redirects to the torrent detail page with the right metadata: title. description, category, ...

### Current status

It works with a fixed torrent file fixture. 

Example of the test passing on CI: https://github.com/torrust/torrust-index-frontend/actions/runs/5546141538/jobs/10126011522?pr=185#step:7:684

But the problem is I want to generate a random torrent file like in the [backend](https://github.com/torrust/torrust-index-backend/blob/develop/tests/common/contexts/torrent/file.rs) to be able to run the test many times. If you try to rerun the same test, it will fail because the torrent already exists in the database.

In the [backend](https://github.com/torrust/torrust-index-backend/blob/develop/tests/common/contexts/torrent/file.rs), we solved it by using a console command to generate the torrent file. Here it's not possible because with Cypress, we cannot use:

- Asynchronous functions in custom commands
- Use packages which need to access the filesystem.

Since it's run in the browser,

### Screenshot

![image](https://github.com/torrust/torrust-index-frontend/assets/58816/29d97755-d0be-4c4f-acd8-23de43230c2d)

Conversation.Prompt: I need to write a test for cypress where I'm testing uploading a torrent file to a website with a multipart form. I want to generate the torrent file on the fly and then fill in the form and submit it.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo complete your test scenario, you will need to do the following:Generate a torrent file dynamically.Create a test in Cypress for uploading the file using a multipart form.Let's break this down step by step:1. Generate a Torrent FileGenerating a torrent file dynamically within a Cypress test is not a straightforward task. The torrent file creation process usually involves reading a set of files and generating a metadata file (.torrent) with their information (including hashes for file integrity checking). This task is typically performed by a torrent client software, such as BitTorrent or uTorrent, or a library like create-torrent in Node.js.Cypress, however, doesn't support the fs module, which is used by create-torrent and other similar libraries to read files. This means you can't create torrent files dynamically within a Cypress test.As a workaround, you can generate a torrent file in advance and place it in the cypress/fixtures directory. You can use a library like create-torrent to generate this file, if necessary.2. Upload a Torrent File with CypressAfter you have a torrent file ready in your fixtures folder, you can upload it in a Cypress test as follows:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This test will:Visit your website.Find the file input on your page and upload the file from your fixtures directory.Fill in the rest of the form (you would need to adjust this to your own form).Submit the form.Make sure to replace 'https://yourwebsite.com', 'yourfile.torrent', and 'input[name=fieldName]' with values that match your actual website and torrent file.Note: For the file upload to work, you need to use the cypress-file-upload plugin. If you haven't installed it yet, you can add it to your project with the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_1]And in your commands.js file (which is located in cypress/support), add this line:[CODE_BLOCK_2]

ListOfCode.Content: npm install --save-dev cypress-file-upload
import 'cypress-file-upload';

Conversation.Prompt: How can I generate a torrent file using a public API?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTGenerating a torrent file using a public API is tricky because, as of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, there isn't a well-known, reliable public API that offers this feature. Most torrent generation processes are performed locally with specific torrent client software or using programming libraries in languages such as Python, JavaScript, etc.However, suppose you are developing a web-based application and don't want to depend on local resources or generate the torrent file in advance. In that case, you could consider developing a simple backend service that uses a library like create-torrent in Node.js to generate torrent files.Here is a basic example of what this might look like:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this script, an Express.js server creates a torrent file when you access the /create-torrent endpoint. The server then sends the created torrent file back as a download.You can then use this service in your Cypress test to download the torrent file and save it in the fixtures directory before running the test for file upload.But this is a workaround and may not be ideal in all cases. Remember to replace 'path-to-your-file' and 'my-torrent.torrent' with the correct file path and desired torrent file name.As mentioned earlier, keep in mind that APIs and libraries are constantly evolving, so there might be a public API for generating torrent files that was introduced after my last training data in September 2021. Always consider researching the most recent and suitable tools for your requirements.

Conversation.Prompt: How can create torrent file from a random torrent file from a memory buffer using "createTorrent" function. I want to do it from Cypress which as you mentioned does not allow to access the file system from the browser
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTGiven that Cypress doesn't support the Node.js fs module, we can't directly use libraries like create-torrent in a Cypress test. A workaround would be to use an API route on your server side, which will receive the torrent file buffer, create a new torrent file and return the new torrent metadata.Here's an example using Express.js with create-torrent:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this Express.js server, we define a /create-torrent route that accepts a POST request with a JSON body. The JSON body is expected to have a torrentFile property that is a base64 string of the torrent file's binary content. The route will then generate a torrent file from the buffer, and return the torrent metadata as a response.Once this server is set up, you can make requests to this route from your Cypress tests to generate torrent files from a buffer:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This test will send a request to the /create-torrent route with the torrent file buffer, save the created torrent metadata to a fixture file, and then upload it to the website.Please note that you'd need to have the server running while the Cypress tests are being executed, and replace '...' with the actual base64 string of the torrent file's binary content.Also, don't forget to replace 'https://yourwebsite.com' and input[type=file] with values that match your actual website and torrent file.You would also need the cypress-file-upload plugin for this code to work.Lastly, remember that the server example is a very basic one. If you plan to use this in a production environment, you should add error handling and security measures according to your needs.

ChatGPTUnfortunately, the create-torrent library operates asynchronously and Cypress doesn't have built-in support for handling asynchronous operations outside of its own API. More specifically, cy.writeFile() and other Cypress commands are not actually executed at the time they're called; instead, they're added to a queue of commands that Cypress will execute in order.Cypress has good support for Promises, but the create-torrent library uses callbacks, which makes it difficult to handle its asynchronous behavior in Cypress.One solution would be to wrap the create-torrent function in a Promise and return it so Cypress can handle the Promise:[CODE_BLOCK_0]But, remember that create-torrent is a Node.js module and can't be used directly in the browser environment where Cypress operates. So, you'll encounter issues if you try to call createTorrent directly in Cypress. You would have to move the creation of torrent files to your server (like mentioned in previous responses), and then interact with your server via HTTP requests in your Cypress tests.

ChatGPTYou're absolutely correct that Cypress allows you to create custom commands to build dynamic fixtures. The command you provided is a good example of how to generate a JSON fixture file with random data.However, the difference between your provided command and the command you're trying to create with createTorrent lies in the nature of the libraries and modules being used. In the provided command, faker is a synchronous library that can be run in a browser environment, which is compatible with Cypress.On the other hand, createTorrent is a Node.js module which has the following characteristics:It's asynchronous, utilizing callbacks instead of Promises. This doesn't fit well with Cypress's command chaining.It relies on Node.js's fs module and other server-side capabilities which aren't available in a browser environment where Cypress operates.These characteristics prevent createTorrent from being used directly within Cypress.However, you can indeed dynamically generate fixtures, just like your example. You just can't utilize createTorrent directly within the Cypress environment due to the reasons mentioned above.I hope this clarifies the distinction between generating dynamic fixtures using faker and attempting to use createTorrent in the Cypress environment.

Conversation.Prompt: The createTorrent has an option to build the torrent file directly from a Buffer. I want to use createTorrent to generate the buffer and them pass that buffer to cy.writeFile
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn theory, you should be able to do that since Cypress can handle buffers. However, createTorrent is a Node.js module that uses the Node.js fs module and other server-side capabilities. It's not meant to be run in a browser environment, which is where Cypress operates.Trying to use createTorrent directly within Cypress could lead to unpredictable behavior or outright failure, because the library might be trying to access Node.js functionality that simply doesn't exist in the browser.However, If you're only interested in generating a torrent metadata in Buffer and you are sure it doesn't involve any file system operation, you might attempt to bundle the create-torrent library with your Cypress tests using a tool like webpack or browserify and use it in a limited way that avoids these server-side operations. Please note that this workaround might not work because create-torrent wasn't designed to work in a browser environment, even when bundled with a tool like webpack or browserify.If you absolutely need to generate torrent files on-the-fly during your Cypress tests, I would recommend creating an API on your server to handle the torrent creation. You could then call this API from your Cypress tests. Your API would receive the necessary data, use create-torrent to create the torrent file, and return the data to your Cypress tests. You can then write this data into a fixture file using cy.writeFile().The Express.js server example I gave in a previous message can be used as a starting point for creating such an API. It's not a perfect solution, but it's likely the most feasible way to accomplish what you're trying to do given the current constraints.

Conversation.Prompt: OK. The API solution seems to be too complex just to generate a torrent file on the fly. My problem is I need to generate random fixture torrents to avoid problem using twice the same torrent if I do not clean the database.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTI understand the concern. However, torrent files are not simply random data; they contain specific metadata about the files they represent. This means that creating a valid torrent file requires at least some knowledge about the files being torrented. While generating a random text file and then creating a torrent file from it is theoretically possible, the requirement of running in a browser environment complicates matters.An alternative approach could be to create a collection of torrent files ahead of time and then select one at random for each test run. If you need to ensure that a torrent file is only used once, you could keep track of which files have been used and then remove them from the collection.Here's how you could implement this in Cypress:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this command, the getRandomFixture function reads the list of used torrents from the usedTorrents.json fixture file and the list of all torrents from the torrents.json fixture file. It then finds the unused torrents, selects one at random, adds it to the list of used torrents, and then returns the selected torrent file.This approach would still require you to generate the torrent files ahead of time, but it would ensure that each test run uses a different torrent file, even if the database is not cleaned up between runs.Keep in mind that you'd need to replace cypress/fixtures/torrents.json and cypress/fixtures/usedTorrents.json with the actual paths to your torrent files and replace cypress/fixtures/torrents/ with the actual directory that contains your torrent files.

Conversation.Prompt: i know there is a way to use a specific instance of S3 of SQS using boto3.client or boto3.resource by passing in a endpoint_url to these functions, but is there a way to do it globally using a set_endpoint_url function or something similar?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYes, you can set the endpoint URL globally for the AWS SDK using the boto3.setup_default_session() function. This function allows you to configure default settings for the AWS SDK, including the endpoint URL for services like Amazon S3 and Amazon SQS.Here's an example of how you can set the endpoint URL globally using boto3.setup_default_session():[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the example above, the boto3.setup_default_session() function is used to configure the default session for the AWS SDK. The region_name parameter is also set, but it's optional and can be omitted if not needed.After setting up the default session, any subsequent calls to boto3.client() or boto3.resource() will use the configured endpoint URL automatically. You don't need to pass the endpoint_url parameter explicitly every time.Note that the global configuration set by boto3.setup_default_session() will be applied to all client and resource objects created using boto3.client() and boto3.resource() without explicitly specifying an endpoint URL. If you want to use different endpoint URLs for different services or scenarios, you can still pass the endpoint_url parameter to the individual client/resource creation functions, and it will override the global configuration for that specific client/resource instance.

ListOfCode.Content:
import boto3

# Set the endpoint URL globally
endpoint_url = 'https://your-custom-endpoint.amazonaws.com'
boto3.setup_default_session(region_name='us-east-1', endpoint_url=endpoint_url)

# Now all subsequent client/resource creation will use the configured endpoint URL
s3_client = boto3.client('s3')
sqs_resource = boto3.resource('sqs')

# Use the S3 client and SQS resource with the custom endpoint URL
s3_client.list_buckets()
sqs_resource.create_queue(QueueName='my-queue')

You can install it via pip using the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Start LocalStack: Once LocalStack is installed, you can start it by running the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Verify LocalStack is running: After starting LocalStack, you should see output indicating that the services are being initialized. Look for a line similar to:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Configure AWS CLI: LocalStack emulates AWS services, so you can interact with it using the AWS Command Line Interface (CLI). To configure the AWS CLI to use LocalStack, run the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_3]When prompted, enter the following values:AWS Access Key ID: testAWS Secret Access Key: testDefault region name: us-east-1Default output format: jsonCreate a bucket: You can now create an S3 bucket locally using the AWS CLI and the LocalStack profile. Run the following command to create a bucket:[CODE_BLOCK_4]This command creates a bucket named my-local-bucket.Interact with the S3 bucket: Now that you have created the S3 bucket, you can interact with it using the AWS CLI and the LocalStack profile. For example, you can upload a file to the bucket:[CODE_BLOCK_5]This command uploads the file located at /path/to/local/file to the my-local-bucket bucket.By following these steps, you can run Amazon S3 locally using LocalStack and interact with it using the AWS CLI. Conversation.Prompt: how to use boto3 s3 with localstack running s3 locally
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo use boto3 with LocalStack running S3 locally, you need to configure the boto3 client to connect to the LocalStack endpoint. Here's an example of how you can achieve that:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the example above, the boto3.client() function is used to create an S3 client with the endpoint_url parameter set to the LocalStack S3 endpoint URL (http://localhost:4566 in this case).You can then use the s3_client object to call various S3 operations, such as list_buckets(), create_bucket(), upload_file(), etc., as you would with a regular S3 client.Make sure that LocalStack is running and the S3 service is available at the specified endpoint URL before running the code. Adjust the endpoint URL (http://localhost:4566) if you're using a different LocalStack endpoint configuration.Note that LocalStack may have limitations and may not fully emulate all S3 features or behaviors, so it's recommended to consult the LocalStack documentation for any specific considerations or limitations when using it with boto3 and S3.

ListOfCode.Content:
import boto3

# Configure the endpoint URL for LocalStack S3
endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4566'

# Create the S3 client
s3_client = boto3.client('s3', endpoint_url=endpoint_url)

# Use the S3 client with LocalStack
response = s3_client.list_buckets()
print(response['Buckets'])

Conversation.Prompt: how to use boto3 sqs with localstack running s3 locally
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo use boto3 with LocalStack running SQS locally, you can configure the boto3 client to connect to the LocalStack endpoint for SQS. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the example above, the boto3.client() function is used to create an SQS client with the endpoint_url parameter set to the LocalStack SQS endpoint URL (http://localhost:4566 in this case).You can then use the sqs_client object to interact with SQS operations, such as create_queue(), send_message(), receive_message(), and delete_queue(), as demonstrated in the example.Ensure that LocalStack is running, including the SQS service, and that the LocalStack endpoint URL is correct (http://localhost:4566). Adjust the endpoint URL if you're using a different LocalStack endpoint configuration.Please note that LocalStack may have limitations and may not fully emulate all SQS features or behaviors, so it's advisable to consult the LocalStack documentation for any specific considerations or limitations when using it with boto3 and SQS.

ListOfCode.Content:
import boto3

# Configure the endpoint URL for LocalStack SQS
endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4566'

# Create the SQS client
sqs_client = boto3.client('sqs', endpoint_url=endpoint_url)

# Use the SQS client with LocalStack
queue_name = 'my-local-queue'

# Create an SQS queue
response = sqs_client.create_queue(QueueName=queue_name)
queue_url = response['QueueUrl']
print(f"Created queue with URL: {queue_url}")

# Send a message to the SQS queue
message_body = 'Hello, LocalStack SQS!'
response = sqs_client.send_message(QueueUrl=queue_url, MessageBody=message_body)
print(f"Sent message with ID: {response['MessageId']}")

# Receive messages from the SQS queue
response = sqs_client.receive_message(QueueUrl=queue_url, MaxNumberOfMessages=1)
messages = response.get('Messages', [])
for message in messages:
    print(f"Received message with ID: {message['MessageId']}, Body: {message['Body']}")

# Delete the SQS queue
sqs_client.delete_queue(QueueUrl=queue_url)
print(f"Deleted queue: {queue_url}")

Conversation.Prompt: so when using localstack does it use the same localhost port for both sqs and s3?
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTNo, LocalStack does not use the same localhost port for both SQS (Simple Queue Service) and S3 (Simple Storage Service) when running locally. Each service in LocalStack has its own specific endpoint URL and port.By default, the endpoint URLs for SQS and S3 in LocalStack are as follows:SQS: http://localhost:4566S3: http://localhost:4572These are the default endpoint URLs for SQS and S3 when running LocalStack locally.So, when interacting with LocalStack, you would use http://localhost:4566 as the endpoint URL for SQS and http://localhost:4572 as the endpoint URL for S3. This ensures that you are connecting to the correct service endpoints when using boto3 or any other AWS SDK with LocalStack.It's important to note that these default endpoint URLs can be customized and configured to different ports during the setup and configuration of LocalStack if desired. However, the default ports mentioned above are commonly used when running LocalStack locally.

Conversation.Prompt: using boto3 setup_default_session how to set different urls (referring to, for example, a localstack version of s3 and or sqs) for different services  (client/resource) like s3 or sqs
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTWhen using boto3.setup_default_session() to set different URLs for different services like S3 or SQS, you can achieve that by creating separate client objects with different configurations. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the example above, two separate sessions are created: s3_session and sqs_session. Each session is configured with the desired region using boto3.Session(). Then, separate client and resource objects are created using the respective sessions and the appropriate endpoint URLs for S3 and SQS.By creating separate sessions and client/resource objects, you can set different endpoint URLs for different services. This allows you to interact with S3 and SQS using the customized endpoint URLs.Adjust the endpoint URLs (http://localhost:4572 and http://localhost:4576) based on your LocalStack configurations for S3 and SQS.Remember that you can still customize and override the endpoint URL for individual client/resource instances by explicitly passing the endpoint_url parameter to the client/resource creation functions.

ListOfCode.Content:
import boto3

# Configure the endpoint URLs for different services
s3_endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4572'
sqs_endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4576'

# Set up separate sessions for different services
s3_session = boto3.Session(region_name='us-east-1')
sqs_session = boto3.Session(region_name='us-east-1')

# Create S3 client and resource with the custom endpoint URL
s3_client = s3_session.client('s3', endpoint_url=s3_endpoint_url)
s3_resource = s3_session.resource('s3', endpoint_url=s3_endpoint_url)

# Create SQS client and resource with the custom endpoint URL
sqs_client = sqs_session.client('sqs', endpoint_url=sqs_endpoint_url)
sqs_resource = sqs_session.resource('sqs', endpoint_url=sqs_endpoint_url)

# Use the S3 and SQS clients and resources with the custom endpoint URLs
s3_client.list_buckets()
sqs_client.list_queues()

Conversation.Prompt: but i would like to do something like globally so i can take advantage of using a different (localstack) endpoint for s3 or sqs but i do not want to have to change existing code which calls boto3.client or boto3.resource without any endpoint_url argument
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTI apologize for the confusion. To globally set different endpoint URLs for different services (e.g., S3 or SQS) in boto3 without changing existing code, you can create custom session objects for each service and use the register_* methods to register them as default session factories. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, two custom sessions (s3_session and sqs_session) are created with different endpoint URLs for S3 and SQS, respectively. The register_* methods are used to register the custom sessions as default session factories for S3 and SQS.After setting up the default sessions, any subsequent calls to boto3.client() or boto3.resource() for S3 or SQS will automatically use the registered sessions and their associated endpoint URLs, without needing to explicitly pass the endpoint_url argument.Note that the code above uses the get_default_s3_signer() and inject_endpoint_url() methods to handle signing and injecting the endpoint URL into requests. The event listeners are registered to ensure the correct behavior with the custom sessions.Please keep in mind that this approach modifies the default behavior of boto3 globally, so use it with caution and thoroughly test it in your specific use case.

ListOfCode.Content:
import boto3
from botocore.client import Config

# Configure the endpoint URLs for different services
s3_endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4572'
sqs_endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4576'

# Create custom session objects with different endpoint URLs
s3_session = boto3.session.Session()
sqs_session = boto3.session.Session()

s3_session.resource('s3').meta.client.meta.events.register(
    'choose-signer.s3.*', boto3.session.Session().get_default_s3_signer)
s3_session.client('s3').meta.events.register(
    'choose-signer.s3.*', boto3.session.Session().get_default_s3_signer)
s3_session.client('s3').meta.events.register(
    'choose-signer.s3.*', boto3.session.Session().get_default_s3_signer)

sqs_session.resource('sqs').meta.client.meta.events.register(
    'choose-signer.sqs.*', boto3.session.Session().get_default_s3_signer)
sqs_session.client('sqs').meta.events.register(
    'choose-signer.sqs.*', boto3.session.Session().get_default_s3_signer)
sqs_session.client('sqs').meta.events.register(
    'choose-signer.sqs.*', boto3.session.Session().get_default_s3_signer)

s3_session.client('s3').meta.events.register(
    'before-sign.s3', boto3.session.Session().inject_endpoint_url)
sqs_session.client('sqs').meta.events.register(
    'before-sign.s3', boto3.session.Session().inject_endpoint_url)

# Set the custom sessions as default session factories
boto3.setup_default_session(
    region_name='us-east-1', 
    botocore_session=s3_session,
    session=boto3.DEFAULT_SESSION)

boto3.setup_default_session(
    region_name='us-east-1', 
    botocore_session=sqs_session,
    session=boto3.DEFAULT_SESSION)

# Now all subsequent client/resource creation will use the registered sessions
s3_client = boto3.client('s3')
sqs_resource = boto3.resource('sqs')

# Use the S3 client and SQS resource with the custom endpoint URLs
s3_client.list_buckets()
sqs_resource.list_queues()

Author: stillmatic
Title: feat: allow more input types to functions, fix tests
Body:
See discussion in #360 -- having just the bytes here is much more maintainable than trying to maintain the entire JSONSchema spec. I have tested that the OpenAI model accepts additional jsonschema params (of which there can be many).

Also, when verifying the behavior, I found that the ChatCompletion and Completion servers weren't actually trying to make completions. Converting `req.N` to a minimum of 1 should fix that.

Conversation.Prompt:
write a golang custom JSON marshaler
```
type FunctionDefine struct {
	Name        string `json:"name"`
	Description string `json:"description,omitempty"`
	// Parameters is a JSONSchema object describing the function. Generate it via another library.
	ParametersRaw json.RawMessage 
   Parameters parametersObj
}
```
 assume that `parametersObj` already marshals to JSON properly. in this case, if `parametersRaw` is available, then we should use that in the marshaled array, but otherwise, we should use parametersObj.
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTTo create a custom JSON marshaler, we need to implement the MarshalJSON method on our type.Here is how you can achieve this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the above code, FunctionDefine has two fields that both represent "parameters". The MarshalJSON method first checks if ParametersRaw is non-nil. If it is, it uses ParametersRaw as the source for the "parameters" field in the JSON output. If ParametersRaw is nil, it marshals Parameters instead, and uses the result as the source for the "parameters" field.This is achieved by creating an anonymous struct with the same structure as FunctionDefine, but with a new Parameters field. This new field is of type json.RawMessage, which can hold a raw slice of bytes that is included as-is when marshaling to JSON.In the call to json.Marshal, the code passes a pointer to a new instance of this anonymous struct. It sets the Alias field to a new Alias (alias of FunctionDefine) instance pointing to fd, and sets the Parameters field to the parameters variable prepared earlier. As a result, the fields of fd (except ParametersRaw and Parameters) are included as-is in the JSON output, and the "parameters" field in the JSON output is sourced from either ParametersRaw or Parameters as appropriate.Note: the Alias is used to prevent infinite recursion in the MarshalJSON method.

Conversation.Prompt:
Let's say I have a table called `responses` with a text field called `comment` that can contain strings like these:

"I got a lot of help from @4154 and @64 this week."
"@4154 thanks a million!!! Also @12"

How would I do a query using Ruby on Rails to return all of the numbers that exist in the table into an array? For example `[4154, 64, 4154, 12]`
Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTYou could do this in several steps in Ruby on Rails using ActiveRecord (the database interface in Rails) and regular expressions.First, you'll need to pull all the comments from your database. Then you'll extract the user ID's using a regex match, and finally, you'll flatten the array (since the match method returns an array of matches).Here's an example on how you might do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This will give you an array of integers like [4154, 64, 4154, 12].Keep in mind this is a simple example and might not cover more complex use cases. For example, it assumes that the "@" character is always immediately followed by the user ID without any space. It also assumes that every string of numbers is a user ID, even if it isn't preceded by the "@" character. You would need a more complex regex if your actual use case doesn't meet these assumptions.

ListOfCode.Content:
# Get all comments from the responses table
comments = Response.pluck(:comment)

# Define regex pattern for @ followed by digits
pattern = /@(\d+)/

# Extract all user ID's into an array
user_ids = comments.map { |comment| comment.scan(pattern) }.flatten

# Convert all elements to integer (as they will be strings after the regex)
user_ids = user_ids.map(&:to_i)

The data will not be deleted when the browser is closed, and will be available the next day, week, or year.Here's an example of how you might use it for your game:game.js[CODE_BLOCK_0]game.test.js[CODE_BLOCK_1]With this implementation, the game will remember each user's picks for each contest. When the user starts playing, the game will display the rikishi they selected along with their previous picks. The picks are stored in the localStorage, and they're organized by user and by contest month and year. The test checks whether the game behaves as expected when a user starts playing. It uses a localStorage mock to simulate a situation where a user has a previous pick.

The backfillResults() function backfills contest results for the current user based on the contest name and rikishi selection entered in the backfill inputs. Author: hoshotakamoto
Title: Addressing module not defined error in browser.

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTThe error "module is not defined" indicates that you are trying to use Node.js-style module exports in a client-side context. The module.exports syntax is common in Node.js for exporting functions or objects for use in other files, but it isn't available natively in the browser environment.You can use a different method to export your functions if you want them to be accessible elsewhere, or you can simply remove the module.exports line if it isn't needed. For example, if you want these functions to be globally accessible, you could attach them to the window object:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Or you could remove the module.exports line entirely:[CODE_BLOCK_1]The decision should depend on how you plan to use these functions.If you do need to use Node.js-style modules on the client side, you will need to use a tool like Browserify or Webpack. These tools let you write modular code for the browser that can be bundled up into a single JavaScript file to include in your HTML.

We can't use module.exports because we are working in a client-side environment, not Node.js.Since we're using Jest (assuming that's the case because of the structure of the tests) to test our code, we can take advantage of Jest's support for ES modules by using import and export syntax.The tricky part is how to make this compatible with the client-side code (in the browser) without using tools like Babel or Webpack. A potential solution is to use dynamic import() function in Jest to import the module.First, modify your game.js like so:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Then, in your game.test.js, you would use dynamic import() function:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This solution works if your Jest configuration supports dynamic import(). Note that this setup does not work in all environments. If you are having problems with the Jest configuration, or if it is not compatible with the dynamic import(), it might be easier to set up Babel or Webpack to transpile your code and allow import and export syntax. That would be a more robust solution for larger projects.

They can compile the code to ensure compatibility across different environments and allow you to write your code using the latest JavaScript features.If you decide to use Babel along with Jest for your testing, your code would look like this:In your game.js file, you would export the Game class:[CODE_BLOCK_0]And in your game.test.js file, you would import the Game class:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This is a more standard setup and should work smoothly as long as you have Babel and Jest configured correctly. Babel will allow you to use import and export syntax and will compile your code into a version of JavaScript that can run in your target environments. Jest will run your tests, making use of the compiled code.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>Banzuke Surfing Game</title>
    <script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js"></script>
</head>
<body>
    <!-- The rest of your HTML content -->

    <!-- Link to the external JavaScript file -->
    <script src="game.js"></script>
    <script>
        const game = new Game();

        document.querySelector("#startPlayingButton").addEventListener('click', () => game.startPlaying());
        document.querySelector("#switchUserButton").addEventListener('click', () => game.switchUser());
        document.querySelector("#backfillResultsButton").addEventListener('click', () => game.backfillResults());
    </script>
</body>
</html>

Author: CMCDragonkai
Title: Consolidating Configuration Entropy and Nodes and Client Services Refactoring
Body:
### Description

The configuration of Polykey has suffered from alot of entropy. This PR attempts to consolidate our configuration structure.

It's based on this comment: https://github.com/MatrixAI/Polykey-CLI/pull/4#issuecomment-1680131511

A note about task 5. It's important to understand that in `PolykeyAgent`, we have a bunch of dependencies that can be injected, but their injection is really intended for mocking, which is only for testing, not intended for production usage. This is different from optional dependencies which has legitimate usecases when injecting or not injecting. If we were to follow task 5. strictly, this would add alot of boilerplate to managing optional injected dependencies for everything in `PolykeyAgent`. And right now, there's no easy way to manage this without manually setting up booleans and conditional checks for all these optional dependencies. Therefore... task 5. should only be applied to situations where injecting or not-injecting is a legitimate usecase such as between `QUICSocket` and `QUICServer` and `QUICClient` and between `EncryptedFS` and `DB`. But optional dependencies in `PolykeyAgent` are the exception. IN FACT, because JS allows module mocking... we may even remove the ability to inject these dependencies and use `jest.mock` instead.

### Issues Fixed

* Related https://github.com/MatrixAI/Polykey-CLI/pull/4#issuecomment-1680131511
* Related #444
* Related #386 

### Tasks

- [x] 1. Move `*base` to `config.paths`. As these are path constants. They are not defaults to be configured.
- [x] 2. Separate "user config" from "system config". There is a bunch of constants that control how the network works, these are not supposed to be changed by the user. These are constants that we developers of Polykey tune empirically for optimal operation. Remember at this point of the abstraction, PK is an application, no longer a library.
  - `config.defaultsUser`
  - `config.defaultsSystem`
- [x] 3. Create a type based on `config.defaultsUser` and have it be referenced everywhere there needs to be some spread of the parameters that will be defaulted by `config.defaultsUser`. This prevents entropy where parameter names get changed and we forget that they need to be consistent.
  - What happens if you only use a subset of the default parameters? Do you end up creating a subtype?
  - All relevant types should be exposed in `src/config.ts` so that way it is always consistent, even if it is a bit weird. It gives us one place to ensure compliance between parameters that should have the same name and same meaning.
- [x] 4. Restructure configuration properties into a special `config` parameter, and do a deep merge
  - `PolykeyAgent.createPolykeyAgent` - create a `PolykeyAgentConfig` type
  - `bootstrapState` - also needs to use `BootstrapConfig`, but it's a far simpler type
  - Fix up `NodeConnectionManager` config
  - Fix up `RPCServer` config
  - Fix up `Websocket` config
- [x] 5. Create issue for injected optional dependencies not having their lifecycle managed by the target system. This was changed for EFS. It should also be the case in PK. This means only encapsulated dependencies are managed. This does impact alot of tests.
- [x] 6. Moved all QUIC client and server crypto into `NodeConnectionManager` and convert to using `keys/utils/symmetric` utilities rather than the HMAC SHA256.
- [x] 7. Move `QUICSocket` lifecycle into `NodeConnectionManager`. All of the QUIC transport will be now encapsulated within `nodes` domain.
- ~[ ] 8. Move all of RPC and websocket into the `client` domain, so that way both transports are encapsulated in their respective domain.~ - this is done in #560
- [x] 9. Flesh out all the connection and stream error codes for the application of the QUIC connection and streams to the node usage.
- [x] 10. Agent handlers should be moved into `nodes` domain if `client` domain contains handlers. We end up having "client service" and "node service", respectively meaning serving clients and serving nodes.
- [x] 11. Ensure that `webcrypto` polyfill has the correct `Crypto` type due to changes in Node's interface. Do this by using `as Crypto`.
- [x] 12. The `NodeConnectionManager` and `NodeConnection` have both pull and push flows.
  - Make `NodeConnectionManager` an extension of `EventTarget` just like `NodeConnection`. This prepares in relation to #444 for subsequent observable integration.

### Final checklist
<!-- Please check what applies. Note that these are not hard requirements but merely serve as information for reviewers. -->

* ~Domain specific tests~
* ~Full tests~
* [x] Updated inline-comment documentation
* [x] Lint fixed
* [x] Squash and rebased
* [x] Sanity check the final build

Conversation.Answer: ChatGPTIn the Rust programming language, whether or not you can mutate a value depends on its mutability and the kind of reference you have to it. In the code snippet you provided:[CODE_BLOCK_0]You're passing a mutable reference (&mut config) to the quiche::connect function, which means that this function can mutate the properties of config.However, after this function call, whether you can continue to mutate config in the calling code depends on what quiche::connect does internally:If quiche::connect consumes the mutable reference (i.e., stores it somewhere or uses it in a way that it becomes inaccessible), you cannot mutate config afterward in the calling code, at least until you regain ownership or another mutable reference.If quiche::connect only mutates config and then releases the mutable reference, you can continue to mutate config after the function call in the calling code.In the Rust documentation or the library's source code, it would typically mention if a function consumes its parameters, or otherwise has some unique ownership behavior. If the documentation or source code doesn't specify this behavior, the safe assumption is that after the function call completes, you regain the ability to mutate config in your code.To be certain about quiche::connect's behavior, you would need to consult the quiche library's documentation or source code.

ListOfCode.Content: let conn = quiche::connect(Some(&server_name), &scid, local, peer, &mut config)?;
